PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it correct that there is an estimated net shortfall of $1,100m in tax collections for the period July to December? Is it correct that instructions have been given by the Australian Taxation Office to place even further pressure on pay as you earn tax collections?

—The answer to the first part of the question has to be obtained from the Australian Taxation Office. I once said, in answer to one of these sorts of questions here, that I did not have any more knowledge of the Tax Office than I have of regular issues of Pravda, and I repeat that answer. I will obtain an answer for Senator Watson as quickly as possible.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does the Government expect the shortfall, which the Treasurer is aware of and which has been accelerating each month, to continue? What will be the impact on the projected Budget surplus?

—I have already answered questions on that matter this week. I suspect that the impact on the Budget surplus will be largely felt next year because of the lags in tax collections, but it may be already being felt. However, I will obtain an answer to that part of the question as well.

—I ask the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support whether he is aware of recent media reports about the poor interface between waterfront and land transport functions. How are these issues being addressed within the current reform program for the waterfront?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am certainly aware of this difficulty. As I have pointed out on a number of occasions, one of the great differences between Australia and, for example, New Zealand and the United Kingdom-to whom we are often compared-is that we have a federal system of government which has strict demarcation lines in responsibility between the Federal government and the State governments. Of course, whatever amount of reform the Commonwealth can deliver on the waterfront can be matched, according to the Inter-State Commission report, by the reform that is needed in the operations of the ports, which of course are State government responsibilities.

ANSWER.PARA: There is also a serious problem with the interface between the wharf and the land transport system, either road or rail. That matter is in hand in some of the agreements that are being progressed. For example, the National Terminals (Australia) Ltd agreement-much criticised-provides for a turnaround time of 30 minutes for trucks by providing a continuous discharge and receival cargo arrangement at its terminal and an earlier start-up time for the terminal to cope with the early peak period of demand for trucks. National Terminals also proposes to introduce some enhanced computer operations, directly aimed at reducing the truck turnaround time problem.

To sum up, there are three outstanding areas that will need urgent attention and which are currently getting it-and I hope I will be able to concentrate on them a lot more in the future when the stevedoring reform is accelerated. The first area is electronic data interchange (EDI), which has already had a very promising beginning in the industry and which has enormous potential. There are currently, in some situations, up to 100 paper transactions which have to take place in getting a container into and out of a port. That can be significantly enhanced by EDI, with great productivity gains.

The second area is the overhaul of the port operations themselves, which is principally a matter for the State governments but one which is being done in close cooperation with the Federal Government. A classic example of that cooperation is being exhibited currently in the port of Melbourne, and certainly in the States of Western Australia and Queensland which have recently completely overhauled their port authority structures, so a beginning has been made there.

The third and remaining one, that raised by Senator Faulkner, is the question of the interface between the wharf and rail transport system. That is currently being addressed by a special committee headed by Peter Morris, a former Minister, who has a particular interest in this area. I conclude by urging all industry parties who want to see some improvements in this area to make submissions to that committee because I am working in close cooperation with it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Social Security still stand by the views he expressed on the Sunday program last October when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I think it would be very difficult for us to try and upgrade training for the unemployed . . . I am not certain there is room in the system for more expansion, even if you could find the money.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been considerable debate on this very question. Quite a number of the groups that represent the unemployed and attempt to look after their interests have argued strongly that there is no point in increasing training during times of recession when unemployment is going up and therefore immediate hopes to get jobs are very limited. I can understand the thinking in that point of view. However, the Government has taken the view that, even if unemployment is to rise or remain at high levels, we should not waste the opportunity to improve the skills base of the Australian work force. Accordingly, if Senator Alston can wait until this evening, he will see the results of those Government discussions. I think it would be inappropriate for me to announce them in advance of the statement.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I take it from that that the Minister is saying that he no longer holds those views and, if he has recanted despite the evidence from voluntary agencies and the like, could he please explain what has changed since last October other than a desperate desire to try to keep down unemployment queues?

—I would always have a desperate desire to keep down the unemployment queues and I would be proud of that desire. It is not one that I will ever lose. In terms of why a change from then until now, there was always in the Government's program a very considerable upgrade in training for the unemployed. We are talking about a further effort caused by the fact that unemployment numbers have blown out since last October much more than we thought then. Consequently, the Government is reacting to it. I do not think that it is appropriate ever for a government to say that it will not react to changed circumstances. Circumstances have changed and, as usual, we are acting.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the meeting of South African and African sports officials held in Botswana over the weekend. What were the results of that meeting and what are their implications for the future of non-racial sport in South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —South Africa's return to international sporting competition took a very important further step over the weekend. Following a meeting of African and South African sports officials in Gaborone in Botswana, as Senator Schacht has said, an interim National Olympic Committee of South Africa-NOCSA-chaired by Sam Ramsamy, has now been established to assume the position of sole representative of all major sporting codes in South Africa. In that capacity NOCSA, the new organisation, will determine which sports have satisfied the requirement of non-racial unity, and then apply to the respective African and international controlling bodies to have sanctions lifted against those sports.

ANSWER.PARA: The first sporting body to affiliate with NOCSA is likely to be the new non-racial South African Football Association, SAFA-soccer, that is, rather than rugby, of course-which is to be officially launched in two weeks time.

Under the new arrangements agreed at the weekend meeting, SAFA will then be able to apply for membership of the Confederation of African Football at its September meeting in Dakar. Cricket, on current indications, would follow within a similar timetable very shortly thereafter.

These new arrangements have been approved by the African National Olympic Committees Association-ANOCA-whose President, Jean-Claude Ganga, attended the Gabarone meeting. These arrangements are expected to receive International Olympic Committee recognition when the senior delegation of IOC officials, including Kevan Gosper, visits South Africa later this month.

This important step towards the normalisation of South African sport is in complete accord with the strategy proposed by Australia and mapped out at the London meeting of the Commonwealth Foreign Ministers on Southern Africa, which, as I have previously told the Senate, affirmed the Commonwealth's support and encouragement for the non-racial unification of sporting bodies, cleared the way for a selective easing of the sports boycott on a sport by sport basis, and placed control of and responsibility for this process back in the hands of the South African non-racial sporting bodies themselves.

In this respect I noticed-I could hardly help but notice, because Senator Baume has been so noisy about it-the concern previously expressed by some senators that the Commonwealth's sporting policy was being held to ransom by the African National Congress or by ANC-affiliated sports bodies. In fact, the ANC and its affiliated body, the National Olympic and Sports Congress-NSC-have been the catalysts for the change that I am now describing and applauding this afternoon.

Let me emphasise, however, that NOCSA also consists not just of the ANC or ANC-affiliated bodies but of the two major white-run, establishment sports federations-the South Africa National Olympic Committee-SANOC-whose Chairman, Johan de Plessis, is now the General-Secretary of NOCSA, and the Confederation of South African Sport, or COSAS, which controls over 100 establishment sports organisations.
Finally, Australia will continue to monitor, encourage and support the normalisation of South African sport in accordance with the new Commonwealth policy, which I outlined in London last month.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware that the proposed multifunction polis (MFP) site at Gillman in South Australia incorporates an aquatic reserve consisting of mangrove forests? Does the Minister accept the opinion of the South Australian Department of Fisheries that these particular mangroves are vital to both the commercial and recreational fishing in St Vincent's Gulf? As sea level rise-and that is mentioned in the status report on the MFP-will drown the mangroves in the aquatic reserve and it will be necessary to provide for landward migration of the mangroves if fish stocks are to be maintained, does the Minister accept that the MFP proposal for the Gillman site is incompatible with the long term protection of this vital resource?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this point I could neither accept nor reject the assertion. There has been no environmental assessment of the project and there would not be any environmental assessment of the site proper until the South Australian Government and the Commonwealth Government have considered feasibility reports on the proposal itself. That will go on over the coming months and no formal environmental investigation will occur until a decision is made on whether to proceed with the next stage of the investigation.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a serious issue that would have to be addressed by the two governments in looking at environmental impacts. But that assessment would not occur until the governments had decided to proceed further with the project.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am pleased to hear that the Minister regards this as a serious issue. Am I to understand that the Minister does not know that the mangrove and the MFP areas are coterminous and, therefore, it is impossible to have one and the other one at the same time, and that no consideration has been given to that fact at this stage?

—I can only say that I do not know where the site is. I have not inspected it. I do not know where the mangroves are, nor do I know what effect the project would have on them. I am not attempting to prejudge something, particularly when I have not even seen it. I am not certain of how much the Minister knows about it, although I shall inquire. Knowing Mrs Kelly, she will make sure that, if what the honourable senator is saying is true, it gets a thorough investigation and an attempt is made to protect the mangroves.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Is it correct that alcohol, tobacco and illicit drug abuse in Australia is estimated to cost the Australian community at least $14 billion each year? If so, what action can the Government take in response to the huge economic costs of drug abuse in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that last week the Government launched a report from the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse, which I believe sets a model for measuring the costs of all drug abuse in Australia. It was estimated in that report that tobacco, alcohol and illicit drugs cost our community $14.3 billion. This is the value of resources which are unavailable to the community for consumption or investment as a result of past and present drug abuse. I suppose the more frightening statistic is that some 26,000 people die from direct drug use each year.

ANSWER.PARA: The costs to the community include health care, lost productivity from death and disability of workers, welfare costs, law enforcement and loss of life. It is estimated that the private sector and industry lose at least $3.7 billion in direct costs from drug abuse each year. Quite clearly, it is not up to the Government alone to address this matter. We need employers and unions to cooperate on industry reform, workplace health and drug education to stop this drain on our economic productivity. I understand that my colleague in the other place, Mr Staples, will be addressing these issues in a conference on drug and alcohol abuse in the workplace in Melbourne in April this year.

Tobacco and alcohol account for nearly $12.8 billion of the total cost to the community of the abuse of drugs throughout Australia. The Federal Government has taken significant steps in reducing tobacco and harmful alcohol consumption in Australia. We have banned direct advertising of tobacco on the electronic and print media, stopped smoking on domestic flights, interstate coaches and VIP flights and banned the sale of smokeless tobacco. In addition, there have been extensive education campaigns launched on smoking and alcohol abuse. Now the alcohol industry itself is ready to contribute to education campaigns and discuss broader issues such as advertising.

It is a fact that Australia has very large alcohol consumption compared with other Western countries. Drinking alcohol is part of our culture. It is vital that people practise safe consumption and remember that the National Health and Medical Research Council recommendation of two and four standard drinks per day for women and men is observed.

The costs that Senator Colston mentioned of some $14.3 billion per year are horrendous. The Government will continue to take action on this front in cooperation with unions, industry and the community, not only to have economic gains but to better safeguard the health of all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Is the Government aware that the Chief Executive of National Terminals (Australia) Ltd stated that he could not see any reduction in charges to waterfront users from the very enterprise-based agreement that the Government claims is a shining example of its waterfront program? If savings are not going to flow to users of the waterfront, what is the purpose of the Government's reforms?
—Is that a dorothy dixer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to get a dorothy dixer from the Opposition. I am very pleased to have the opportunity to correct this piece of nonsense, because Julian Manser has been widely misquoted. I am very pleased to have the opportunity because it simply confirms something I said five minutes ago. What Julian Manser said-and I am happy to send the honourable senator a copy of the speech, which was delivered in Sydney at a waterfront and shipping conference which I attended-was that the savings that will be achieved on the waterfront in the National Terminals agreement will not be passed on to users if those savings are simply eroded by increases in charges levied by State-controlled port authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: That is what Julian Manser said. It has been misquoted by the National Farmers' Federation and by the Australia shippers users group, principally I would imagine because it was initially misquoted by John Sharp, along with all of the other nonsense he puts out. I agree with Julian Manser. As I said a few moments ago, the Inter-State Commission report clearly identified productivity gains to this country in the port authorities area equivalent to those that can be achieved on the waterfront. It is a fact that if the port authorities see the opportunity, because they are under State governments-I must say, that in State-Federal relations, it does not really matter much what complexion the government is, whether it is Labor or conservative-they will certainly take to get a few more dollars out of the Commonwealth by whichever means they can. If there is any attempt made to increase port charges to take up the opportunity that is created by the provision of those savings, indeed those savings will be eroded.

It is extremely important that the State governments deliver on the question of State port reform. The Trade Practices Commission and the Prices Surveillance Authority have been deliberately involved by the Commonwealth in this exercise to make sure that the savings that will be gained on the waterfront with productivity increases in those enterprises will not simply be eroded away by some opportunistic action on the part of State controlled port authorities to increase their charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think the chief executive's remarks were probably referring more to the additional costs of these reforms. I ask the Minister whether the offset created by extra redundancy payments, multiskilling, retraining and investment in new technology will actually totally offset those factors that he mentioned and therefore lead to a situation where there are no real savings on the waterfront.

—I am afraid that Senator Tierney is absolutely up a tree on this one. The multiskilling program that is being introduced into National Terminals substantially produces a great deal of the productivity that is going to be delivered as a result of the National Terminals agreement. In fact, rather than delaying the time of the Senate any longer, I would simply answer this question by reiterating the offer that I gave to the honourable senator before -that is, to put the question beyond dispute, I will send him a copy of Julian Manser's speech.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is the Minister aware of moves within the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) to downgrade the status and functions of the Women's Bureau? Can the Minister give an assurance that the Women's Bureau, established in the 1960s, will continue to be given a level of status and resources consistent with the Government's own equal employment opportunity policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some information from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training on Senator Reynolds's question. I am informed that while there are currently changes being made to the Women's Bureau within DEET, these will not result in the downgrading of that Bureau. As Senator Reynolds quite rightly said, the Bureau has been in existence in one form or another for nearly 30 years and it has been recognised by the Government as having made a major contribution to improving women's participation in employment, education and training. However, I am advised that there is now a need to review arrangements for progressing women's issues in the portfolio. This need has been brought about because within a few months DEET will have in place for the first time national action plans in all major areas of the portfolio, covering higher education, technical and further education schools, and the Commonwealth Employment Service.

ANSWER.PARA: In order to make these plans more effective, responsibility for carrying them out has to rest with the program managers. So some of the staff of the Women's Bureau will be outposted to other areas of the Department to assist in the implementation of these action plans. I am assured by the Minister that there will be no reduction in portfolio resources devoted to women's issues; nor will these revised management arrangements result in the downgrading of the Women's Bureau. Indeed, the Director of the Bureau will be upgraded to a more senior position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I appreciate Senator Bolkus's reply. I ask: would he convey to Minister Dawkins the extensive concern of many women about the apparent failure of DEET officers to value the work of the Women's Bureau which could be jeopardised by what appears to have been a high-handed restructuring process? The mere mention of the word `outposting' in the Minister's response simply reinforces my concern. Would he be kind enough to convey that to Minister Dawkins?

—There are a couple of judgments made which, on the information provided to me by the Minister, may seem to be pre-emptory. I note that in the supplementary question there is talk of an apparent failure and also a high-handed process. On the information I have before me, I do not accept that these allegations are correct. However, I will ensure that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training has Senator Reynolds's supplementary question brought to his notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I remind Senator Cook of the Prime Minister's statement that no single sector of the community should have to bear the burden of trade sanctions against Iraq. Where does the Government stand in respect of the industry's claim of $315m for costs and losses borne by the wheat industry as a result of those trade sanctions-a claim which is in addition to the insurance claim that the Australian Wheat Board has made in accordance with its contractual agreement with the Export Finance Insurance Corporation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Kerin put out a statement yesterday on the whole question of wheat industry assistance and, in part, covered aspects of trade with Iraq. As Senator Boswell would know, the Government is not proposing to adjust insurance cover to any more than the current level, which is 80 per cent insurance cover as things stand. It might help Senator Boswell if I were to read from the media release of John Kerin on this matter. Referring to Iraq, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: The question of compensation for losses resulting from Australia's compliance with UN trade sanctions against Iraq will be considered at a later date. Already $72m has been paid out under the Government's national interest cover of sales to Iraq. These payments will reach $181m this financial year.

He goes on to refer to the adjustments that we will review for the rural adjustment scheme and what further funding we will provide to that mechanism as a better targeted mechanism for assistance to growers.

I notice as well that in an interview yesterday on the point of what further assistance or what further compensation might be paid, Mr Kerin was asked specifically the same question that Senator Boswell is now asking. He pointed out, in addition to what I have just said, that if the Wheat Board sells all its wheat this year, the compensation component is really the difference between what it would have sold it for, and what it might not have sold it for had the Gulf war not gone ahead. That is a matter that the Government is directing its attention to at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Prime Minister in his statement said that no single sector of the community should have to bear the burden of trade sanctions. I accept that the Government has met its commitment on the insurance payment, but 20 per cent of the wheat sales are not insured and, therefore, the burden of those uninsured sales would fall back on the wheat industry. How will the Minister meet the Prime Minister's commitment and compensate the wheat industry for the 20 per cent that is not insured?

—I understand the question. The effect is that the Australian taxpayer is picking up the 80 per cent insurance, and when the Prime Minister makes a statement that no one sector shall bear the whole of the burden, it should be immediately recognised that the 80 per cent insurance component is something that is supported by the Australian Government and the remaining 20 per cent is a component that can be supported by the wheat industry. However, Mr Kerin has said that one will not know what the effect of that is-and it is therefore difficult to respond to it-until such time as the Australian Wheat Board sells all its wheat this year, because the compensation component is really the difference between that amount and the price the Wheat Board would have got had the Gulf conflict not gone ahead.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Can the Minister inform the Senate how the finance sector has responded to the Government's deeming policy? Given Opposition claims to the contrary, is the Minister satisfied that there are adequate numbers of accounts available throughout the country? Can the Minister also tell the Senate whether the Financial Information Service for Pensioners (FISP) is achieving the objectives for which it was established, especially with regard to this deeming initiative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time of the Budget I predicted that the financial community in Australia would react properly to this new deeming initiative, and that is what has happened. In fact, it has gotten better and better, even over recent weeks. If I were making a statement as to the number of accounts available at call, three weeks ago I would have said 29; two weeks ago I would have said 33; and a week ago I would have said 39. There are now 44 accounts available at call, and the numbers are going up all the time. Thirty-three of those 44 accounts are special accounts that have been made available for pensioners.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously there is some variation in the conditions which apply to those accounts and that will always be the case in a competitive environment. However, there are now 26 accounts that pay 10 per cent from the first dollar-on the whole balance-and that includes three of the four major banks, that is, the Commonwealth Bank, the National Australia Bank Ltd and the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd. No doubt they are all doing well as a result of it. The State Bank of New South Wales and a host of the other larger banks have that now as well. A number of banks like the Advance Bank Australia Ltd and the ANZ Bank have actually improved their accounts in the past few weeks by announcing some changes. On that basis I think it is now able to be said quite categorically that the financial industry in Australia has reacted positively and the criterion I set down in the first place of 10 per cent available at call across the country is now well and truly met. That does not mean that I will not continue to monitor the situation carefully. I shall certainly do that.

There is now an extensive radio and newspaper information campaign under way to explain the new rules, and Social Security hot lines are also well and truly in use. I have written to all age pensioners to inform the ones who are likely to be affected by deeming and of course we now have the situation where we believe most of them have complied already. One of the most successful measures, however, has been the Financial Information Service for Pensioners. In the last Budget we announced there would be 32 more officers in that service. Over the four-week period ended 1 March, FISP delivered help to over 17,000 pensioners and beneficiaries, which is an extraordinary record, a magnificent achievement, and one for which we should commend the 61 FISP officers around the country. Given that, the level of confusion and fear is gradually dying down. I am very confident that within a few months this will be an accepted reform where every person affected by it benefits financially.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. It is about what seems to be a first-class proposal by the Federation of Vehicle Industry Unions, which has offered manufacturers a new industrial relations deal--
—Are you a pro-unionist?

—I am certainly in favour of the proposal being put by this group of unions. The Minister might notice that it is along the lines of our policy and not along the lines of the Government's policy. This proposal has offered manufacturers a new industrial relations deal in return for increased investment and long term commitment to local manufacturing. Does the Minister join me in congratulating the Federation on its enterprise and initiative? Does the Minister appreciate the need of the Federation in 1991 to call on manufacturers to invest `to improve quality, productivity, technology and industrial relations to world class standards in the short term and to invest in world class technology in the long term' is in fact proof positive that the Minister's car plan has failed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it may be news to the honourable senator but I will be saying something about that in the Senate a little later. The question relates to the initiatives of the Federation of Vehicle Industry Unions, which were really exposed in Melbourne a week or so ago at a seminar at which all the things that Senator Lewis referred to were put on the table by the relevant unions. I am very pleased to see that in the Australian Financial Review this morning, Mr Nasser, the chief executive of Ford is quoted as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: What they are talking about has to be part of the overall discussion.

If I might say so, I think that is a conservative statement of response to the initiatives taken by the Federation in terms of all those issues of quality, productivity, long term industrial agreements and so on. It is interesting that, in respect of some of these issues, it is the unions that have been taking the initiative rather than others. Even in the newspapers one is confronted with the situation where the management, in a sense, is responding to that initiative. So, yes, I share the view which Senator Lewis has put about this sort of initiative. I have been aware of it for some time and I have already passed my congratulations to the unions. I think it is a very promising outlook based on those views.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. There has been a lot of talk-indeed, leaks-about making pay television part of the Aussat sale. Could the Minister explain to the Senate what is the future for Australia's three remote commercial services, particularly Imparja Television Pty Ltd, when Aussat is sold to the new telecommunications carrier? Will Aussat's original purpose of bringing television to outback Australia be sacrificed in the interests of expediency?

—No, I will not, and I cannot see that it will make any substantive difference to their position at all. As I explained in the Senate the other day, and as Senator Kernot said quite correctly, there has been a lot of discussion and a tremendous amount of speculation-depending on which newspaper one picks up-as to what is likely to happen. The relevance of Aussat in respect of pay television is only that. The satellite is one means available for transmitting pay television-not the only means available. As a result, the people who will be bidding for the purchase of Aussat will have to get some guidance from the Government as to the Government's position on pay television. As I said before, Cabinet is currently considering that matter and the Government will announce its decision at an appropriate time.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I really do not think that the Minister addressed remote commercial television. What is going to happen to Imparja? It is extremely fearful for its future under the sale of Aussat. Who is going to pick up the community service obligation there?
—It is perfectly true that Imparja is fearful of its future and has always been fearful of its future.
—For different reasons.

—For the same reasons effectively. The sale of the satellite will not make the slightest difference to the problems that Imparja has got. Basically, the problem that Imparja has got is in providing an extremely important and, I must say, very popular television program to 80,000-odd-in fact, its carriage is larger than that now-very remote--
—It is highly subsidised.

—Thank you, Senator. The program is provided to very remote Australians in a highly subsidised form. It is the question of that subsidy which provides the question mark on Imparja's viability. It has got nothing whatever to do with the sale of Aussat.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. The report produced recently by the EPM Consulting Group on the projected supply of professional engineers in Australia confirms the projection of other bodies that this country is facing a shortage of 30,000 engineers by the year 2010. It further states that to fill this gap will require an increase in graduations of 60 per cent plus an immigration level 25 per cent above the average of the 1980s, or a graduation increase alone of 220 per cent. Has the Government considered the engineer shortage in Australia? What steps does it propose? When will a start be made, particularly having in mind the continual worsening of the position and the increasing of the opportunities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a very long running issue in Australia. There are always figures quoted about the employment of engineers compared with employment levels of engineers in other countries. I must say that the employment of engineers in Australia has been very much a cyclical thing, with upturns and downturns in the mining industry, for example. Indeed, it is reasonable to say that a decade or so ago it was the policy of some of the peak engineering bodies not to encourage increased numbers of engineering students because of those cyclical effects, which were very detrimental to the profession. That has certainly been said to me by people associated with peak engineering bodies.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the particular report the honourable senator mentioned is concerned, I am not familiar with that but it is consistent with other reports, and I do not in any sense query those findings. In terms of migration, I think it is true to say for both scientists and engineers that there has been a significant net increase in those professions in Australia from migration in the last few years. That is a good thing. In terms of student numbers, what the report says is probably correct-that there is a very pressing need to increase student numbers in the engineering profession. Sometimes that does not happen, however, because of the lack of applicants for those courses, largely, I suspect, because of a reluctance to teach what are sometimes called the `hard disciplines' in secondary education in the 1970s. That undoubtedly has been a problem. In respect of the general issue of engineering and engineering research in Australia, I understand that the Government will be making an announcement about that in the next few weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer the Minister to the comments made by Dr Arnold Mann, as reported in the Sun-Herald on 10 March 1991 and again on the 7.30 Report last night, that mammography screening may be of no benefit in reducing mortality from breast cancer. I ask the Minister, firstly, whether the evidence is consistent with Dr Mann's opinion. Secondly, if not, is the Minister able to reassure Australian women-most especially women aged 40 to 49, who appear to be most confused about the possible benefits of mammography-to allay any concerns they may have following Dr Mann's comments, and indeed those of Germaine Greer, as reported in the Sun-Herald a week earlier?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of Senator Giles's very important question for Australian women is, quite simply, no. Advice to the Government, as contained in the Australian Institute of Health's report Breast Cancer Screening in Australia: Future Directions was unequivocal in its finding that mammography screening for breast cancer leads to a significant reduction in mortality.

ANSWER.PARA: On the basis of the report's recommendations, in March 1990 the Government announced its intention to establish the national program for the early detection of breast cancer. The main features of the program, which is being phased in over the next five years and which will deliver a coordinated, quality service for Australian women, are that a doctor's referral will not be required; the service will be at minimal or no cost to those taking part; and all clinics and assessment centres under the program will be accredited to ensure a high quality service in both the taking and reading of the X-ray film.

Present indications are that with a fully operational screening program, 375 deaths could be averted if screening is of high quality, there is a high take-up rate and there is proper follow-up treatment of any abnormalities found. The reduction in mortality in women offered screening after five years is estimated to be in the order of 34 per cent. Women who regularly participate in screening can anticipate a reduction in their risk of death from breast cancer of around 58 per cent.

Turning to the second part of Senator Giles's question, I acknowledge that there is some concern among women as to whether they should participate in mammography screening. It seems to be most evident among women aged 40-49 years, who seem to be subject to much conflicting advice, as instanced by Arnold Mann's recent comments. The Minister is of the view that there is considerable evidence that the incidence of breast cancer rises rapidly between the ages of 40 and 49 years, from 23.7 cases per 10,000 in the 30-34 years age range through to 138 cases per 10,000 in women aged 45-49 years.

Screening for early breast cancers by mammography is generally agreed to be more effective in post-menopausal women but, nonetheless, is one of the most effective means of cancer detection for all women, regardless of age. The decision, then, to include women aged 40-49 years in the national program was made on the basis that to exclude these women from the program would prevent a large number of women from having access to a service which could be of great benefit to them. The age range will, of course, be monitored and reviewed regularly. Finally, women under 40 years, who either have a family history of breast disease or suspected early symptoms of malignancy, will continue to have access to diagnostic mammography services, including the accompanying Medicare rebate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to reports of suggestions that the Government's affirmative action program makes women second-class citizens? Can the Minister advise whether there is any logical way that the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act can be interpreted in that way? Can he advise what progress has been made in implementing the affirmative action legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the allegations that have been made. The suggestions are, of course, ludicrous and those who are making them are reducing this whole process to that of a joke-a joke on themselves, I might add. This Government introduced the affirmative action legislation five years ago. We have therefore had a chance to see it in operation. It was, at the time it was introduced, and it continues to be, legislation that is based on merit as a basis for employment and promotion at all times. Indeed, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in his second reading speech, when introducing the legislation on 19 February 1986 said:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is determined that women should be able to enter and compete in the labour market on an equal footing with men and that outdated prejudices or conventions should not prevent them from fully participating.
He went on to say:

I want to stress that the Government's affirmative action legislation does not propose positive discrimination or reverse discrimination. We are totally opposed to the use of quotas, and this legislation, by stating that all actions are to be based on merit, makes this clear.

The Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986 was introduced by the Government as a practical measure to remove barriers in discrimination against women in the work force. Those barriers do exist. Some of them include the long-held stereotype of what is women's work and what is men's work in the workplace and the lack of access to training and career paths for women. Only 11 per cent of all apprentices in Australia are women. If we take out hairdressing apprentices, only 3.8 per cent of all apprentices in Australia are women.

Another barrier is that women often, and almost exclusively, take responsibility for child-care in the family home and, thus, interrupt their careers accordingly. In addition, they frequently have two jobs-that in the work force and that of providing care and child-care at home as the so-called housewife.

There is also quite convincing documentary evidence to show that there is unequal access by women workers to over-award payments and indeed to overtime in the Australian workplace. Anyone who would argue that the legislation operates as reverse discrimination should have his attention directed to the remarks of, among other people, Mrs Carolyn Hewson, who is reported in the Australian today--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is she?
—She is the wife of Dr John Hewson, the Leader of the Opposition. She is reported as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: Working mothers should be able to bargain with their employers for flexible hours and childcare facilities to ensure equality in the work-force.

I might say that that is a principle on which this Government made submissions to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission last year in the parental leave case, and that landmark decision brought down last year enables that type of negotiation to proceed now. She also said:

Also, women are still under represented at a high professional level because they traditionally were seen as ignorant in areas of business and finance and because their careers were interrupted through child bearing and rearing.
The article goes on illuminatingly to say:

Although Liberal Senator Bronwyn Bishop agreed with this view, she said she opposed the Government's Affirmative Action program because it made women `permanent second rate citizens'. She said women should be able to compete on an equal footing with men to earn respect.
That is all a denial of what I have said and a denial of the right of equal opportunity for women in the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has nothing to do with the question.

—Senator Watson is getting the answer. The question was: what sorts of financial management practices have been put in place in Administrative Services to take into account these sorts of problems? Let me say: we have restructured the Department. It is on a commercial footing. It has been acknowledged by a wide number of commentators both within and outside government as operating quite successfully on that footing. The last one I quoted was Mr Henry Bosch, who talked of changes in Administrative Services as somewhat of a perestroika approach in governments in this country-fundamental changes that have placed imperatives on managers in government to provide services on a cost effective basis.

ANSWER.PARA: Our process has not stopped there. We are committed to continuing that process of reform within Administrative Services. If those opposite do not mind waiting a few more hours, they will probably get some more information in respect of that.

If I go back specifically within the parameters of a commercialisation approach in Administrative Services, let me say that there are quite extensive scrutinies which take place in terms of contracting out to organisations, either in the construction area or other areas of this Government. Whether tenderers are approaching Government to go into construction or to go on contracts for the provision of all sorts of services, there are quite extensive assessments. TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 March 1991, Senator Crichton-Browne asked me a question as Minister representing the Treasurer concerning the 1990-91, $8.1 billion Budget surplus estimated at Budget time last August, and how much of that was earmarked for payment of the government debt. I have obtained an answer from the Treasurer. It is somewhat lengthy. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

The 1990-91 budget statements indicated that of the prospective $8.1 billion surplus, around $7.1 billion would be available for debt redemption. It was envisaged that this would include scheduled Treasury Bond maturities of around $3 1/2 billion, redemptions of $1/2 billion of Australian Savings Bonds and around $1 1/4 billion foreign currency debt to be retired on maturity and through early calls and the exercising of sinking fund options. It was noted that there would be scope to repay additional domestic and foreign currency liabilities prior to maturity. The stock of Treasury Notes on issue was expected to remain at around the same level at year-end as at the beginning of the year.

A number of early calls, sinking fund options and repurchases of foreign debt have already been undertaken so that a total of about $2 billion in foreign currency debt will have been retired over the financial year. Redemptions of Australian Savings Bonds are now expected to be a little lower than was envisaged at Budget time. With the reduction in the expected budget surplus, the Government has announced that a program of Treasury Bond tenders will be conducted this year to meet maturing securities. In addition, it is now envisaged that we will exit 1990-91 with a larger stock of Treasury Notes on issue than at the beginning of the financial year.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FUNDING OF HIGHER EDUCATION IN QUEENSLAND

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March, Senator O'Chee asked me a question in respect of the establishment of a campus in Cairns. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided me with further information on this issue. I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

The growing demand for provision of higher education in North Queensland has been an important factor in allocating 1,600 new places to James Cook University between 1988 and 1993. This has been supported with capital grants of $19m. The Commonwealth does not however earmark places or operating grants for individual campuses. James Cook University has established a campus in co-operation with TAFE in Cairns and is currently providing courses in Arts, Social Work, Psychology and Community Welfare.

There has been pressure to invest in development of regional campuses in many regional centres throughout Australia in recent years. Before committing funds for capital development in regional centres, it has been Commonwealth policy to ensure that there is sufficient demand for higher education provision.

In all cases where there has been pressure to invest in development of regional campuses, we have requested that demand be tested by offering a limited range of courses using TAFE facilities prior to Commonwealth commitment to large scale capital investment. A recent newspaper report from North Queensland indicated that James Cook University was able to offer places at Cairns to all qualified applicants for 1991.

The Commonwealth also considers the educational viability of any projected development of new campuses. In order to be viable, a campus must be able to offer enough courses to enable students to complete their course of study. This means there must be a large enough student population to support the staffing levels required over the long term. It is important therefore to establish that the demand is growing.

As establishment of a new campus has very long term implications, the Commonwealth also requires commitment from States Governments before allocating funds for capital development. A Working Party involving the Commonwealth, the State and James Cook University has been established to oversee longer term planning for higher education provision in Cairns.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 March, Senator Bell asked me a question in respect of Austudy. The relevant Minister has provided me with further information on this issue. I seek leave to incorporate that further information in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
AUSTUDY PAYMENTS FOR CONTINUING STUDENTS IN 1991

AUSTUDY recipients are paid on a fortnightly basis. The last pay day in 1990 was Wednesday 26 December (actually prepaid on Friday 21 December). The first pay day in 1991 was Wednesday 9 January-exactly two weeks later.

In other words the system is designed to ensure that there is no break in continuity of payment for continuing students who lodge correct application forms in sufficient time for their forms to be processed prior to the first pay day in 1991. Obviously, if insufficient information is provided on application forms, payment cannot be approved.

DEET has established a national client service standard whereby 80% of applicants are to receive notification of approval/rejection of their application within 21 days. This standard is being met comfortably. Of those approved for pay the majority receive their payment within this 21 day time-frame.

The adoption of best management practices, together with innovations such as a major redesign and simplification of the notice of assessment and application forms specially designed for continuing students, have helped ensure that Student Assistance Centres can continue to improve the level of service provided to clients. These improvements have led to impressive achievements. In comparison with the first pay day in 1990, double the number of applicants received payment on the first pay day of 1991.

Urgent payments may be granted to students who are in financial difficulty, either as a result of their personal circumstances or because of delays in processing their application. Cases are processed urgently or counter cheques are made available in cases involving hardship.
Continuing students are catered for through the above arrangements and have no entitlement to Department of Social Security (DSS) benefits, nor should they.

For new students, transferral arrangements exist whereby a DSS benefit can be paid up until the day before the intending student commences full-time study. AUSTUDY is then granted from the following day and urgent payments may be made in cases involving hardship.

Even though the telephone number of a senior DEET official has appeared in a Melbourne metropolitan newspaper only two inquiries regarding hardship surfaced. I repeat my request last week for written advice of hardship cases being raised by Senator Bell.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, early this year the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) determined that he should deliver a major statement about what we must do together to meet the economic challenges facing this country. —Thank you, Mr President. Government has the responsibility to lead the community by getting the right policy framework-we will do that. But it is only with the understanding, the commitment, of all Australians-as individuals, and through their representative organisations-that our nation will best meet the challenges ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: What are those challenges?

The first is for us all to realise that this tough, increasingly competitive world of five and a half billion people does not owe, and will not give, seventeen million Australians an easy prosperity. The days of our being able to hitch a free ride in a world clamouring, and prepared to pay high prices, for our rural and mineral products, are behind us.
From this fact flows everything else.
The challenge for the foreseeable future, is to produce more than we spend. The rest of the world will not allow us to continue indefinitely to live beyond our means by borrowing from them.

Our rural and mineral products will remain important into the future. But the challenge is to add to them. That is, we must export more manufactured goods and services and substitute more quality Australian production for imports.
The challenge is therefore to make the decisions and adopt the practices and attitudes which will enable this and succeeding generations to achieve those basic goals.
Those are the challenges. How we are prepared together to meet them will determine the standards we can enjoy and the kind of Australia we will pass on to our children.

We will today announce a package of substantial new measures directed to the fundamental task facing this nation: improving the productive capacity of an economy that will be more internationally competitive.

Highlights of the package are: tariff cuts, reduced wholesale sales taxes for business, substantial business savings through simpler depreciation, retraining assistance, new support for apprentices and further initiatives in education and research to build the `clever country'.
The Treasurer and Senator Button will today be making more detailed statements covering the announcements in their respective portfolio areas.

All these measures continue and intensify the far-reaching reforms the Government has initiated over the past eight years. Ultimately, they sharpen our ability to reduce the current account deficit and stabilise foreign debt.
We emphasise that they share one overriding objective: building a competitive Australia.
In this statement we will reaffirm for the Australian people the longer-term economic goals to which we aspire, and identify the progress we are making towards them.

And we want all our fellow Australians to understand where the nation is moving and to understand how all of us-workers, employers and Government-have complementary roles to play in achieving our common goals. I say it again: in the final analysis the challenges ahead demand the involvement of all Australians.
The Australian economy is currently at or near the bottom of a downturn that has been sharper, deeper and more prolonged than we anticipated.
We acknowledge the recession has hurt many people and cost many jobs, and that is something we regret very deeply.
Higher unemployment is likely in coming months. Rural Australia in particular is experiencing a very tough period.
There are some important global factors at work. But we don't walk away from the Government's ultimate responsibility to manage the national economy.
And we certainly do not resile from having taken the necessary decision to squeeze demand by high interest rates.
Policy makers and commentators, in Australia and around the world, underestimated the strength of resurgent demand in the wake of the 1987 sharemarket crash.
But with the benefit of hindsight, it is clear that had we acted sooner to dampen that surge, some of the current hardship could have been avoided.
The question facing us now is not: will we emerge from the recession?

For the decisions necessary to end the recession have already been taken: official interest rates have been brought down by 6 percentage points over the last fourteen months; and tax cuts paid on 1 January will also stimulate demand.
Business will begin to rebuild stocks, and international confidence will be helped by the successful end of the Gulf War.

There are testing months immediately ahead. But the best estimate is that we will be coming out of the recession in the second half of this year. So the real question, and the real challenge, facing us is: how can we ensure that when we emerge from the recession, we will be best equipped to take up the opportunities for sustained growth?
In particular we have the opportunity to secure economic recovery:
- with low inflation
- and hence lower interest rates
- in an increasingly competitive and productive economy.
And this Government is determined to seize that opportunity.
That is what this Statement is really about today. It is not about short term palliatives, but longer term structural change to make us a more competitive nation.
That was what the Government set out, eight years ago, to achieve-through fundamental reform of long established economic institutions and of deeply entrenched attitudes.
We still have a long way to go but today we can certainly say that, together, we have made substantial progress: we are more open to the world and we are more efficient at home.
We are becoming more competitive.
1. Tariffs and Australia's trading future
Mr President, the most powerful spur to greater competitiveness is further tariff reduction.

Tariffs have been one of the abiding features of the Australian economy since Federation. Tariffs protected Australian industry by making foreign goods more expensive here; and the supposed virtues of this protection became deeply embedded in the psyche of the nation.
But what in fact was the result?
- inefficient industries that could not compete overseas; and
- higher prices for consumers and higher costs for our efficient primary producers.

Worse still, tariffs are a regressive burden-that is, the poorest Australians are hurt more than the richest. The Industry Commission estimates that the burden tariffs impose on lowest income Australians is three times heavier than that imposed on those with the highest incomes.

Right from the start, this Government deliberately and determinedly set about pulling down the tariff walls. By 1992 our existing programs will have slashed the nominal rate of assistance to the manufacturing sector by over one-third, from 13 to 8 per cent, and the effective rate from 22 to 12 per cent.
The results, the benefits, have been dramatic.
Since 1985, manufacturing output, employment and exports have all expanded at rates faster than the OECD average.
For the Australian consumer and business, prices for many goods are lower than they would otherwise have been.

Tariff cuts presented Australian manufacturers with a major challenge. To their credit, many of them are meeting that challenge. Their endeavours are too rarely appreciated and their success all too often underestimated.
Mr President, this Government will continue to open up the manufacturing sector and Australian industry generally through lower protection. We now announce:
* the general level of assistance will be reduced from 10% and 15% in 1992 to a general rate of 5% by 1996;
* tariffs on passenger motor vehicles will be phased down from 35% in 1992 in annual steps of 2.5 per cent to 15% in 2000;
This change can be expected to result in an average real reduction of $2,000 to $3,000 in the price of a $20,000 car, in today's dollars, over the next decade.
We also announce:

* tariff reductions on textile, clothing and footwear will be accelerated so that the maximum tariff will be 25% by the year 2000 and the termination of quotas will be brought forward two years to 1 March 1993; and
* general agricultural assistance will be reduced in line with the pace of tariff reform in manufacturing.

The dimension of what we have achieved is demonstrated by the fact that these changes will bring the average nominal rate of assistance down to 3 per cent, and the average effective rate down to 5 per cent, by the end of the decade.
All these changes will help keep inflation, and therefore interest rates, down.
They will also make our exporters and our import competing sector more competitive by lowering the cost of their inputs.
The overall impact of the reforms will be a net gain in employment, although jobs will be lost in declining industries.

It has been the Government's firm conviction that if the community believes that change is necessary in the interests of the community as a whole, then that belief carries with it a necessary corollary-that the community must not leave those individuals or groups who are adversely affected to bear the whole burden of change. It must itself be prepared to share that burden of change, as well as reaping the benefits of change.

Accordingly, we will establish labour adjustment programs to assist displaced workers in our car and textiles, clothing and footwear industries with relocation, training, and wages subsidies for redeployment to other jobs. This will cost at least $90 million over the life of the programs. Mr President, with these tariff cuts, we demonstrate once again our commitment to liberalising international trade.
The Government has been fortified in this approach by a number of recent reports, not least Dr. Ross Garnaut's report Australia and the Northeast Asian Ascendency.

We have rejected the views of the so-called ``new protectionists'' because they are simply proposing, in effect, the same discredited policies that had isolated our national economy from the rest of the world and caused the great damage we are all working to repair.
However much our competitors might bend or break the principles of fair trade, our own self-interest is served by a steadfast refusal to return to the days of protectionism.

But we don't for a minute seek to excuse those nations who do flout the rules of international trade, especially those who cause so much damage to our farm trade. The problem lies in the inadequacy of the rules on agriculture under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. GATT has been an outstanding success in substantially reducing manufacturing protection around the world. As a result, world trade in manufactures has boomed.
But at the same time, agricultural trade has been absolutely corrupted-particularly by the European Community and to a lesser extent by the United States and Japan.
Recently, their combined farm subsidies have averaged more than $300 billion-a year! And this for a sector which produces only about 3 per cent of their GDP.
This has imposed a heavy burden on our farmers: despite consistent large productivity gains, they exported the same volume of goods in 1989-90 as they did ten years earlier.
While world trade thrived, agriculture, one of our most competitive and significant sectors, has marked time.
So what further steps can we take to improve our trading position?

First, we will maintain our vigorous international campaign to achieve equal treatment for agriculture under the GATT umbrella. The Europeans already accept, due in no small way to the efforts of the Cairns Group, led by Australia, that there can be no result in the Uruguay Round negotiations without substantial reform of agricultural trade. We will keep pushing them hard.
Members of both sides of this Parliament have recently visited Washington, and will travel to Europe in coming months, to urge both sides to avoid the chaos and insanity of a trade war.
This international campaign by Australia depends for its credibility and impact on one thing: on our general willingness to practise at home what we preach abroad.

Second, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will announce a rural adjustment package in April to ensure that those farmers most in need during the current rural crisis receive appropriate assistance.

Third, we will help our farmers and manufacturers take effective action against foreign producers who seek to dump their products on the Australian market at unfair prices. We will strengthen anti-dumping procedures, including by cutting 40 days off the time taken to process complaints.
Fourth, the preferential tariff arrangements for Singapore, Taiwan, Hong Kong and the Republic of Korea will be phased out from 1 July 1992.

Fifth, we will provide $2 million to continue the Australian Made Campaign, since reducing our reliance on imports is totally complementary, in economic terms, to expanding our performance in exports.
Sixth, we will upgrade the services available to Australian exporters. In particular:

* We will boost the capital base and range of services provided by the Export Finance Insurance Corporation by making available a $200 million callable capital base to supplement EFIC's existing reserves.
* A new $50 million facility will be made available by EFIC, to enable Australian exporters to meet demands for performance bonds without using their own reserves.
* We will create a new program of fellowships so that Australian business men and women, and recent graduates, can get direct working experience in the Asia-Pacific region.
* We will implement the McKinsey report recommendations including refocusing Austrade's efforts on the Asia-Pacific region.
* We will transfer responsibility for Austrade to the Minister for Overseas Trade and Development from 1 September-

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Greater Efficiency and Competition within Australia
Mr President, with further tariff cuts, we are dismantling the barriers to competitiveness and efficiency that stand at the borders of Australia.
This Government is also set on dismantling the barriers that exist within Australia.
We have pioneered the concept, and the delivery, of micro-economic reform-seen by industry, rightly, as an essential means towards higher productivity and efficiency.

We are freeing up our transport systems; we have revolutionised our taxation system; we are creating more efficient workplaces; we are injecting competition where for too long Australian firms and public sector enterprises have been content with the quiet life.
And we are reforming the processes of Government itself through the Special Premiers Conferences.

In all this, perhaps no issue has achieved the prominence of the waterfront so essential to our export performance. It is particularly satisfying to be able to report to the Senate on the achievement, just last week, of a new agreement that will deliver breakthroughs in waterfront productivity.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, by year's end, the national waterfront labour force will have been cut by over 1,500-in anyone's language, a major gain in efficiency.

In telecommunications, in aviation, in road and rail transport, in removing through national uniform regulations the requirement for business to meet six or seven different standards, we are achieving fundamental gains in efficiency.

This activity amounts to the most ambitious plan, the most rapid pace, and the most comprehensive sweep of micro-economic reform this country has ever seen. Productivity is increasing, and new investment is taking place-all without industrial disruption.

And here we are witness to a paradox. Those who for more than a generation in office entrenched the inadequacies of the past and themselves effected no change whatsoever, now with an hypocrisy that is truly breathtaking, clamour for even faster change.

They bear an onus, which they simply cannot discharge, of showing how in a practical way this could be achieved without poisoning the better industrial relations and investment environment we have created-without, in short, bringing the whole reform process to a grinding halt.
It is a matter of our results versus their rhetoric.
We will press ahead with further reform, to increase competition and efficiency within Australia.
For the consumer, competition means lower prices and a broader range of better quality goods and services; for producers it provides the spur to better performance-at home and abroad.
We want to see the whole domestic economy opened up to this kind of positive structural change.
And we have established a sub-committee of Cabinet's Structural Adjustment Committee to examine systemically the whole economy for opportunities to promote this process.
The Trade Practices Act is our principal legislative weapon to ensure consumers get the best deal from competition.

But there are many areas of the Australian economy today that are immune from that Act: some Commonwealth enterprises, State public sector businesses, and significant areas of the private sector, including the professions.
This patchwork coverage reflects historical and constitutional factors, not economic efficiencies; it is another important instance of the way we operate as six economies, rather than one.
The benefits for the consumer of expanding the scope of the Trade Practices Act could be immense: potentially lower professional fees, cheaper road and rail fares, cheaper electricity.

This has to be done-and the Prime Minister has initiated the process, by today writing to the Premiers urging a positive examination of all we can do, at the May Special Premiers Conference, to widen the ambit of the Trade Practices Act to bring such excluded areas within the scope of a national framework of competition policy and law.
Investment for the 1990s
Mr President, to secure sustainable economic growth and the living standards to which we aspire, we need to ensure that there is a fertile environment for investment.
Our efforts to repair the macro-economic fundamentals underpinned rapid investment growth in the late 1980s-through the Accord, through floating the dollar, and through cutting Government spending.
There is, however, one other fundamental which is crucial to investment: inflation.
It is vital that Australians understand the debilitating nature of the inflation disease.

High inflation has brought high interest rates and a higher cost of capital than in our trading partners. This, in turn, undermined investment and made it harder for Australian firms to compete overseas.
It has also discouraged productive investment in areas that would generate jobs and exports in favour of speculation in real estate.
But today we have the opportunity of putting Australia on a low inflation path.
Australia's inflation is now below the OECD average: ours is 6.9 per cent and just 5.4 per cent in underlying terms and theirs is 7.2 per cent. A continued lowering of inflation--
