SPEECH.PARA: A continued lowering of inflation is, without doubt, the major contribution this Government can make to the climate for investment in the 1990s.
Of course new investment, combined with lower tariffs, has meant, and will mean for a time, higher imports and a higher current account deficit.
This becomes even more obvious at times when commodity prices are falling, as they are now, due to the slowdown in world economic growth.

But this is a short term cost we must bear if we are to wind back the current account deficit in a sustainable way and thereby reduce our foreign indebtedness permanently. We are taking the essential steps to build an economy that is stronger in the long term. There are other important areas where we can take action to foster productive investment.
The Government is very concerned at the difficulty which small and medium-sized Australian companies face in raising long term funds.
We are pursuing discussions with major financial institutions aimed at overcoming this difficulty by ensuring a readier flow of such funds.

The development of new industry and the rejuvenation of the old depends on ready access to appropriately skilled labour-access which is increasingly difficult in our sprawling cities, with their often inefficient transport systems. These factors also reduce the quality of life for the residents affected. We are cooperating with Commonwealth, State and local government to develop effective approaches to these issues.
Mr President, this Government has done more than any other to reform the taxation system so that, as far as possible, tax considerations do not distort investment decisions.
Today we announce:

* a substantial widening of exemptions from sales tax for business inputs used by manufacturers, primary producers and miners. The cost to revenue of this measure will amount in 1992-93 to $375 million. But the cost benefits to producers, allowing for the effects of mark-ups as goods pass along the production chain, will in that year total around $700 million.

* we have radically overhauled depreciation provisions to bring them more in line with business realities. The reforms provide, for the first time, a definition in the Act of effective life. And it will allow self-assessment by the taxpayer. This will result in savings to business of the order of $100 million in 1992-93.
* expenditure on environmental impact statements will be fully tax deductible over 10 years.
An industry which will benefit from these new tax provisions is tourism, which has generated over 100,000 new jobs during the 1980s and has the potential for substantial further expansion.
One sector of the Australian economy is unique in terms of the investment environment in which it operates-the forest industries.
This Government's consistent commitment is to the proper protection of our precious native forests. This has been, and remains, fundamental to our approach to Government.

But we recognise that-in part due to this commitment-there has been a contraction of the forest resource allocated to existing operations in the industry. Concern about future access to the resource has made new investment uncertain.
Accordingly, the Government has decided to provide resource security for major new wood processing projects
* where the project involves a capital- intensive value-adding investment of $100 million or more and is directed to export or to import replacement;
* where the proponent of the project makes a commitment to adhere to environment, heritage and Aboriginal policy requirements; and
* where the State Government agrees to enact parallel resource security legislation.

Resource security will involve undertakings backed by legislation, guaranteeing an agreed volume of timber supply from an identified catchment area. There will also be provision in the legislation to establish plantations to provide for long-term timber supply. The objective is to phase out woodchip exports by the year 2000 or soon after, and to replace them with value-added products. This new emphasis on plantations which will also, over time, take pressure off our native forests.

Mr President, the Government decided on resource security legislation only after receiving unqualified legal advice that it was the sole way the Commonwealth could provide a binding undertaking of the kind necessary to get major projects started which will provide new exports and new jobs.

Government has a duty to listen to and understand all legitimate community interests. It has a responsibility then to seek as far as possible to balance those interests where they compete. It should, where appropriate, establish processes aimed to achieve that purpose. In the end, Government must do what it was elected to do and make the necessary decisions. This will mean facing up to tough issues and it will rarely entail universal approbation.

So it is in this case where the Government has struck the correct balance between environmental concerns-to which our commitment remains vital and unambiguous-and the interests of one of Australia's largest industries.
4. Becoming a Clever Country

Mr President, I said at the outset that securing the future of the country is in the hands of each one of us. To achieve change, we must mobilise our most valuable resource: the talents of the Australian people.
This does not necessarily mean working harder; in Germany and Japan, both highly successful competitive countries, working hours are actually falling.
But it does mean working smarter-working more effectively, using new materials, new production technologies and new management methods. It means being, like Germany and Japan, a clever country.

During the last election campaign the Prime Minister said that Australia needed to become a clever country. The centrepiece of his commitment to that goal was the creation of a network of Cooperative Research Centres. He said that these Centres would draw together outstanding research groups to provide new drive to our national research effort.
Today we announce that the Government has selected the first fifteen Cooperative Research Centres. These Centres will focus their research effort on projects in the following key areas:
* resource based industries;
* manufacturing and information industries;
* the environment; and
* medical research.
My colleague the Minister for Science and Technology will provide details of successful projects this week.
The Government has also decided to continue indefinitely the tax deduction for spending on research and development at 125%.

Cooperation with our talented neighbours in the region is important if we are to remain at the frontiers of technology. The Multifunction Polis provides an opportunity to do this. Next month the Government will receive the report of the MFP Adelaide Management Group which was set up to assess the economic and social viability of the MFP.

Cleverness is not confined to our universities and `hi-tech' firms. Cleverness is something that should permeate the entire society-and especially our workplaces. And the foundation of a clever country is its eduction system.
The Government has repeatedly stated its pride in our achievements in virtually doubling the school retention rate, in expanding the number of tertiary places.

Quite simply, unless we give our young people the motivation and the opportunity to bring out the best in themselves through education, we shall never be able to bring out the best in ourselves as a nation.
Today we announce
* an increase in the number and average value of Australian Postgraduate Research Awards;
* extra funding of $15 million over three years for the Country Areas Program to focus on greater rural school retention; and
* $10 million over three years in a community project to identify the key elements of good schooling.

Ours is a dynamic region, in a world of ceaseless technological innovation and burgeoning knowledge-based industries. In a clever country, all of us, as workers and managers, need to upgrade our job skills regularly.

A recession can savagely damage the job skills of a nation. Apprentices have been hit particularly hard in the past-young Australians seeking to acquire and improve their job skills have been laid off with their training incomplete.

Accordingly, we announce a new program of assistance so that employers can retain and improve the skills of apprentices and other workers who would otherwise be working reduced hours or have been retrenched.
We will also spend $74 million over two years to provide work experience opportunities for people unemployed for more than six months.
And we will commit $50 million over the next fifteen months to provide additional pre-vocational training places, and we will seek State cooperation in this.
We will provide $6 million over three years to strengthen management skills.

Education is clearly a vital preparation for the work force in a clever country, but it is in the workplace itself that the skills must be developed if they are to yield the productivity dividend we so desperately need in our enterprises.
Our trade union movement has made an enormous contribution to the creation of a more efficient Australia.

Mr President, this Government has never been in doubt about the kind of Australia we wish to build-a modern, growing, prosperous and competitive economy, within a tolerant and fair society; a nation where quality of life counts for as much as quantity of output; an outward-looking community, enmeshed with the dynamism of the Asia Pacific region, and capable of taking on the best the world has to offer-and winning.
These are not short-term goals; they are not transitory values.
They are deeply embedded in the character of this Government and this Party.
This process of modernisation, of adaptation to the changing world economy, is not something that has some future cut-off point. It must be a continuing process.
There is no point at which we can say, reform is finished-because there is no point at which the world will stop changing.
And this is the essential point, Mr President. We live in a world of unprecedented, indeed breathtaking, change. Our own region is a crucible for change.
We can no longer afford the easy simplicities, the costly complacencies of the fifties and sixties and seventies.
I say ``costly'' because we are now paying the price for the neglect of those decades.
Our task now is to make sure that future generations are not called upon to pay a similar price for any neglect or complacency on our part, in this make-or-break decade.
We need the habit of adaptation-because the lesson of international competitiveness must be constantly learned and re-learned.

If we get the basics right in these critical years we need not set limits on our prospects. The Government does not avoid the fact that we hold these prospects out to you at a time of recession. But we should understand that Australia comes to this task with two great advantages-enduring advantages that transcend the temporary, but real, difficulties of the recession.

First, we bring to the task our great natural and acquired endowments as a nation-our vast material resources, our vibrant multicultural community, our strengths as a free and prosperous people, our proximity to the fastest growing regional economy in the world.
Second, in meeting these tremendous challenges that lie ahead, we are not, in 1991, starting out from scratch. We are not, in this decade, coming to the task cold.

We have already taken many of the essential decisions, we have already learned many of the vital lessons, we are already enmeshing ourselves with our region, we have already mastered many of the skills that we will need, to enter the next century with well-founded confidence that we will reach our goals.
But we must face the fact unflinchingly that we need as a nation to equip ourselves, further, to meet the challenges of exposure to international competition.

This has been central to the endeavour of this Government. It is central to the theme of this statement. It is the central purpose of the measures that we have announced today. It must remain the central challenge of this great nation for decades to come.
The involvement, the commitment of all Australians is the vital ingredient to success in the challenge ahead. It is a challenge that, together, we can face and meet with confidence.

DEBATE.TITLE: CHALLENGES AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRY

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, this statement is about the challenges and opportunities for Australian industry in the remaining years of this century.

SPEECH.PARA: It is about making Australia more efficient and making it work better.
There are two very clear economic challenges facing the Government:
* the recession and the problems which it is causing for many Australians; and
* the continuing restructuring of the Australian economy.
The recession has resulted in anxiety and reduced levels of confidence within industry and the community.
But it does not reduce the importance of continued structural change in the Australian economy.

Without continuing change and fundamental restructuring of industry and the economy, the next generation would inherit a much poorer Australia. We must improve our capacity to pay for all the products we buy from overseas.

In 1988 the Government introduced a general program to phase down most tariffs to 10 or 15 per cent by 1992. Prior to 1988 tariffs had already been lowered on an industry-by-industry basis. These tariff reductions were accompanied by other measures to enhance the performance of Australian industry.

These steps were essential to develop an outward looking and internationally competitive industry in Australia. Only by doing this could it be possible for Australia to take advantage of the rapid growth occurring in our region.
The task facing Australia in 1983 was daunting. As Professor Helen Hughes noted in her report on Australian exports, and I quote:

The difficulties of reversing the protectionist policies which have existed in some States for more than a hundred years and overcoming the structural and productive inefficiencies which they have created, cannot be achieved overnight.
This Government inherited a legacy of inaction from the previous conservative Government.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I repeat: this Government inherited a legacy of inaction from the previous conservative Government. I invite senators to listen, if to nothing else, to the next two sentences. For example, the average nominal and effective rates of assistance accorded Australian industry were not reduced over the period 1975 to 1983. As a result the huge costs of inefficiencies in our ports and transport systems were masked by high levels of protection, complacency and inertia.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1983 we have had an unchanging commitment to the concept of a growing and internationally competitive industry. Our strategies have been aimed at building a more productive culture within industry and the community generally, revitalising our mature industries and fostering the growth of new industries.
Despite the low base from which we started much has been achieved in a relatively short time.

The decline in manufacturing's share of GDP, in train since the 1960s, has been arrested. Manufacturing investment has grown at unprecedented rates over the period. In terms of the growth in manufacturing employment, production and exports, Australia has outperformed most other countries.
The record of manufacturing since 1983 shows that Australian industry can compete successfully against the rest of the world.

This statement will continue to build the base for continued growth in the 1990s. It involves the Government setting the environment for an internationally oriented, forward looking industry able to compete vigorously with foreign companies and to share in the growing prosperity of this region.

While Australian industry has grown stronger and more resilient over the last eight years, the rest of the world has not been standing still. Other countries have been assiduous in their pursuit of reforms, increasing their research and development, and generally improving their competitiveness. That is why we in Australia have to do more. We have to change faster.
These points have been underscored in the recent reports of the Hughes Committee, Professor Garnaut and the Australian Manufacturing Council, each of which has been a vital input to this statement.
The decisions announced today will assist Australian firms in facing the challenges of the 1990s.
REDUCING PROTECTION
General Reductions

Mr President, I turn to the question of reducing protection. In 1988 the Government introduced an across-the-board program to phase down all tariffs (except passenger motor vehicles and textiles, clothing and footwear) to either 10 per cent or 15 per cent by 1992.

If Australian industry is to compete successfully in the 1990s it needs to take a longer term approach to its activities. Equally, the Government needs to provide a stable, long-term environment within which industry can plan and invest. As such industry is entitled to know well in advance the tariff regime to apply after 1992.
Accordingly, general tariff rates will phase down over four years from 1992 to 1996 from 15 and 10 per cent to a single rate of 5 per cent.

This decision will finally put behind us the legacy of a highly protected, inward looking industry sector. It will reinforce the fact that Australia's prosperity can only be achieved by creating the environment within which Australian industry can compete internationally.

Most Australian firms have already responded to the challenges of reduced tariff assistance and are able to compete on equal terms with foreign competition. Indeed our forward looking companies dismiss tariff assistance as being irrelevant to their competitive strategies.
Passenger Motor Vehicles

I turn to the passenger motor industry. Prior to the current arrangements there had been a plethora of different assistance packages for the passenger motor vehicle industry. The current arrangements represent the first stable long term assistance package for the industry since the early 1960s.

This stability has given the industry the certainty needed to invest to improve competitiveness and integrate with the world economy. It has been able to compete with imports at lower levels of Government assistance and provide better quality products for consumers at lower real prices.
Under the plan which has the real tariff rate phasing from almost 100 per cent to 35 per cent:
* price increases have stabilised below the Consumer Price Index;
* model numbers have reduced from 13 to 8;
* average production per model has increased from 28,000 to 45,000;
* quality has improved markedly; and
* exports increased from $370m in 1984 to nearly a billion dollars last year.
The Industry Commission commented on the current plan in a recent report, and I quote:

In contrast to previous assistance packages for the industry, there have been some important positive developments under the current plan. First, a plan was announced and adhered to-most of the amendments to the plan made subsequent to its introduction did no more than restore adjustment pressure on the industry following the major depreciation of the Australian dollar in 1985 and 1986.

Second, for the first time in at least twenty years, there have been ongoing reductions in assistance to the industry. Third, the automatic provision of increased assistance to the industry whenever its competitiveness declined has been ended through the termination of import quotas and the local content scheme. Fourth, there has been some rationalisation of production facilities in the industry and the quality of locally produced vehicles has improved. Fifth, since the removal of quotas and reductions in tariffs in 1988, there has been a fall in the real price of both locally produced and imported motor vehicles.

The new arrangements announced today reinforce the stability of the previous plan and provide firms with certainty in the assistance framework they will face until the year 2000. Without such certainty firms would be reluctant to undertake the investments needed.

They also maintain the policy direction already established by continuing the existing rate of tariff reductions, while making the export facilitation scheme more flexible and rewarding to those firms prepared to make the investments needed to considerably expand their exports.

This will encourage the Australian industry to build on its past achievements of increasing its competitiveness, achieving a higher level of global integration, and improving product quality at reduced prices.

The Government is not prescribing a structure for the Australian motor vehicle sector. However, companies that limit their operations to Australia will come under increasing pressure from lower tariffs. On the other hand, companies that recognise the opportunities in overseas markets will be assisted by elements of this package.
Under the new arrangements, after 1992:
* tariffs on passenger motor vehicles and original equipment components will reduce to 15 per cent by the year 2000;
* tariffs on four wheel drive and commercial vehicles will reduce in line with general tariff reductions; and
* the 15 per cent by-law entitlement to duty free import of passenger motor vehicle products will be retained.

Export facilitation will be expanded and made more flexible beginning this year, while modified minimum production volume requirements will be in place until the end of 1996. The Government will commence negotiations with State Governments with a view to exempting the industry from offset obligations, and will introduce an improved labour adjustment package.

Consistent with the provisions of the Closer Economic Relations Agreement with New Zealand, the Export Facilitation Scheme will not apply on certain exports to that country after 31 December 1992. Consequential issues relating to this decision are the subject of discussions between the two Governments and a further announcement will be made in due course.

Mr Deputy President, since the introduction of the higher rate for the luxury sales tax in May 1990, there has been a dramatic contraction in sales in that sector. Monthly sales are now running at less than a third of the level over the years before the tax change.

This has serious consequences on the overall business of these vehicle importers. Vehicle importing is only part of the Australian operations of the larger luxury car companies such as Mercedes-Benz and JRA. These companies also have major bus and truck operations in Australia and are large employers of highly skilled labour, including many apprentices. The downturn in their car sales has put at risk these operations and their capacity to grow in Australia.
They have also been exporters of automotive components from Australia and have been integrating Australia into their world-wide sourcing of automobile components and materials.

To ensure that these companies can continue to contribute to the Australian economy the Government has decided to review the higher rate luxury sales tax and to revert to the May 1990 arrangements. These still include higher sales tax of 30 per cent for these vehicles compared with the general vehicle sales tax of 20 per cent.

These automotive industry arrangements will build on the achievements of the earlier motor vehicle plans in a way which will minimise disruption within the industry. The labour adjustment measures which are being put in place will provide the basis for an orderly restructuring process with minimum disruption to the people involved.

The success of these arrangements will depend on all those involved in the industry committing to the future. The Federation of Vehicle Industry Unions is committed to improving productivity, efficiency, quality, work processes, the work environment and industrial relations. The ACTU strategy for rationalising unions is important for the vehicle manufacturing industry. The current ACTU policy involves one union at any `greenfield' site. For existing sites, union amalgamations are occurring and the Government expects one manufacturing union in the industry within 12 months.
This should ensure a co-operative basis for progressing the constructive initiatives undertaken by the FVIU and lead to a more flexible and highly skilled work force.
An independent body will be maintained to monitor progress in the industry and report to the Government.
Textiles, Clothing and Footwear (TCF)
Mr Deputy President, as part of its review of overall industry assistance measures, the Government has examined the current TCF assistance arrangements.

As the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority highlighted in its 1990 State of the Industry Report, it is clear that the pace of restructuring in the TCF industries has not been sufficient for these industries to become more internationally competitive by the end of the scheduled Plan.

There has been, of course, a spate of corporate failures in recent times, which has caused significant disruption within the industries as some large companies have been placed in receivership. These failures have not been related to pressures arising from the Plan. Equally the recent downturn in the market for TCF goods is also largely a consequence of the general economic downturn, rather than adjustment pressures.

Although investment levels increased in a narrow range of capital intensive areas immediately following the announcement of the current Plan, this had more to do with implementing necessary investment plans held up awaiting a decision on TCF assistance post-1986.

Mr Deputy President, there continues to be a pre-occupation with protection levels instead of improving underlying elements of competitiveness such as technology, skills development, quality and service. This is evidenced by the generally poor take-up rate of restructuring assistance available under the Industries Development Strategy.

In spite of the general lack of performance of the industry some firms have taken the opportunities to invest and restructure their operations to become more efficient. For these firms the new arrangements will provide continued encouragement. As I have already outlined, the Government is committed to lowering protection levels throughout manufacturing and has put in place further reductions. The Industry Commission has often pointed to the high effective rates of assistance applying to the TCF industries-some 12 times higher than those applying to manufacturing industry generally.

To do nothing about TCF tariff levels or quotas would increase this gap without doing anything to improve the TCF industry's performance. There would be a continuing debate about the level of protection afforded to these industries.
This is undesirable.

Already, only half way through the current plan, uncertainty has been generated about the post-1995 assistance arrangements. The scheduled Industry Commission Report would generate further uncertainty, divert attention from improving firm efficiency and stall essential investment plans.
Accordingly, reductions in protection to the TCF industries will be accelerated and extended beyond 1995.

The revised arrangements for the TCF Plan will begin this year and will apply until the middle of the year 2000. This will provide a predictable and stable long-term planning horizon and enable the industry to plan further ahead than it is possible to do at the moment.
Under these new arrangements:
* the termination of quotas will be brought forward by two years to 1993;
* tariffs will be phased down to a maximum of 25 per cent by the year 2000; and
* bounties will be abolished by 1 July 1995, and where appropriate be replaced by tariffs.

The Government is also committed to the continued provision of up to $120 million in positive assistance through the Industries Development Strategy over the period until 30 June 1995. Furthermore, assistance to firms under this program will be made more flexible. In addition an Import Credits Scheme will be introduced to assist firms to integrate their operations into the global industry.

Under the current plan up to $50 million was allocated to a TCF Labour Adjustment Program to operate over the life of the Plan. While the take-up of labour adjustment assistance has been relatively low to date, the Government will ensure that current provisions are adequate for the needs of displaced workers. The current TCF labour adjustment arrangements and funding levels will be reviewed by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training.
These changes should lead to a larger, more export-oriented textile and tanning industries and smaller clothing and footwear industries capable of producing better products at competitive prices.

To ensure that the benefits of the lower tariffs are passed on to consumers, the Prices Surveillance Authority will monitor the prices of TCF goods from the beginning of the implementation of the new phasing arrangements.
Bounties

There are currently a number of bounty arrangements under which individual recipients may qualify for very small annual payments. Such payments are inefficient and do nothing to enhance industry development and we have decided to institute minimum annual payment thresholds for bounty eligibility.
Duty Reductions for Capital Equipment
The Government has decided to reduce the input costs to industry by removing the import duties on some capital equipment. Action will be taken:
* to remove duties on minerals processing equipment not made in Australia;
* to extend the coverage of the existing by-law which allows for duty free entry of goods for shipbuilding and ship repair; and
* to extend the split consignment provisions to some goods not presently covered.

The Government is disposed to continue a Commercial Tariff Concession System and introduce a by-law to allow duty free entry of state of the art capital equipment not made in Australia in the normal course of business.
A final decision on this is subject to consideration of the Industry Commission's report on the Tariff Concession and Bylaw Systems.
Anti-Dumping
As tariffs continue to be lowered, the Government will not allow unfair competition from dumped imports which damage local industry.
A comprehensive review of anti-dumping procedures and the operations of the Anti-Dumping Authority will be finalised by the end of this year.
However, the Government has taken a number of steps to immediately strengthen anti-dumping procedures by:
* speeding up the processing of anti-dumping and subsidisation complaints by Australian industry;
* providing better access to the system for Australia's agricultural and horticultural producers; and
* ensuring that anti-dumping actions are kept in place for a full three years wherever they are warranted.
Developing Country Preferences

From 1 July 1992, the preferential tariff arrangements for Singapore, Taiwan, Hong Kong and the Republic of Korea will be adjusted for tariff items which are phasing down. Tariffs applying to imports from these countries will be frozen from that date until tariff phasing brings the general tariff down to their levels. Thereafter the general tariff rate will apply to these countries.
Agricultural Assistance
Tariffs on general agricultural products will be phased down to 5 per cent between 1 July 1993 and 1 July 1996 in line with reductions in protection for the general manufacturing sector.

The Government has made no decision at this stage on longer term assistance for the dairy, sugar and tobacco growing industries, all of which have inquiries either under way, or foreshadowed, by the Industry Commission.

In the interim, however, the Government believes it appropriate that assistance for the sugar industry be brought back on track with the spirit of the 1988 decision, which was altered following a Senate standing committee inquiry.
The specific rate tariff for raw and refined sugar will therefore be adjusted from the scheduled $95 per tonne to $76 per tonne at 1 July 1991, and from $70 per tonne to $55 per tonne at 1 July 1992.
By maintaining a specific rate tariff, the sugar industry will remain protected in the event of low world prices over this period.

The Government is disposed to reduce assistance over the longer term for dairy, sugar and tobacco, equivalent to those now being announced in other industries. Full consideration of assistance to these industries will follow the Industry Commission inquiries.
COMPETITIVENESS
The phasing down of tariffs reinforces our conviction that growth and prosperity lie in building longer term competitiveness. Both Government and industry have vital roles to play.

The Government must provide a competitive environment so that firms operating in Australia are not disadvantaged compared with their overseas rivals. Creating this environment requires, among other things:
* an internationally competitive taxation structure;
* an efficient transport system;
* an education system able to produce a highly skilled work force;
* an innovative research and development culture; and
* competitive housing and construction industries.
The Government has already done much in these areas.
Announcements in this statement demonstrate the Government's commitment to do more to improve the business environment throughout the 1990s.
Governments can influence competitiveness. But only firms themselves can deliver the creativity and drive which build competitive advantage.
The management of firms must address the challenges of quality, design, marketing, and research and development.
Many firms are already operating in this way. To compete successfully in the 1990s all firms will need to do so.
Development Capital

The Government is very concerned at the difficulty that small and middle ranking Australian companies face in raising long term patient finance. A regular flow of such capital is a prerequisite for the development of Australian industry.

The Treasurer and I have had discussions with major financial institutions on ways of increasing the availability of development capital. The Government will continue to work with the financial insti- tutions to address the capital issue.
Research and Development

In the past, Australian public sector research has been excellent but the amount of research and development done by the private sector has been very low by world standards. However, with the introduction of the 150 per cent research and development tax concessions in 1985, industry is recognising the importance of research and development. As a result production is becoming more efficient and exciting new products are being developed and marketed.
A strong commitment to research and development is essential if we are to create and maintain the competitive edge necessary for success in the 1990s.
The Government has therefore decided that from 1993 the research and development tax concession will remain permanently at the 125 per cent rate.

Availability of this concession on a long term basis will enable the continuation of the research and development syndication scheme. These syndications have stimulated investment in close to market product development.

We need to continue to strengthen and develop effective links between research and its application. To this end the Industry Research and Development Board will focus more on the commercialisation of Australian innovations. The objective of obtaining a better return on Australia's investment in research requires continuing analysis of the commercialisation process and identification of barriers and actions needed to overcome them.

The Government has also extended the discretionary grants scheme into the service industries and has made market research an eligible part of a research and development project under the scheme. Legislation will be introduced so that Government business enterprises and Government contractors may be deemed to be Government customers under the national procurement development program.
Commercialisation of Public Sector Research

Australia's public sector research is a national asset capable of playing an important role in our economic development. However we do not yet derive the economic benefit from this research commensurate with the resources devoted to it. Promising public sector ideas are either not commercialised by the private sector in Australia or are developed overseas. This produces a lower return for Australia than might be achieved if they were exported at a later stage of their development.

The National Health and Medical Research Council will give increased em- phasis to encouraging commercial developments from research funded by it, and to making scientists more aware of commercial opportunities.
Also, an examination of impediments in the biomedical area will be undertaken.

The Government has a longstanding commitment to the development of the biotechnology industry in Australia. An area of particular opportunity is the development of applications based on fermentation of agricultural inputs such as sugar and wheat. However, commercialisation of Australia's leading edge research in this area is being inhibited by price distortions in both the domestic and international markets.
It has therefore been decided to support the continued development and com- mercialisation of this technology in Australia through a bounty on citric acid production.

I turn now to the question of advanced manufacturing technologies. The use of advanced manufacturing technology and advanced manufacturing techniques can make important contributions to industry's efficiency and productivity. We are, therefore, putting in place an advanced manufacturing technology strategy to encourage greater local production and domestic use of AMT products and services. This will assist the necessary process of change and improvement in our manufacturing base.

The advanced manufacturing technology development program will support joint projects for research and development, trialling and demonstration of innovative Australian AMT products and services which meet the requirements of local end-users. The program will also improve the take-up of new technology.

An amount of $20 million will be committed to the program over four years, commencing in 1991-92. The operation of the program will be modelled on the national procurement development program, but targeted at the private sector.

A review has been undertaken of the metal working machines and robots bounty. It is important in maintaining a key industrial capability and will therefore be continued. However, the rates will be phased down over time to align with the level of assistance provided to other industries.

The bounty will be extended to cater for current and prospective advances in the area of processing technology for new materials. Production of advanced and standard machines will receive uniform treatment under the revised arrangements, including, eventually, a common rate of bounty.
International Performance Benchmarks

Australian firms need to operate in the most efficient possible environment. However, Australian standards of efficiency in the provision of infrastructure services to business are well behind international best practice.

As part of our program to accelerate progress towards international best practice, the Bureau of Industry Economics will undertake, in association with the Business Council of Australia, a major research project on international performance benchmarks of business input services. This study will identify the key services which affect industry costs and develop measures to compare performance against best international practice.
Design and Quality
Australian products will compete successfully with their overseas competitors only if they are well designed and their quality meets market demands.
Quality and design are key determinants of competitive advantage. Increasingly, they make the difference between sales and lost orders.

The Government has supported the establishment of the Australian Academy of Design. More recently the Australian Quality Council has been established as the prime focus for the encouragement and development of quality within Australian companies.
Those companies which achieve excellence in the area should receive recognition for their own achievements and an opportunity to provide a role model for other companies aspiring to excellence.
We have decided therefore to increase support to Enterprise Australia, through the Australian Quality Council, for a range of awards which recognise quality achievements by Australian companies.

The Government will continue to support firms in acquiring skills in the area of design and quality through the National Industry Extension Service program, a joint Commonwealth and State/Territory initiative.
Product Liability

The Government is disposed not to accept the Australian Law Reform Commission's recommendations for a ``no defect'' product liability scheme. It will instead be developing a proposal based upon the 1985 European Community Directive on this issue.
The Government will consider shortly a detailed proposal along these lines from my colleague, Senator Michael Tate, Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs.
EXPORTS
Increased exports will help tackle Australia's current account deficit and international debt levels.
But if Australia is to prosper and advance through the 1990s we must not only lift exports, we must do it through a greater variety of high value added goods and services.

In this way Australia can share in the wealth created by the fastest growing sectors of world trade. Put simply, significant growth in our net manufactured and services exports is a pre-requisite to long term maintenance and improvement of our standard of living.

The range of export-oriented measures I now outline will better focus Government resources to meet the needs of Australian exporters. They will help maintain our competitiveness in international markets and stimulate in Australian industry an improved knowledge of Asian language and business culture. Together these measures will expand our contacts and trade with the fastest growing markets of the Asia-Pacific region.
AUSTRADE

The challenge of establishing or expanding an export market is often daunting in both financial and cultural terms. It can be difficult to identify the best contacts and establish effective distribution chains. In many of the fastest growing markets, especially those in the Asian Pacific area, there are additional cultural and language barriers.

Staff from the Australian Trade Commission (AUSTRADE) have in past years performed a valuable role in assisting firms to overcome such barriers, to identify the right contacts and to set up effective distribution networks.
In the future, however, more can be done to enhance the effectiveness of these operations. For that reason, an independent review of the agency was instituted.

I strongly endorse the Review recommendations and believe that the emphasis on overseas activities, particularly in difficult markets, can be better realised by closer linkage with Australia's diplomatic network.

Accordingly, from 1 September 1991, AUSTRADE will come under the Foreign Affairs and Trade portfolio with Dr Neal Blewett, the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, as the responsible Minister. Dr Blewett and I will be jointly involved in the implementation of the Review recommendations over the next six months.

The Review, Mr Deputy President, has highlighted the role that AUSTRADE can play in difficult markets. These markets, despite language and cultural barriers and different styles of government administration, have enormous potential for Australian firms. North and South East Asia are of special importance. In future, AUSTRADE will concentrate more of its efforts and resources on this region and less on North America and Europe. AUSTRADE's overseas staff will have greater independence under new management arrangements.

In Australia, there will be more focus on the needs of businesses, particularly those with high export potential. Those needs are better served by the relocation to Sydney of AUSTRADE's head office and with the transfer of some central office functions to State offices.
Finance
Australian exporters must have access to competitive financial facilities to be effective, especially in Asia-Pacific markets.

The Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) has been in operation for almost 35 years. It has a unique role in providing export finance, guarantee and insurance services on the Government's behalf.

For the past four years, EFIC has been part of AUSTRADE but the Government now believes it is necessary to re-establish it as an independent statutory corporation with greater visibility, and an extended range of services for exporters. New arrangements will be in place by 1 September and I will continue to have Ministerial responsibility for EFIC.

The new agency will have a reorganised financial structure to ensure an adequate backing for its insurance guarantees and lending operations. The Government will provide $200 million in callable capital to supplement existing reserves of some $160 million and this amount will be reviewed in the next few months. The Government's guarantee will continue to underpin EFIC's activities.

There will also be enhanced services for exporters. The agency will be able to use interest subsidy arrangements in a more aggressive way to create new market opportunities through Australian dollar financing and through lines of credit for Australian banks offshore.

In addition to the extensive use by international competitors of concessional finance, Australian firms undertaking projects overseas find it difficult to meet performance and other bonding requirements demanded by buyers.

The Government will establish a new $50 million facility to cover bonding requirements for firms with a proven record of performance but which are unable to meet the requirements of private bonders. Over a three year period, this facility could provide up to $1 billion in additional export business.
Asia-Pacific Fellowships

Mr Deputy President, to expand our contacts and trade with Asia, we must rapidly increase the number of business people who are fluent in the languages and familiar with the business cultures of that region. While the Government has encouraged the development of Asian language studies in our schools and universities, the benefits to business have not been fully realised.

We have therefore decided to introduce, initially on a three year basis, an Asia-Pacific Fellowships program to assist Australian business people to acquire Asian language skills and foreign business experience.

Mr Deputy President, the range of export oriented measures that I have announced today provides an environment which will support the international activities of Australian firms and encourage and assist firms which are not already exporting to take the first step.
TAXATION
Mr Deputy President, today, the Treasurer is announcing a number of changes to taxation arrangements for business.
As I noted earlier, the taxation system has a far-reaching impact on firms. Our objective must be to have the most competitive taxation environment possible.
A particular concern for Australian business is tax imposts on goods and services which are not borne by competing products in export markets or by competing imports.
Wholesale Sales Tax

With respect to the wholesale sales tax, the current exemptions from wholesale sales tax for business inputs have been broadened to include a wider range of goods used in the range of activities carried out by manufacturers, miners and primary producers.
Exemptions will now apply to goods used in:
* research, development, engineering or technical design of products and production processes;
* production related activities involving the ordering of goods or the controlling or the costing of production processes;
* storage, handling or dispatch of own-produced goods; and
* the training of staff to perform any of these and other eligible activities.
This measure will reduce the cost imposts faced by firms and encourage the adoption of modern manufacturing technologies. It will also reduce administrative and compliance costs.
Depreciation
The current taxation depreciation provisions are complex and inflexible. The following changes will be introduced to assist industry:
* effective life will be defined in the Income Tax Assessment Act to take full account of technological obsolescence;
* the number of depreciation rate classes will be more than halved to seven;
* immediate expensing of items costing up to $300 and items with lives of less than 3 years will be allowed;
* the option will be given to business to pool assets within the same rate class for depreciation recordkeeping purposes; and
* taxpayers will be able to determine the depreciation rate for their equipment in accordance with the definition of effective life and the self assessment principles.

These changes will provide significant scope to reduce accounting burdens by clarifying and simplifying the operation of the depreciation provisions. In addition, the definition of `effective life' should help ensure that lives afforded for tax purposes accurately reflect the actual period an asset can be expected to contribute to the income earning process.
Environmental Impact Studies
Considerable concern has been expressed to Government in relation to the non-deductibility of costs incurred in undertaking environmental impact studies.
In certain circumstances, environmental impact statements are required by law. In other cases these studies are essential to protect the environment.

As part of the review of the tax treatment of environment related expenditure (announced in the 1990-91 Budget) the Government has decided that expenditure on environmental impact studies may be written off over ten years or the life of the project, whichever is the lesser.
SMALL BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT

Small to medium-sized businesses are recognised internationally as key agents of economic growth and structural change. They are an important source of innovation and new employment. Small and medium-sized enterprises operating in the non-traded sector can also provide a very efficient supporting infrastructure for other larger businesses operating in export markets and the traded sector.

To ensure a more strategic and better coordinated approach to the development of small and medium-sized enterprises, existing programs and other development measures addressing impediments to business growth will be strengthened and integrated into a Small and Medium-sized Enterprise Development Program.

The Program will promote the creation and development of efficient and competitive enterprises by removing regulatory and other impediments to enterprise development and providing appropriate assistance at critical stages of business establishment and growth. The Program will also recognise the need to improve efficiency and productivity across the full range of business activity including manufacturing and service businesses operating in both the traded and non-traded sectors.
INDUSTRY-SPECIFIC MEASURES
Sectoral Initiatives

The Government has been prepared to formulate policies in relation to certain industries or sectors that have faced common problems, constraints or opportunities. This approach has generally involved the identification of impediments to improved economic performance and areas where Government action could be effectively used to remove such impediments and build on competitive strengths.

The Government continues to attach a high priority to identifying and eliminating any remaining impediments which may blunt industry's competitive edge and has decided to establish a special sub-committee of Cabinet to continue this task.
Aerospace

The aerocomponent industry, which exports over $150 million of high value added products a year, has demonstrated its ability to break into the world market. Assisted by the Government's civil offsets policy, it is now a world-competitive supplier.

Future development of the aerocomponents industry needs to be based on the formation of risk sharing ventures with the world's major aerospace firms.Civil offsets are no longer an appropriate mechanism to develop these arrangements. Therefore the Government is currently negotiating with these firms to replace existing civil offset arrangements with longer term strategic agreements. Those agreements will provide Australian firms with access to risk sharing work on a free and fair competitive basis.

The Commonwealth and State Governments are also intending to establish a scheme to assist smaller aerocomponent manufacturers in reaching the high levels of quality demanded by the risk sharing partners.

In the area of aircraft maintenance and aviation services, recent initiatives by ASTA provide new opportunities for growth. Following the Government's commitment to privatise part of ASTA, an injection of equity by Hong Kong's HEACO Corporation and a five year service contract from British Airways make it well placed to expand. It is estimated that over 600 new jobs will be created at Avalon in Victoria.
In addition ASTA's Avalon airfield facility has the capacity to become a major centre for aircraft repair and maintenance and will have an important role in the future of the Geelong region.
Information Industries

Since the Information Industries Strategy was launched in 1987, the world information technology market has changed substantially. Hardware has become a commodity and software and services are the most rapidly growing parts of those industries.

These changes in the structure of the information industries offer Australian companies excellent prospects for growth. In particular, Australia has competitive software and service companies and these firms have the potential to grow into major international players.
The original Information Industries Strategy addressed primarily the hardware side of the industry. Today the Government is announcing initiatives to address the software and services side.

The strategy, particularly through the Partnerships for Development Program, has already encouraged transnational companies to increase their long term commercial activities in Australia through commitments to exports and research and development. In 1987, the companies now committed to the Partnerships Program exported $190 million worth of goods and performed research and development worth $63 million. In 1990, their exports had risen to $460 million and research and development to $180 million. The companies are committed to similarly large rises by 1995.
The main extensions to the current Government Strategy are in purchasing of information technology, offsets and the Partnerships for Development Program.
The Government is a major customer of information technology goods and services. As such, it can make demands on its suppliers and influence the development of the local industry.

To facilitate this, the Government will rely more on private sector providers of information technology services. It will establish a panel of these companies to service major public sector information technology projects.
The panel will comprise both local companies and multinational companies that have demonstrated a major commitment to the development of Australian industry.
The Government is also making some evolutionary changes to the Partnerships for Development and offsets programs. We will expand the range of eligible activities under the Partnerships scheme.
Partnership will become mandatory for all multinational firms with annual Government sales of over $40 million.

Firms with annual public sector sales of between $10 million and $40 million will be expected to enter Fixed Term Agreements with the Commonwealth Government. These agreements will combine elements of the Pre-Qualified Offsets and Partnerships programs.
We will be abolishing offsets for firms with annual sales to government of less than $10 million.

A consolidated statement of information technology purchasing policy will also be issued, clearly stating the Government's approach to the acquisition and use of information technology. Measures will be introduced to ensure compliance with these policies by Commonwealth agencies.
The Government is also introducing several other changes to stimulate the local information technology manufacturing sector.

It will remove the tariff on printed circuit boards, and extend the Computer Bounty to include these components so local manufacturers are not disadvantaged. It will also extend the Vendor Qualification Scheme for a further three years and widen its scope to cover software as well as hardware.
Resource-Based Industries
The Government recognises the contribution further development of resource-based industries can make to improving the current account deficit.

In the forest and forest products industries, it is the Government's objective, in cooperation with the States, to phase out the export of woodchips by the year 2000 or soon thereafter. This will be replaced by the manufacture of pulp and paper, and other value-added products, for domestic use and export.
Underpinning this objective is the introduction of a five-stage Forest Conservation and Development Process, each stage dependent upon the satisfactory completion of the previous steps.

With this process in place, companies can proceed with major value adding initiatives with confidence that governments will not act to inhibit their access to forest resources. The process will also ensure that the Government's environment protection policies are well applied.
The Government is prepared to legislate as soon as possible to achieve this outcome.

In addition, an improved process for consideration of other major resource processing projects will be implemented with the establishment of the Commonwealth Major Projects Group. This Group will be the initial point of contact at the Commonwealth level for companies proposing major projects. It will identify and seek to resolve impediments or consider ways in which project development can be facilitated. It will also provide a point of contact on major project proposals with agencies in the States.
CONCLUSION
Over the last eight years, industry has responded well to the challenges of a more competitive Australia. We cannot relax our efforts to improve our efficiency and respond to the global challenge.
In announcing these initiatives today, the Government has sought to promote:
* further integration of Australian industry with the world economy;
* a more competitive domestic business climate;
* better use of the technology and skills of the nation; and
* specific measures to meet the needs of individual industries.

In all of this, the Government is building upon the foundations of its industry policies to date, in improving competitiveness, efficiency, and the intelligent use of technology for Australian industry.
The Government must of course deliver the right environment for the development of a more competitive economy.
But it will take the efforts of all Australians to build the society we want to see at the end of the century.
Industry, trade unions, management and workers all have their part to play.
So do our scientists, our designers, our teachers.

I am confident that Australians will respond to the demands of the 1990s and the initiatives announced today to bring about a new decade of greater competitiveness and expanding production and exports.
These are the directions towards the establishment of a dynamic economy which will enable us to take up the great challenges and great opportunities available in the region in which we live.

The statement read as follows--
STATEMENT BY THE TREASURER, THE HON P. J. KEATING MP
``BUILDING A COMPETITIVE
AUSTRALIA''-TAXATION MEASURES
The package of measures announced today ends forever Australia's sorry association with the tariff as a device for industrial development.
In presiding over such a major transition, the Government through its Industry Minister, Senator Button, has ushered in a new philosophy for Australian industry.

By turning its back on tariffs, Australia will be further propelled in its quest for international trade and efficiency, a search begun with the opening up of the economy in 1983 when we floated the dollar and abolished exchange controls.
As in all nations before it, the pursuit of trade and competition has instilled in Australia a thirst for greater efficiency at home and a larger dominion abroad.
Today's Statement will further serve those ambitions.
Within a couple of years, remaining non-tariff barriers will have been completely removed.

By the end of the decade, tariffs on motor vehicles and on textiles, clothing and footwear will have been wound back to such an extent that effective rates of protection will be less than a third of their present levels.
Across the rest of manufacturing, tariffs will have fallen to a mere 5 per cent by 1996.
Within this decade, Australia will have renounced once and for all the fallacious doctrine that prosperity can be found behind the insular wall of protection.

The wool industry's problems are only the most recent example of how we deceive ourselves if we think we can ignore the imperatives of the international market-place even in a commodity where we are dominant.
Today's Statement completes the program announced in the Economic Statement of May 1988.
It puts an end to the high tariff culture which did so much to diminish Australia's potential in the post war period.
But the decisions announced today do more than complete the transition to an open economy.
They will also make our domestic economy more responsive and supple, giving us a greater capacity to compete with imports and produce goods and services at lower levels of cost.
But our frontline goods and services can only be competitive if the productive sectors which support them are required to be similarly competitive.
The measures announced today by the Prime Minister and Senator Button are designed to improve that prospect, strengthening forever the productive base of the economy.
As part of that process I also announce today significant taxation reform measures which will further reduce tax burdens on Australian industry.
Mr Speaker, since 1983 the Government has undertaken path-breaking reforms of the Australian tax system, increasing its fairness and economic efficiency.
The reforms direct Australia's scarce investment funds to the most economically promising activities.
Reform of the tax system has attacked tax shelters and discouraged speculation, while enhancing the attractiveness of genuine business projects.
The closing of loopholes has funded reductions in tax rates and the establishment of a full dividend imputation system.
These have removed the bias against corporate equity investment and created a world-class financial system for Australian business.
The reformed tax system is an essential foundation for the restructuring and growth of the Australian economy in the 1990s and beyond.
Today's Statement builds on our major reforms with further measures designed to simplify the tax system and improve economic efficiency.
These measures will reduce the tax burden on genuine business activities, particularly those engaged in competition on world markets.
Each measure flows from the basic tax reform direction consistently pursued by the Government and will enhance our competitiveness as a trading nation.
Wholesale Sales Tax
The wholesale sales tax is an important element in Australia's indirect tax system, and has been substantially reformed over recent years.
I announced in the 1990 Budget that it would be comprehensively reviewed in order to simplify its operation and to consider further avenues for removing tax on business inputs.

Given the continuing need for enhanced competitiveness, the Government has given priority to measures to reduce tax on business inputs, as these can operate to disadvantage Australian producers of goods relative to their international competitors.
In last year's Budget, I announced a significant widening of the tax relief provided for computer hardware used in manufacturing-related processes.
The Government has now decided to introduce a major reform to the wholesale sales tax system with a package of changes designed to substantially reduce the tax on business inputs.
A wider definition of production has been adopted so that a wider range of goods used by goods producers can be exempted from sales tax.
Activities for which goods will be exempt include:
* pre-production activities such as research, development, engineering and technical design;
* production-related activities such as ordering raw materials, controlling or costing production processes, monitoring emissions, cleaning premises, lighting and so on;
* post-production activities including storage, handling and dispatch in relation to the goods-producing premises, and rehabilitation of minesites; and
* staff training in relation to such activities.
Exemption will also be extended to goods used in the transportation of products by rail, pipeline or conveyor.
Restrictions on the range of goods which are exempt under the existing exemption provisions will be eased.
When mainly used in eligible activities, lubricants, office furniture and equipment will also be exempt.
Hand tools used in agriculture or fishing will be similarly exempt.
To reduce the costs of handling goods at sea ports and international airports, exemption will be introduced for freight storage and handling facilities at such ports.
Importantly, the exemption provisions will be extended to sub-contractors so that they do not suffer a disadvantage compared with in-house production-related activities.
The comprehensive new provisions to give effect to these exemptions will be drafted in a plain English style and introduced in the Budget sittings.
They will take effect on the date legislation receives Royal Assent.
The new exemptions will reduce tax revenues by $200 million in 1991-92 and $375 million in 1992-93.
Because input taxes are subject to markups as goods pass through the production chain, this measure will have an even greater impact on production costs.
The cascade effect of this taxation relief at the input taxing point will induce a cost benefit estimated at up to $700 million in 1992-93.
Depreciation
Mr Speaker, flowing from its tax simplification agenda, the Government is also introducing major reforms to the processes determining depreciation claims by taxpayers for plant and equipment.

These reforms will have many positive benefits as they provide taxpayers more discretion, greater certainty and enhanced simplicity in dealing with the now complex and often cumbersome task of applying these provisions.
In essence the reforms:
* Legislate to clarify the meaning of effective life.
* Permit taxpayers to self-assess the rate of depreciation of plant and equipment.
* Reduce the number of rate classes for depreciation from eighteen to seven broad-banded rate classes.
* Allow taxpayers to pool items within a rate class for further administrative simplicity.
* Permit items below $300 or with a life of less than 3 years to become deductible immediately, to reduce the large accounting task associated with small items.
Mr Speaker, the methodology of depreciation is already substantially concessionary.

For instance a five year life asset which would be written off at a scheduled 20 per cent a year on a straight line basis can under present arrangements be written off as to 36 per cent in year one under the declining balance system.
This means that most of the value of the asset is depreciated within the first two years of its life.
The 20 per cent loading previously introduced by the Government facilitates such an outcome.
The Government does not believe that assets should be written off faster at an even higher budgetary cost.
Rather, what is needed is a less arbitrary approach and enhanced simplicity in the application of the law.
Amendment to the law to provide greater clarity to the meaning of effective life will give taxpayers a much enhanced capacity to select appropriate write-off periods suited to their circumstances.

The law will specifically refer to factors to be considered in determining effective life, including predictable obsolescence, circumstances of use and the restriction of plant life to the life of a project in which it is used.

Taxpayers will continue to be able to appeal a decision by the Commissioner on the effective life of an asset, in the first instance with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and, if required, the Federal Court.
However, such appeals will now be argued with the assistance of the new definitional criteria and the process of appeal will commence earlier than under present arrangements.
These new processes should see depreciation claims equilibrate quickly with the actual effective lives of assets.

Permitting taxpayers to self-assess the rate of depreciation for allowable plant and equipment gives them the freedom to use rates which they believe are more in keeping with the circumstances of the use of the asset.
The Commissioner of Taxation will however continue to provide guidance on rates of depreciation through private and public rulings.
Taxpayers exercising the option to self-assess depreciation rates will be required to annotate their taxation return to that effect.

The Commissioner will be able to consider the taxpayer's claim. This reform will mean that for items of plant and equipment, both large and small, taxpayers will be able not only to truncate any process of review or ruling by the Taxation Office but may have the more immediate advantage of improved after tax incomes from a more appropriate deduction in the years in question.

To ensure that implementation issues are addressed adequately, the detail of the self-assessment system for depreciation will be determined after full consultation between the Taxation Office and interested bodies prior to implementation.
The reduction in the number of rate classes from eighteen to seven will also greatly simplify the accounting task for much of Australian business.
Broad-banding will make depreciation claims for the myriad of depreciable items at many and varied rates dramatically more simple.
Pooling of assets within a rate class will amplify the simplicity.

The new depreciation arrangements, other than broad-banding and pooling, will take effect for items acquired and first used, or installed ready for use, for income producing purposes on or after 1 July 1991.

Broad-banding and pooling will be available from the 1991-92 income year in respect of all items, including those acquired before 1 July 1991, while used for income producing purposes, unless the items remain eligible for special depreciation rates.
The measures are expected to reduce tax revenues by $100 million in 1992-93, but to have a declining cost in later years.

Mr Speaker, these reforms will not only materially and beneficially affect the after tax position of a business, they will also provide flexibility and relief from the onerous and costly task of preparing depreciation claims.
Environmental Impact Studies
I announced in the 1990 Budget a review of the tax treatment of expenditures relating to the environment.
That review is continuing, but the Government has decided to announce an initial outcome today.

For expenditures incurred after today on environmental impact studies, tax deductions will be allowed over a period of the lesser of ten years or the life of the associated project. The deduction will remove a bias in the tax system against projects requiring such studies and against appropriate environmental assessment processes.
The cost of this measure will be low initially, but steadily build up to an estimated $45 million per year after ten years.
Other Tax Measures
Some other tax measures form part of the initiatives announced today by the Government.
The deduction for eligible research and development expenditures is to be extended indefinitely, with the rate of deduction of 125 per cent to continue after 1995.
This extension will maintain strong fiscal assistance to this activity and enable companies to develop their research and development plans on a longterm basis.
As part of the arrangements announced for the motor vehicle industry, the wholesale sales tax on luxury vehicles is to be reduced to 30 per cent.
This is expected to reduce tax revenues by about $15 million in the current financial year, and $45 million in 1991-92.
Fiscal Impact
Let me now discuss the fiscal impact of the measures announced today.
The Government's approach to budget strategy has been, and remains, keyed to the medium-term requirements of policy.
This has involved, first, the need to achieve a Budget surplus, contributing to national savings and easing pressure on the current account.
At the same time personal income tax relief negotiated under the Accord has bought further progress in enhancing our international competitiveness, and in successfully tackling inflation.
Second, budget formulation has involved sustained efforts to improve the effectiveness of outlays programs, the efficiency and equity of the tax system and the productivity of government enterprises.
Mr Speaker, the measures announced today are fully consistent with the medium-term objectives of fiscal policy.

In aggregate, the measures will add only $123 million to outlays in 1991-92. The tax and tariff reforms will cost the revenue an estimated $324 million in 1991-92, although this will increase in the medium-term reflecting the full-year cost of the new exemptions under the wholesale sales tax and the phased reductions in tariff duties.
These costs to revenue, however, are in the higher service of significantly improving the efficiency of resource allocation in the private sector.
Those improvements will serve to strengthen the nation's income growth, with beneficial medium-term fiscal effects.
The package announced today deals with our underlying structural problems without losing sight of current cyclical difficulties.
The present slowdown in economic activity will contribute to a substantial reduction in the surplus this year compared with the record $8 billion outcome for 1989-90.
This budgetary response, involving slower revenue growth and increased outlays on unemployment benefits, will serve to cushion the effects of the recession.

With similar intent, measures announced to enhance labour market and training programs, at a cost of $45 million in 1991-92, will protect the skills base of the labour force from the effects of the recession and develop that base further.

In the medium-term our objective will be to maintain the structural integrity of the Budget so that, as the level of activity recovers, the Budget will further contribute significantly to national savings.
In order to meet this requirement the Government will, as usual, carefully scrutinise its spending programs in formulating the Budget for 1991-92.
The discretionary outlays measures in this Statement are modest but the Government intends to ameliorate those impacts with measures in the forthcoming Budget round.
Such an approach will ensure that the public sector comes out of the present slowdown in much better shape than after any previous post-war recession.
Conclusion
Mr Speaker, sustained consistency in rational structural reform has been a hallmark of this Government.
Today we have yet again demonstrated our commitment to that standard, this time in circumstances of economic adversity.
With these measures we complete our transition to an open economy. By promoting a more competitive cost structure we also underpin our transition to a lower inflation path in the 1990s.
The process of structural change in this country has been long and arduous.
But we have made great strides.
Our export sector is now a much larger part of our economy than when we came to office.

This package will continue that process and will ensure that as the economy comes out of recession we will have in place the proper ingredients for a firmly based expansion of our economy throughout the 1990s.
