TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Hawke Government came to office in 1983 with a clear call for policies of reconciliation and renewal. Australians had grown tired of the divisiveness of the past and anxious for a new era of cooperation so that we could overcome the problems facing us. We needed to rejuvenate the economy and make it more productive. And we needed to pull together so that we could do so. The new Government therefore sought the help of all the interests involved in providing ideas and helping to frame the industry, education and other policies which go to make a reform strategy.

SPEECH.PARA: Nowhere were reconciliation and renewal more necessary than in industrial relations where the climate had become increasingly confrontationist in the early 1970s and early 1980s. This climate had to change if the strategy of economic renewal were to be effectively pursued. The industrial relations role in this strategy involved drawing all parties together so that a reform environment could be created in which a productivity culture could be nurtured and made to flourish.
All the elements of the Government's industrial relations policies since it was elected have been part of this carefully planned and phased reform program.

The Accord has brought about union cooperation in structural change and wage restraint. The Government has actively supported a tripartite consultation process as a central factor in remoulding established institutions to remove impediments to flexibility in the system, particularly at the enterprise level. Rationalisation of the union structure, after many unsuccessful years, is now achieving results which are significant for industry flexibility. The Government has decided to allocate $2 million towards helping unions through the rationalisation process with legal and other costs. This will be in addition to the $2 million it has already invested in the process.

The reform environment encouraged by these and other developments is already transforming the way work is performed and rewarded in many areas of industry. From the two-tier days to the current phase of the Structural Efficiency Principle, wage fixing has been linked to changes designed to increase productivity and efficiency. It has been used to force the pace of award restructuring. This is a massive exercise in which job classifications and work organisation which have existed for decades-and even for generations--have been streamlined to bring about reforms to make work at the plant level more flexible and more productive. The achievement should not be underestimated. In the metals sector, for instance, more than 350 narrow, separate job classifications have been cut to 14. In Germany, a similar sized reform took more than 10 years; here it has taken less than three.

But, as massive as all these changes have been, the reform program still has to negotiate a significant cross-over point. With the momentum of restructuring continuing, we must manage the decentralisation of wage fixing to the enterprise and bring about a great change in the culture of the workplace.

The Government has invested considerable financial and other resources in encouraging reform at the workplace level. It has put more than $25 million into its Workplace Reform Program which assists training, education, planning and other reform activities and helps fund a national network of workplace resource centres. The Prime Minister has announced today that, in its industry strategy, the Government will invest a further $20 million in this program.

It has also decided to press the pace of workplace reform via demonstration projects which will illustrate the productivity gains made possible by the work practices used overseas and by our more enlightened companies. The Government will allocate $25 million over the next two years to this program, the Australian Best Practice Demonstration Program (ABPDP).

The program will be administered by me, in association with the Australian Manufacturing Council (AMC). It has been developed following extensive consultations with peak employer and union organisations and enterprises. The scheme will use a competitive bidding process in which firms bid for inclusion. There is advantage in this process in that, for each successful candidate, there will be a significant number of others who have brought about productivity-enhancing change. These spin-offs will be available throughout the life of the scheme as the competitive bidding process is completed.

The Government is confident that the process will produce a catalytic effect, stimulating much more widespread change than that displayed by those companies selected. Each demonstration project will be a model for what can be achieved and a hands-on resource on how to achieve the kind of productivity gains made by reformist companies. By this program, the Government wants to galvanise senior management into action, in cooperation with their work force. Only those enterprises which can demonstrate that they are prepared to undertake a comprehensive reform and restructuring program within a reasonable timeframe will be eligible to take part.

The successful companies in the competitive bidding process will be selected on the advice of a panel of employer and union representatives. The panel will be chaired by Mr John Prescott, Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer-designate of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Chairperson of the Australian Manufacturing Council. Members of the panel will themselves be chosen on the strength of their demonstrated practical knowledge of successful business, a track record in implementing change, and a commitment to the new workplace culture.
The difficulty in creating such a culture leads me to make two final points.

It can no longer be accepted that workers should leave their brains at the factory gate and pick them up again on their way home. The truly productive company uses its employees' brains as well as their hands. This calls for much wider use of consultation and participation than is ev ident throughout industry today.

My second final point is that, though the Government has invested enormous resources in the reform effort over the past eight years, it cannot do the whole job itself. Peak employer organisations and unions have cooperated significantly in the effort. Their cooperation should be reflected more widely and more actively at the workplace and plant level.

The Government-through the statement today of the Prime Minister-has set out a clear long term vision of a productive, clever Australia. The reforming role to be played in this by the industrial relations system will be significant. This statement is to explain how the system has facilitated reform so far and how it will play its part in the industry strategy outlined today.
I commend it to honourable senators. I table this statement and move:
That the Senate take note of the statements and documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my remarks to the motion to take note of all of the ministerial statements and associated documents, I will concentrate on the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) entitled Building a Competitive Australia. As the Prime Minister pointed out, we have awaited this particular statement for some time. In this statement the Government has finally accepted some responsibility for intervention in the economy. In fact, the Prime Minister says:

SPEECH.PARA: But I do not walk away from my Government's ultimate responsibility to manage the national economy.

For the Australian Democrats that is a welcome move. However, to our mind, this statement represents tentative steps in that direction. In my remarks I will indicate those areas which we welcome and those where we have concerns, and my colleagues and I will outline other measures which we believe ought to have been included in the Prime Minister's statement and in the supporting statements of other relevant Ministers.

The Prime Minister, having stated that he accepts the Government's responsibility to manage the national economy, goes on, not too far into his statement, to make this point, when talking about questions of trade:
However much our competitors might bend or break the principles of fair trade, our own self-interest is served by a steadfast refusal to return to the days of protectionism.

What the Prime Minister is putting forward there is, to our mind, a black or white scenario and one which does not allow for any different approach; that is, either a full-blown protectionism-which nobody in this place would stand up and support-or the sort of flat earth theory which this Government is apparently still promoting in terms of overseas trade.

Fair trade is in fact what we should be standing up for. There will be many in our community today, especially in the rural community, who will be very concerned by that statement of the Prime Minister, particularly because it is followed by at least a page extolling the virtues of the work that the Australian Government is doing at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade but clearly setting out the determination of this Government not to be flexible enough or imaginative enough to deal with the problems of our own industries in the context of an international trading regime which is far from fair at this stage. That is not to say that Australia should not be negotiating strongly towards fair and open trade around the world. It does not exist and there are other considerations which must be met by a responsible government; and to be met, degrees of intervention will be necessary which we do not find in either the Prime Minister's or the other supporting statements.

At the point at which the Prime Minister is discussing questions of overseas trade, he refers to new protectionists. I want to make it quite clear at this point that the Australian Democrats do not come into any category thus named. We simply say that it is not enough to take the simplistic view to cut tariffs on a rigid timetable in this way. There is a need for a strategy to increase our industrial capacity and our competitiveness, but it will require more intervention and more imagination than the Government is prepared to allow. My colleague Senator Spindler will detail, in his contribution in the debate as it goes on, our specific measures and ideas in that respect.

We must be targeting what we are doing. We must develop sustainable industries, obviously, and our concern here is in the global context. We believe that we need to acknowledge that there is no level playing field and that sustainability must be a major priority. To that end, we will be discussing what we would call an exploitation index which recognises that it is environmental and human exploitation that is so often at the base of the unequal surface of the playing field on which we operate in international trade.

The Prime Minister quite early in his statement acknowledges the fact that we can expect increased unemployment. There is very little else he could do, of course, in the current environment. We have got over three-quarters of a million people currently unemployed. A million is clearly a figure which regrettably we look like reaching. In this context, the statement later on talks about a range of training schemes. This, of course, is welcome. The intention is to spend $74m over two years for work experience for people who are unemployed for over six months; $50m over 15 months to provide pre-vocational training places, for which I hope State cooperation will be forthcoming, because that is a very important part of this Federal Government's program; and $6m over three years to strengthen management skills. That totals $130m to address that obvious unemployment problem, which is acknowledged by the Prime Minister.

However, the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) submission which was put to the Prime Minister recently with regard to this major economic statement, in the context of the present high levels of unemployment-and bearing in mind that the figures I have quoted from the Prime Minister's statement are stretched out over up to a three-year period-assesses that in employment and training we would need $130m for work experience and $90m for training programs, plus an additional 600 staff for Commonwealth Employment Service officers, just to meet the needs which are currently there. That does not take account of any increased unemployment which will obviously be occurring as we see the cutbacks in tariffs which are ahead of us. That is a total of what ACOSS terms at least $290m in the employment and training budget for the next financial year. So we do not take a great deal of encouragement from the training scheme's $130m over up to three years, as outlined in this statement. That remains a major area of deficiency both in this statement and in the Government's policies as they stand.

ACOSS put to the Prime Minister the need for a bold industry policy. As I say, Democrat initiatives will be outlined by my colleagues but I just put on record the suggestions that came from ACOSS: that we definitely need, for instance, carefully targeted grants and Government participation in pool risk arrangements for new export ventures; national guidelines to increase the proportion of Australian goods and services in government procurement-and, of course, the statement has gone some distance in that direction; and increased resources for Austrade and other trade assistance services, especially for South East Asian markets. There is a mood and an understanding in the community that there is a need for increased government intervention to get this economy moving. It is that mood, obviously, which has been picked up, at least in part, by the Government in making this statement today.

While we are talking about the present stresses in the economy and particularly at the human level, we must of course look at the rural scene. The Prime Minister's statement tells us that as tariff reductions occur general agricultural assistance will be reduced in line with the pace of that tariff reform in manufacturing. That is fair enough as a statement. However, while there are still some agricultural areas where there is a high degree of assistance-and I refer specifically to the tobacco industry, where the effective rate of assistance, according to the Industry Commission's most recent annual report, has risen from 24 to 111 since 1986 up to the year 1988-89, something that we should all be questioning-we must look at other commodity areas.

In the potato industry we have a negative rate of effective assistance of minus 3.1. The tomato industry, again, has a negative rate of assistance, minus 1.2. As for some of the extensive cropping areas, in 1988-89 the level of assistance in wheat, one of our major commodity crops and one most stressed at this time, the rate of assistance is 1.4 only; in barley, 0.6; in sorghum, a growing industry, 0; and oilseeds generally, 3.4. As far as many of our rural commodity areas are concerned, the intention to reduce is not going to be a major exercise in terms of the overall benefit to the economy or to government revenue or loss of revenue, but it certainly will be in those stressed rural industries, or has the potential to put enormous further stress on those industries. We suggest that that is something, if we are going to look at targeting and being specific on an industry by industry basis, which should not be done across the board.

The Prime Minister also points out that we can expect the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr John Kerin, to announce in April a rural adjustment package to acknowledge the difficulties that will be experienced by rural people and are being experienced. We must at this stage call for that package to move away from the present situation where rural adjustment is largely there, as it has been historically, to help people off the land in adjustment industry by industry. What is needed in the rural sector at this time in particular is rural adjustment which will help people stay on the land. In this enormously stressed period primary producers of many kinds and in horticultural industries in particular, as well as the major commodities, are not suffering because they are inefficient but because of international factors very much beyond their control, most of them-or many of the significant ones-beyond the control of this Government, including the political changes in the Eastern bloc, the situation in the Middle East and so on.

Surely we do not want to force those people off the land and even spend money to get them off it and in the process decimate industries which we need for economic reasons and, of course, for social reasons, as our rural communities run the risk of total disintegration. These are difficult times and they will get more difficult, particularly for people in the rural industries. Any major statement of this kind which does not acknowledge that would be deficient, so we look forward to Mr Kerin's statement with regard to rural adjustment. We welcome the commitment to strong anti-dumping measures. We supported the establishment of the committee which is now looking at that issue, but in that process the Government must acknowledge those hidden supports, hidden subsidies, that exist in that very unlevel playing field in which the rural sector particularly is operating.

I now move to the area of micro- economic reform, an area in which I think we had all expected a good deal of extension of information on what is intended and so on by the Government. This section of the Prime Minister's statement gives the clearest indication that this so-called milestone statement is largely just a media beat-up. There is nothing new in this section. What is announced is already happening. We notice that Senator Collins is still the Minister in his area-a very vital area, an area in which we welcome the reforms and developments which have taken place. We congratulate the Government on those reforms and on not being forced, as it might have been by the Opposition, to take a pace which was beyond any rational approach, particularly in the area of the waterfront. But there is nothing new in this statement. The Government appears to be running out of puff on this one. Basically we have huff and puff when it comes to micro-economic reform.

There is not a word about rail. We have heard in the past about the development of a national rail strategy. Nothing could be more essential to the development of a sustainable future economy in this country. Surely if this statement is such a landmark, as it was said to be, we should have had some direction pointed out here, some initiatives begun, if this Government was interested in a genuinely sustainable economic future for this country. The trucks are out there ripping up the country roads and contributing to our atmospheric pollution. This particularly efficient, in many ways, form of transport has not been given anything of a push along by virtue of this statement.

Having said that the Democrats welcome much of what is happening in micro-economic reform, I would have to exclude from that the disaster of reform in the telecommunications area. The introduction of competition on what is a blind ideological process is at a great cost to the community, a cost to service, and a cost to our local industry. After all, a large part of what we have been given today from the Government is supposed to be about the development of industry in this country, particularly the export industry, yet all of the evidence shows that the track down which the Government is going in telecommunications is a disastrous one.

The US turned a US$1 billion balance-of-trade surplus in 1978-
in telecommunications equipment-

—Even if it is rubbish?
—Presumably Senator Alston has not read the US Department of Commerce's US Telecommunications in a Global Economy, which found basically:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . whenever a country was a net exporter of equipment, it had in place policies for preferential local procurement.
That is regulation. The article in the Australian Financial Review continues:

In France, for example, equipment procurement is not open to international competition. Foreign companies wanting to sell in the French market must agree not to worsen the country's trade balance-any imports have to be balanced by exports.
Canada has similar local preference policies . . .
Japan has supposedly liberalised access to markets, but in reality NTT has kept its close relationship with its preferred suppliers, Hitachi, NEC, Oki and Fujitsu.
Australia has built an equipment industry with a $3 billion turnover based on Telecom's and OTC's procurement policies. With the coming of a second carrier, this policy is in the melting pot.

There is nothing in the Prime Minister's statement to commit the OTC-Telecom combined carrier or a new carrier to that sort of procurement policy. All we can say is that this statement is therefore confirmation of the worst fears that this disastrous telecommunications policy will also be a disaster for a major sector which has massive export potential, particularly in our region, about which a great deal of lip-service is paid in this statement. That is an area of massive deficiency.

Still in the communications area, an Aussat driven deal is being put forward to introduce pay television when two of our commercial operators are in receivership. This push is totally irrational. There is no sense of economic or social responsibility in that sort of approach. Yet, that is the direction in which the Government is going. Although there is nothing new in this statement, there are moves that are to be welcomed in some aspects of micro-economic reform. In other areas, the Government is clearly rushing down a disastrous path.

In his statement, the Prime Minister talked a little more about structural change in the economy. He referred to the Trade Practices Act as the principal legislative weapon to ensure that consumers get the best deal from competition. If it is a sword, I would say that it is hardly out of its sheath and it is about as blunt as the Government's rhetoric. This is an area where the Democrats want to see more action; it is an area where we will be promoting more action, as we have in the past. We are reliant on a subcommittee of the Cabinet structural adjustment committee and the State Premiers in terms of the process of new federalism. So how can we really have confidence in this process?

The Prime Minister and, in more detail, Senator Button make the point that the Government has rejected product liability. This matter has been fobbed off again to a later date and, in our view, we are left with an inferior proposition. It is interesting that this announcement in Senator Button's statement comes immediately after his discussion about the need to promote quality in our industry. The Democrats believe that that is a major negative in this statement.

The Prime Minister says a good deal about inflation and the success in that area. The Government has brought about a small reduction in inflation through its induced recession which we are suffering at the moment at human cost and long term damage to many key industries. The Government could have achieved this reduction, and probably more, had it reduced asset price inflation through financial regulation. Financial deregulation has been a disaster. We are clawing back in inflation terms only part of what has been caused by this Government's policy. In speaking about the accord and wage restraint, Senator Cook did not mention that there has been no control of management salaries under that system. Blow-outs in that area need to be dealt with. That is a matter which the Government cannot be congratulated on at all.

In his statement to the Parliament, the Prime Minister made the point that this Government has done more than any other to reform the taxation system so that, as far as possible, tax considerations do not distort investment decisions. The Democrats agree that some important tax reform measures have been implemented during this Government's term of office-fringe benefits, capital gains tax and so on. Those measures have been supported by us. We agree that the tax system should be used to effect structural change through investment decisions so that they fit in with the direction in which we want to go. We believe that it should be an instrument by which the Government promotes sustainable development.

Of course, we support the tax initiatives that are in the statement-the widening of exemptions from sales tax for business inputs and the overhaul of depreciation provisions to bring them into line with business realities. In particular, these measures come into the category of positive tax reforms by this Government, which my colleague Senator Spindler has been pushing very strongly for since he has been in this place. But there is nothing in the statement about the use of the tax system to encourage, for instance, pollution control by effecting a polluter-pays policy.

The Democrats put the Government under enormous pressure, which finally resulted in the removal of sales tax from recycled paper. A new developing industry has now been given a boost by that process. Senator Spindler has attempted a similar approach in respect of recycled plastic. Again, this potential industry has enormous social and environmental benefits. As the Government has not stated that it will do that or given us any encouragement, we shall continue to apply pressure as we did on the issue of sales tax on recycled paper. These are just a couple of examples of the growth industries of the coming decades. There are many others, which I am sure my colleague Senator Coulter will mention, which could and should be developed, encouraged, assisted and supported through the tax system.

A good deal was said in the statement today about the motor car industry but we did not hear a word about developing fuel efficient cars, about alternative powered cars. Again, I know that Senator Coulter will refer in detail to the ideas of the Democrats in that area, which are not encompassed in the Prime Minister's statement.

The statement also referred to the disaster of the removal of the sales tax on luxury cars. This tax ought to be extended to other luxury imports. Our problem is one of too many imports. This is the sort of tax that, if the Prime Minister really means what he says about the use of the tax system, the Government should not be removing but extending.

I will not spend very much more time talking about the resource security approach which has been taken and which was already in the public arena before this statement was made. My colleague Senator Coulter will deal with that. But I want to say that this approach would not even be necessary if we genuinely had a government which understood the reality of sustainable development which equals genuine resource security; not a short term exercise which protects an already heavily subsidised industry, which the proposal for the forest industry is, but genuine long term security for all members of the community and for future generations.

A good deal was said about cooperation with our regional neighbours. That is essential and the concept is welcomed. But care will need to be taken in our foreign policy and defence postures if this is to bear fruit. We must not strut the Pacific stage like big brother. We must not only be looking at industry and economic policies. We must look at other policy areas if we are genuinely to forge good relations in our region which will have an economic benefit to us all.

As I have said, the Prime Minister's statement represents something of a breakthrough in that the total costs of $33m in the first year, $446m in the second year and $854m in the third year are basically increases in industry assistance. Of course, we welcome that as an acknowledgment, at least in part, that government has a responsibility to intervene in the economy in the interests of the kind of society in which Australians deserve to live. However, the direction that the Government intends to take us is, no doubt because of the tentative nature of this, unclear. Sustainability, either social or environmental, is not an issue in this statement.

We welcome the direction and some of the specific moves, many of which I have already mentioned. We note the Opposition's non-response today. It, of course, does not provide an alternative. The Democrats have substantial alternatives and they will be detailed by my colleagues as the debate proceeds.
