DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Alston proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's cynical disregard of the tragic human consequences of the recession, `We had to have'.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At long last we now have the opportunity to consider the other side of the coin because what we have had so far today, and indeed what we have had for most of the past eight years, has been failed attempt after failed attempt to get the economy right. Unless the Government gets the economy right, it is really not in a position to do anything about the social consequences that follow. It has to be said time and time again that the best antidote to poverty is employment. Yet, what we now find is that, after all the anguish and toil and the gymnastics from the great showman, from the world's greatest Treasurer through to the world's greatest recession engineer, it has all been for nought. What we now have is levels of unemployment as high and dole queues as long as they were in the early 1980s.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has always prided itself on its commitment to social justice as though it had a monopoly on compassion and concern. The Australian Democrats, of course, are also past masters of this. But there is not much point in having that concern unless one has practical policies to do something about it. The Democrats' idea of doing something about it is to throw money at it-large dollops of money which they do not have and which they do not have the responsibility of raising-which, of course, just compounds the problem. The solution is, as this Government knows in its heart of hearts, to restructure the economy-to bite the bullet, to create more jobs and to provide the opportunities that people really want. People do not want to be put on welfare. By and large, people do not want to get benefits, allowances and handouts. They ought to be a last resort. They should certainly not be a first resort. People should not really be put in that position.

The approach of the Government ought to be to provide as many opportunities as possible for people to help themselves. If it had done that, by having a competitive economy, a growing economy that leads to increased capital investment and more job opportunities, we would not have the magnitude of welfare problems that we have in this country at the moment. That is the great tragedy-not just the pathetic non-event that has been launched today by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I think we all noted who launched it in this place. It clearly was not the person who ought to have been representing the Prime Minister. There is a very good reason for that. That person could not bring himself to address the hypocrisy contained in the statement put down on behalf of the Prime Minister. There is just one small example that I found particularly instructive that is contained in the following passage, where Senator Button said:
Other countries have been assiduous in their pursuit of reforms . . . That is why we in Australia have to do more. We have to change faster.
Yet, when we turn to the Prime Minister's statement, he said:

Those who for more than a generation in office entrenched the inadequacies of the past and themselves effected no change whatsoever, now with an hypocrisy that is truly breathtaking, clamour for even greater change.

So on the one hand we have Senator Button saying that we have to change faster and on the other hand we have the Prime Minister saying that it is truly breathtaking hypocrisy to clamour for greater change. That characterises the extraordinary contradiction between the rhetoric of this Government in professing to have achieved breathtaking micro-economic reform and the reality that it has managed to achieve virtually nothing in that area. It was the catchcry of the third term of government; it was the catchcry of the fourth term of government; it is now the catchcry of what is laughingly called `building a competitive Australia' when we do not even have a solid foundation let alone an edifice about which we ought to crow.

That is the tragedy of it. Whilst the Government knows that it ought to be about structural change and micro-economic reform, it really has not been prepared to even embark upon that process. Because the Government is not interested in real reform on the waterfront, because it is not interested in anything other than mickey mouse telecommunications restructuring, because it is not prepared to embrace flexible labour market policies and because it is too afraid of what the union movement might say, we have an ossified economy. We have a structure that is making us fall further and further behind our competitors, not only in this region but elsewhere.

The end result of that policy paralysis is that we have social consequences that are getting greater and greater by the passing day. That is the point of our matter of public importance and the issue that I am sure exercises the minds and hearts of all Australians. No-one wants to see people getting in the dole queues; no-one wants to see them going to voluntary agencies and asking for handouts; no-one wants to see them ringing rural counsellors in the bush because they are out of work, their income has gone down dramatically and there is no hope in sight; no-one wants to see pensioners having to rely on the advice of financial investment service counsellors; no-one wants to see people going to government departments looking for mickey mouse training schemes and all sorts of methods of keeping people out of the labour force. They want to be in employment. They want to be doing something useful and constructive. They want to have a bit of self-worth and self-esteem. They want to contribute to the economy-not simply take government handouts.

That is why it has all come unstuck for this Government. What we will see, and what we will develop over the next few days, is an analysis of the Government's latest effort at tackling this problem- almost everything but structural change. Hundreds of millions of dollars are being thrown into make-work projects.

One thing that struck me as very puzzling, and it came up today in Question Time, is that less than six months ago Senator Richardson was saying, `I think it would be very difficult for us to try to upgrade training for the unemployed. I am not certain that there is room in the system for more expansion, even if you could find the money'. Well, the Government found the money; it simply decided that Budget surpluses did not matter any more-that $8.1 billion ought to be translated into a likely deficit. It thinks that one can buy one's way out of a recession. But one cannot, and we know that. The Government can create as many schemes as it likes for keeping people out of the work force and massaging the numbers, but at the end of the day it will simply compound the problem.

That is what we are seeing at the moment, by way of response to Mr Keating's masterful engineering exercise. There is simply no hope in sight as a result of the statements that have been made today. Therefore, we have to ask ourselves why it is that, with a social security budget in excess of $23 billion, that money cannot be used more productively. Why do we have to have $73m, or 14 per cent of the payroll of the Department of Social Security, being spent on training employees of that Department, when in most instances those regional office people last in the job for little more than 12 months?

Most of this money is going on people who have no use for it because they will be quitting the system. Ultimately about half of the total work force of 16,500 are the beneficiaries of these training schemes, travel allowances and all sorts of lurks and perks and a sum of money approaching $100m in the present year could have been spent on the alleviation of their poverty. It is money that did not have to go to the bureaucrats but it has.

One of the most offensive items-and I think that my colleague Senator Chapman will give us a practical example of this tomorrow-is the $11.5m that is being spent by the Department of Social Security on promotional projects. I could not believe that this Department is actually printing balloons, sunshades, fridge magnets, wall charts and a whole range of things that are utterly useless when it comes to its sole professed purpose in life, which is income transfer payments.

I used to get stuck into Telecom for promoting itself when it was a monopoly and wasting around $30m a year on telling everyone what a great job it was doing when we all knew that it was doing quite the opposite. However, I find it morally offensive that, when we are prepared to have a Department of Social Security committed to the alleviation of poverty, or hopefully to its amelioration at least, it spends money on these sorts of self-congratulatory exercises. That is flaunting the bureaucrats' wealth in the face of those who are desperately in need of assistance, and they are everywhere around us.

One does not have to go to the local Commonwealth Employment Service office or Department of Social Security office to see people queued up on the footpaths, and quite often being kept waiting deliberately because that is a way of discouraging people. One has only to go to the voluntary agencies to see the massive increase in demand that has occurred in recent weeks and months.

The Brotherhood of St Laurence has reported that in January its material aid service in Frankston, Victoria, assisted 394 people but was unable to assist another 154 people because of insufficient stocks of clothing and furniture. The Anglican Community Service at Elizabeth in South Australia reported that in January 197 people were given assistance, but another 540 had to be turned away. The Salvation Army's welfare centre in Adelaide gave away more than $23,000 in food and vouchers in January and $17,000 in February to 1,624 people-more than double the amount for the same period last year.

Sydney City Mission reports that it is having to turn away 20 people a day at its Campbelltown centre, and the story is similar at other centres in Green Valley, Mount Druitt and Wollongong. The mission's 26 senior staff have agreed to take a voluntary pay cut of 10 per cent over the next four months to allow for more funds with which to aid its clients. The mission says that 20 per cent to 30 per cent of families coming in for financial counselling are in trouble because of retrenchment or reduced income owing to the recession.

In the face of all that we have had on two occasions-one in response to a question by Senator Lees-Senator Richardson saying quite blithely `No, we are not thinking of giving any more money to voluntary agencies because they have not asked for it. Indeed, if they want to come to talk to me about it, I will be very interested to hear from them, but I cannot vouch for my colleagues. Perhaps they have approached others'. If he did not know, he ought to have known.

The fact is that the Australian Council of Social Service approached Mr Staples over a month ago asking for a grant of $7.5m to be given to the voluntary agencies to assist them in immediate and practical income and poverty relief. The answer from the Minister's office, as reported in today's newspapers, was that a decision was still pending and was likely to be made sooner rather than later. What an appalling and cynical response. If ever one wants to see an indifferent government, one has only to look at that type of reaction.

It is quite clear that the Government does not want to provide assistance through voluntary agencies because it will lose control of the process. Never mind that they are the people at the coalface who understand the level of need and are the people best placed to provide assistance. Never mind that the voluntary agencies are very well regarded by ordinary Australians and that people are much more prepared to consult with non-government organisations than they are to confide in bureaucrats. Despite the propaganda, we know that that is clearly the fact with the family income supplement scheme where pensioners are literally terrified that any information which they provide will be taken down in evidence and used against them. This Government is acting in this way for purely ideological reasons. There are those in its ranks who believe that volunteers and voluntary organisations are not quite the right way to go because somehow they exploit people and should be paying their employees twice as much as they are getting, so bureaucracy is better.

That sort of approach in government clearly is alive and well to the extent that the real need as measured by those on the ground, the voluntary agencies, is being totally disregarded by this Government. That is what we mean when we talk of a cynical disregard for the tragic human consequences of this deliberate recession. It is not something that has just come about. We know that from the Treasurer's own mouth. Despite the fact that he has had eight years to get it right, all that we are being offered today by way of a statement is promises of more to come. I understand that the Government intends to establish yet another subcommittee of Cabinet to look at structural change. It is pathetic to think that somehow one can buy off the Australian people by promising to set up even more committees and structures and not bite the real bullet.

In the Weekend Australian, Alan Wood pointed to two obvious and easy ways of measuring progress on micro-economic reform. One was trans-Tasman trade, if one were prepared to free that up, and the second was the third runway at Sydney airport. That is what business has put to this Government as the benchmarks. These things are easily achievable, and there have been endless reports showing what needs to be done. Therefore, there is no logical or economic reason why they cannot be accomplished immediately. The only objections are political. That is why they have not surfaced. That is why we have not heard a word about them. That is why there will be no progress in terms of economic recovery. Of course, eventually one day we will come out of a recession, because no recession lasts indefinitely any more than do boom periods.

TALK.START.PARA: —This one will last a while.

—I do not doubt what Senator Panizza says is right, that all this nonsense about the end of this year should not be taken at face value. What is the end result of all that policy paralysis and economic ineptitude?
—You can't believe a word this Government says.

—Well, of course, we cannot and we do not, but somehow the Government expects the public to swallow this latest dose. It has a placebo effect, but I do not know who will want to ingest any more of that medicine. It is the consequence in social terms that we are concerned about today. One does not have to look at the statistics, which show: the number of people who have been out of work for more than 12 months rose by more than 30 per cent over the last 12 months to January; the unemployment rate in January rose by another 26,000, in other words, about 1,000 a day; the number of people unemployed in Victoria has risen by over 10 per cent since April 1983, just after this Government came to power, and the same figure generally applies in other States; and Australians have been joining the dole queues at a rate which now sees over half a million people receiving unemployment benefits, many more than the 455,000 predicted in the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: They are the figures that one cannot encapsulate in human terms in the course of a debate, but anyone who walks the streets, particularly the western suburbs of the major cities, will be made acutely aware of the position. Certainly those who come from rural areas will have been made acutely aware, by means of phone calls and meetings that people attend, of the anguish that is alive in the bush at the moment over the wool and wheat debacles. This is compounded by the fact that there are literally no job opportunities, no ways of people rescuing themselves from government-induced predicaments.

Yet all of this money is being squandered in all sorts of other ways. For example, the $45,000 that was paid to Cleo to assist the Australian Council of Trade Unions to advertise itself to women was an obscenity. But we have not heard a word of apology from this Government. Rather, we have heard almost a boast that this is the sort of thing that ought to be tried in other places.

I do not suppose that the Senate is aware that the Department of Social Security is presently spending $40,000 on a feasibility study to determine whether it should have a corporate uniform. A few years ago Qantas Airways Ltd got bagged on this, and so too did Australian Airlines Ltd. However, that has not stopped the agency that is supposed to be providing income support payments for those who are sick and unemployed from spending $40,000 on a feasibility study for corporate uniforms. I do not need to go on much more about those sorts of waste and extravagance.

The tragedy is that the numbers now receiving benefits do not need to be anywhere near as high as they are. It is not just a matter of throwing more money at the problem. It is a matter of freeing up the system and having a flexible labour market that would enable many able-bodied people who want to work to actually get into the workplace.

I am delighted that the Government is now talking about training wages and other support programs, which are the thin end of the wedge and which presumably the trade unions will hit on the head as soon as they recognise them for what they are. It has taken the Government eight years to start to go down that track and it simply has not been prepared to bite the bullet to date. As a result, we will have more and more stories of heartbreak from non-government organisations, detailing to us in graphic terms what the ordinary citizens are incapable of expressing other than in the privacy of their own homes. The occasional person who bursts into tears during a radio interview is really symbolic of mass human tragedy that results, in many ways, from deliberate Government policy. This Government will have a lot to answer for to Australian society in the years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have once again in one of these matters of public importance a speech which indicates the important distinction between talking about important things and saying something important. Important as the subject matter we are talking about is-Australia's present economic circumstances and its human consequences-and eloquent as Senator Alston always is, there was nothing new in what he said. He did not put forward one proposal on what should be done about the human consequences of the recession. In fact, his speech was all about people receiving too much assistance-not too little. It was about an attack on public servants and the conditions under which they work, as if somehow or other that would resolve the problem. It was all about trifling around the edges.

SPEECH.PARA: No-one can deny the significant human cost involved in any recession. Recessions hurt people. It is an inevitable consequence. As the economy gets smaller, we obviously cannot all be better off. What is more, the burden falls unfairly. As Harold Wilson once said, even if unemployment is only one per cent, the individual concerned is 100 per cent unemployed. The significant human costs at the moment are very real, and it is government's obligation, firstly, to try to implement policy to bring us out of the recession and, secondly, to try to compensate and assist people who are carrying the burden of the recession.

However, we need to somehow put the current economic circumstance in context. We get these wonderful figures thrown around on how the economy has been in a mess for the past eight years and whatever. I do not happen to have with me statistics on the past eight years. I have with me a document that many honourable senators will be familiar with-the monthly economic and social indicators put out by the Parliamentary Research Service of the Parliamentary Library. It uses as its cut-off point the 1986-87 financial year. That is why I will use that figure, not because it is particularly advantageous to the Government-we would actually be better off going back to 1982-83.

TALK.START.PARA: —Back copies are available.

—I did not think it was worth the effort of sending someone off to get it. The 1982-83 statistics would actually be better for us. I am making the explanation only so that people do not get too excited about my somehow selectively using the cut-off date.

SPEECH.PARA: Even though no-one can deny that the economy is in recession, and that is a bad thing, let us have a look at the situation relative to July 1986. Since July 1986-and Senator Alston correctly says the best antidote for poverty is employment-there has been an increase in the number of jobs in this economy. Notwithstanding that we are now losing some of that gain, the net increase from July 1986 to January 1991 is 838,000-an increase of 12 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort? Government created initiatives just to take up the slack. The little side things you set up.
—No. In fact, government employment in that period has fallen. Senator Panizza should look at those statistics and not just let his prejudices guide his assessment.
—Who are they? They are people at the lower end: part timers, casuals and--
—They are people in jobs, and that is the important thing.
—Terminating jobs; mickey mouse jobs.

—Look at the productivity of those people. Let us look at the size of the economy over that period. The gross domestic product at constant prices since September 1986 has also increased by 12 per cent. So the output of workers has not declined; it has kept pace. We have an economy 12 per cent bigger than it was in September 1986. So the economy is substantially larger. A bigger cake is being distributed.

SPEECH.PARA: People talk about the great crisis of the decline in manufacturing production, and I heard Senator Boswell interject about it earlier today. Manufacturing production has increased by 16 per cent since 1984-85. None of those statistics are put in to in any way say that the economy is not in recession and that Australians should not be concerned about it or its economic and social consequences. It is simply to say: let us not pretend that somehow or another there have been eight years of disaster. We have a recession, but it is a recession that has followed from seven years of enormously high growth-much higher than in the countries with which we normally compare ourselves.

As Senator Alston did, I want to briefly outline some of the relevant features from the industry statement that relate to this particular debate, to make some comments about the continuing attempts by the Opposition to have it both ways, to give some examples of Government initiatives to assist those in greatest need, to highlight that contrast in the time available, and to try to bring together some of those economic and social policy questions.

In the statement made in the Senate on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and by the Prime Minister himself in the House of Representatives and released publicly, there are some important short term measures to deal with the impact of the recession and the process of adjustment to a more competitive economy, particularly some important initiatives in the area of labour market adjustment and training. This is another of the very many contrasts we find with the circumstance in 1982, when we came out of that recession. Not only was it a recession that in many ways was significantly worse, but we came out of it with our skill base fundamentally eroded.

So those labour market adjustments and training initiatives in the statement, consciously included as part of the package of reform and restructuring, are designed to soften the impact in human terms. I reject the criticism that somehow or another this is an inappropriate way to try to assist people in a recession. It is very appropriate that we provide extra labour market adjustment to keep apprentices in employment, to keep trainees in employment, and to encourage employers by giving them greater assistance to employ apprentices and others so that as we emerge from the recession-as we certainly will-we emerge with the skill base intact and do not put those stresses on the labour market and do not find the bottlenecks in shortage of skilled labour that we did as we emerged from the 1982-83 recession, which caused significant labour market problems with inflationary and other consequences.

Those measures in this statement complement the fundamental medium term focus of the statement by putting in short term labour market adjustment and training measures that will both soften the impact of the recession in human terms and ensure that the economy comes out in a better condition to cope with the upturn than after previous recessions. That is compatible with a number of other things that are taking place in terms of getting some gain out of all the pain and trying to ensure that the economy emerges from the recession in better shape than it did in the past. Those are matters we have debated before; I do not think I will have the time to deal with them today.

The statement also contains reference to the package that will be handed down in April on rural adjustment to ameliorate the impact of that crisis. It is obvious that many of the problems in the rural sector are more of an international nature than a product of the Australian recession. However, that does not make them any the less painful for the individuals who are suffering their consequences. It does not stop the fact that they will have adverse social and economic effects flowing through the Australian economy and society because of the importance of the rural sector. So that rural adjustment package will also be important. I have briefly referred to those parts of the statement today because otherwise they may not have been taken into account in this day's considerations.

We once again find, in dealing with this matter and in listening to Senator Alston and his predecessors who have moved similar matters of public importance over the last fortnight, that the Opposition tries to have it both ways. It says, `We are going to be very macho in fiscal policy. We are going to cut $3 billion off outlays, and half of it will come from cutting people off the dole. But we are also concerned that the Government is not sufficiently concerned about the human consequences of the recession'. It wants to appeal to the small government constituency who say, `Get out there and beat down the government outlays from their already record low. Go out there and tighten fiscal policy further', even though they know that will kill off any recovery in the economy. At the same time, it wants to hide behind a mask of compassion.

The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), has said that, in government, the Opposition would cut expenditure by $3 billion and $1.5 billion of that would come from restricting access to the dole. That is a great exposition of concern for the tragic human consequences of the recession. We had the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), in his previous role as shadow Treasurer, saying that the long term unemployed should live by their own means. That is fairly easy to say if one owns sports cars, restaurants and all those sorts of things, but it is not easy for the long term unemployed to be told that they have to live by their own means.

It is quite clear that that $3 billion cut would substantially worsen the Australian recession. It would snuff out the insipient recovery that we have. The only good fortune that we can see is that there will be no opportunity for those opposite to implement that proposal. But we can try to look for some indication of where that $3 billion might come from. Across the Tasman the conservative Government of New Zealand came in with a similar sort of macho rhetoric. We find that in its Social Security Amendment Bill it has displayed great concern for the tragic human consequences of the recession! It has axed the dole for 16- and 17-year-olds. It has cut $NZ35.40 per week off the unemployment benefit for those aged under 25 and made substantial cuts for those over 25. It indicated at the weekend that it will look for more savings by cutting superannuation payments to people in New Zealand and making a whole line of other draconian cuts. That Government reflects that great compassion that we also see in the conservatives here! It was most starkly illustrated by one of the great quotes of modern political life, when the Police Minister, of all people, in New Zealand urged people to grow silverbeet instead of collecting welfare cheques.

We have the sort of simplistic nonsense that somehow or other if only people would wander out and take care of themselves there would be no need for further assistance and therefore we could make massive cuts in welfare payments and still profess compassion and concern for those in greatest need.

One of the redeeming features of Australian democracy is that political parties that tend so grossly to underestimate the intelligence of the voters tend to pay the price. Voters do see through double standards like that. They do know that one cannot pose at one and the same time as the pillar of fiscal rectitude and as one with concern for the tragic human consequences. They know that the whole equals the sum of the parts. We cannot try to reduce the size of the cake and say that we are going to make everybody better off. They do see through an entirely negative approach. That is what we have seen today.

One of the interesting things to speculate about is what poor old Opposition members are going to do when the economy picks up. They will be absolutely bereft of things to talk about because they have nothing positive to say. They are always in here talking about the recession. They must have been absolutely distraught today when they started to find newspaper headlines saying, `Signs of slump moderating', and `Figures suggest economy is ready to begin growing again'. I am not crowing about those small indicators of possible future improvements. It is far too early. I do not wish to be misinterpreted as saying that the economic problems are behind us. I am simply saying--

TALK.START.PARA: —You're not talking about an early election, are you?

—Not however one pronounces it. I am simply saying that the Opposition is taking a totally negative approach in the almost endless series of matters of public importance that we have been facing recently. How bereft it is of policy will be displayed when the economy picks up, as it inevitably will. We find, as I have said before, that most of the economic commentators are expecting the economy to pick up during 1991 and predicting a healthy rate of growth in 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: I have referred before to the Westpac Banking Corporation's Market Insights magazine of March 1991, in which the bank indicates that it is expecting in 1992 real growth in gross domestic product of 2.8 per cent with inflation at 4 per cent. It would be a remarkable achievement if it were to be true-to have that growth combined with inflation at that low level. That is not an unreasonable prediction from a very competent and impartial observer.

I want to take a little time-I have only a few minutes left-to look at some of the social expenditures undertaken by this Government that deal with what this matter of public importance is supposed to be about, although Senator Alston did not make much reference to it; that is, the consequences for those individuals who are carrying a disproportionate burden of the cost of the recession. It is always the case that some individuals do that, because unemployment inevitably cannot be distributed equally. Of course, there are individuals who are suffering loss of income in other ways and households which might have gone from two incomes to one. They are not suffering the same sorts of consequences as in previous recessions, where we had households losing their sole breadwinner, but it is still a very significant social and economic problem for those families.

I do not have time to go through all the issues that one might consider and contemplate the consequences of the Opposition's proposals for cutting $3 billion from outlays and its other policies as enunciated. But for many of those families one of the very important factors is the availability of child-care. They may previously have had two incomes and now be down to 1 1/2, or one if they are battling, but there is still the capacity to take advantage of some of the enormously increased numbers of government-funded child-care places that have been made available. One of the most fundamental underpinnings of the social wage, of social conditions in which families under stress find themselves, is services made available to them by Medicare; the guarantee that they will be able to afford to take care of the health of their children without being left by the wayside, as has occurred in the past.

There have been very fundamental income support measures introduced as a consequence of the 1987 election promises, highlighted by the family allowance supplement, and also the benefits that are flowing to many families in need through the child support scheme. Those two things have done a lot to enhance the income level of families in greatest need in Australia. They are reforms of which the Government is justifiably proud. But income support measures alone will never be enough. They will not eliminate all the social problems that families have. They do not deal with all the social wage aspects that a government would wish to have.

Other measures are provided for, such as improvements in housing and education. We have already seen the important statistics about the jobs, education and training program; about, as I have said, the child support scheme; about rent assistance for low income families; and about the provision of more public housing. All these, and the initiatives that today's statement has reflected in the area of training and labour market adjustment, will assist families to cope with the difficult and harsh consequences of the recession.

Today's economic statement by the Prime Minister, and the supporting statements by the other three Ministers, is primarily a question about medium term strategy, and that is appropriately so. The recession is not going to finish tomorrow because of anything stated today. The leads and lags in economic policy take much longer than that, as all sensible commentators know. The initiatives that have been taken with regard to lowering interest rates, tax cuts and the countercyclical impact of fiscal policy are working to bring the economy out of recession, and will do so.

So it is appropriately and primarily a medium term strategy document; and that is what the economy needs. But it does have some of the short term measures to which I have referred that will both ameliorate the human consequences of the recession and bring us out of the recession in a healthier state with regard to our skill base. There are important other social justice initiatives that the Government has taken over the last eight years which continue to have that effect.

Tragic as the recession is, the human consequences for the individuals most adversely affected are ameliorated in a way that no party that professes concern can deny. By proposing to cut $3 billion from expenditure, the coalition would crush the life out of the economy. It would crush many of the families who would have to bear the consequences of its policies. It is that combination of economic and social policy, of medium term and short term initiatives, that is a government's responsibility in response to a recession, and that is what the Government is doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to begin on a positive note, if indeed that is possible in view of the topic we are debating this afternoon. I think we have an all-party agreement on two issues. Firstly, employment certainly is a solution. If we were able to maintain full employment-which should be the goal of any government-we would not find ourselves looking at the misery and other human consequences of this recession. Indeed, we would simply not have a recession.

SPEECH.PARA: The second issue is that certainly people do not want to have to go through the indignity, the demeaning, arduous and difficult processes-as Senator Alston highlighted-of having to wait for perhaps two or three hours to obtain social security benefits. People do not choose to go through that process. There is a common community perception that somehow they are a drain on the system; that they are, to use the term, `dole bludgers' and all the other connotations that unfortunately this society continues to put on people who, through no fault of their own, find themselves in need of support.

Unfortunately, we have considerable disagreement with the Opposition on the way in which we need to treat the people who, through no fault of their own, find themselves in need of welfare support. The matter of public importance states:
The Government's cynical disregard of the tragic human consequences of the recession, `We had to have . . .'

The Australian Democrats have no problems with the fact that there is a very tragic human consequence. Indeed, the Government itself has admitted that this recession has led to considerable hardship, particularly on Australian families. But the word I do have some problems with is the word `cynical' because the majority of the difficulties people trying to access welfare benefits are having were caused by policies voted in with the support of the Liberal and National parties in opposition in this chamber. The Opposition has supported what the Government has been doing-eating away, cutting away, at the so-called social security support services or the welfare net.

In my relatively short time in this chamber, I have seen the Opposition support the Government on a range of measures that have contributed to the problems that are part of these tragic human consequences of the recession. I refer to problems such as reducing the income support for young unemployed and homeless people to well below the poverty line; refusing to support exemption of family farms from the family allowance supplement-an issue which Senator Alston covered very well. Not only are farm incomes down but also there are no jobs in rural areas which these families can fall back on. At the same time as acknowledging the difficulties, farm families are still cut off from the family allowance supplement which the Government has highlighted as one of its achievements. I would certainly agree with that-it has been very successful in the case of city families on low incomes. Unfortunately, farming families and families of small business men and women are not able to access that support service.

We have also seen the introduction of a liquid assets test on unemployment and sickness benefits; reductions in rent allowance; the introduction of a $2.50 prescription charge for pensioners; and so on. Indeed, in the life of this Labor Government, the list goes on and on, and grows alarmingly. The Opposition has continually aided and abetted the Government in its practices in implementing these policies. That is why I have great difficulty with the word `cynical' in the Opposition's matter of public importance.

These measures have served to exacerbate the problems faced by those people who find themselves retrenched or unemployed through no fault of their own and who are unable to secure any job-an inferior job, a job well below their level of expertise; indeed, any job at all. These measures have helped further entrench many Australian families in poverty. Senator Alston pointed out again-and we talked about this last week in this place-the growing lists of people trying to access the support services offered by welfare agencies only to be turned away in more and more cases. So I think a fair bit of cynicism is coming from both sides, rather than just the Government.

Whilst I understand the Opposition being a bit miffed about having its policies stolen from under its nose and wanting to jump on the band wagon and be full of concern about the consequences of the recession, just what is it specifically offering? What is it offering long-suffering Australian families at this time? What would it be doing in this situation? Where is the benefit to low income and rural Australian families in policies that call for total deregulation and privatisation of our transport, health, financial and communication systems? Where is the benefit in the unemployment benefit being cut off after nine months? Where is the benefit in an across the board, flat rate consumption tax? Where is the benefit for them in massive cuts in public expenditure?

To those families and people now experiencing hardship, it all sounds like more of the same-the rhetoric of the trickle down economic theory and a major shortage of new ideas from either the Government or the Opposition. The country is not in good shape-and this is something else that we seem to be in agreement about today. We all know that Australian families are certainly feeling the pinch.

I will not spend time going over the statistics-which Senator Alston did so ably-looking at the unemployment rates. However 9.1 per cent is only the official unemployment rate. It does not take into account hidden unemployment, particularly women. It does not look at those who are now underemployed and forced to work perhaps a four-day week. In fact, officially, some 760,000 people are now unemployed; and I consider that to be very conservative. We now have statistics which show that, on average, 18 people are trying to fill each job vacancy. There is certainly a far larger number of people looking for the jobs in the low skilled or unskilled areas. There were some 3,000 bankruptcies Australia-wide in December and, as has been stated, farm incomes are dramatically lower-in fact, they are estimated to be about 67 per cent lower this year.

What these families suffering these difficulties now need to hear is fresh ideas from the Government. There needs to be some acknowledgment that its way may not be the only path through these difficult economic times. The difficult times that are facing them have been made more difficult by the fact that the Government is refusing to acknowledge that they are having major problems. The Government needs to show some concern and give some practical support now. Instead, we have a situation where any alternative point of view or criticism of the Government, from within its ranks or from the community, is often taken as naive and treacherous and, as a result, we simply do not get to hear from those who actually disagree with the prevailing economic line. For example, we hardly ever hear the view-contrary to mythology-that Australia spends less on housing and social security payments than most other developed countries. Also, we are not as heavily taxed as most comparable nations. The problem with our taxation system is: who pays?

I want to speak briefly again about Australia's income support system because it seems to me that this is where the Government's disregard for human consequences of the recession is most apparent. As I have said many times before, we are seeing a move away from the social security system which was designed to be a safety net; by the way, it did have the bipartisan support of the Opposition when in government.

Our social security system used to be driven by the attitude that we helped those who, through no fault of their own, were in financial need. What has occurred is that, through the notion of targeting, we have moved away from that basic concept-that is, that the social security system would apply universally to those Australians who lacked sufficient funds to maintain themselves and their families-and we are now dangerously close to talking about the `deserving poor', an attitude one would have hoped would have gone out with the poorhouse.

We do not say, as Senator Alston likes to make out, that the social security system should be available willy-nilly, as much as one likes, to anyone who happens to pass by. There obviously must be eligibility requirements. We object to the increasing whittling down of those requirements to the point where the system can no longer be said to be supporting those Australians who do not have sufficient funds to support themselves and their families. Every time a piece of social security legislation comes before this Parliament, it contains further constraints placed on eligibility criteria. What this means in practice is what Senator Alston was talking about previously: longer and longer waiting lists and longer and longer waiting periods before even getting to see somebody; a high level of literacy needed to complete the increasingly complex forms; a remarkable set of double standards put in place for women who want to receive sole parent pensions; a continuing invasion of privacy for social security recipients; and many recipients now needing personal advocates to find their way through the maze and over the hurdles that have been placed in front of them. For example, I draw the Senate's attention to what happens to young people trying to access the young homeless allowance.

What it also means is that we have accepted as a community that it is okay to tighten the eligibility criteria on one group in the country, but not on others. For example, Professor Don Edgar from the Australian Institute of Family Studies pointed out that there are three main ways in which the state provides welfare. They are: public welfare or the social security and welfare programs; fiscal welfare-that is, tax relief, concessions and allowances; and occupational welfare-that is, benefits received by employees as a result of their employment.

What has been happening in Australia is that the eligibility criteria for public welfare has become tighter and tighter, while the other two have, in fact, eased, thereby increasing benefits to the better off members of the community. And this is where targeting is taking us-not forward to a more equitable social security system, but backwards to Victorian notions of the deserving and the undeserving poor.

People are either in poverty and unable to support themselves and their families and in need of financial assistance, or they are not. It does not matter how they got there or whether some of us might think some people are more deserving of support than others. We need an income support system that does just that-provides support to those who need it-instead of one that is unravelling at such a rapid rate that people in need of financial assistance are not getting it and have to resort to the welfare agencies, thus putting greater and greater pressure on the agencies' very limited resources. I call again on the Government to take note of what is happening. I ask: what is the Government planning to do for those people who are not able to access social security support and who cannot get support from the agencies? Where do they turn next?

These agencies tell us that three ongoing problems are responsible for the increase in the numbers of people calling on them for assistance: firstly, tighter eligibility criteria; secondly, the longer waiting periods that now exist before people can access benefits at all, and this is particularly crucial for young people who are leaving school; and, thirdly, inadequate income support-that is, even if people eventually get onto the benefits, and again I highlight the situation of young people. The amounts they are asked to live on are so far below the poverty line that they are forced to turn to the agencies for additional support.

When people receive support through the social security system, there are still numerous structural problems which the Government-and I must add here I suspect also the Opposition-refuses to address . For example, we continue to impose poverty traps and extremely high marginal tax rates on many social security recipients. Even in these harsh economic times, we hear scarcely a murmur of dissent or concern about these problems.

Despite the slash and burn mentality of the Government's social security policies, it cannot target every unemployed person out of eligibility for benefits. Increases in unemployment are a direct consequence of the recession and, therefore, increased support and financial assistance will be required. I am pleased to note that additional funds will be going into training programs, but after these people have been trained, where are they going to go unless the jobs are available?

The Government must accept responsibility for the increasing numbers of people needing income support and it must ensure that these people get the support and assistance they need. If it cannot get its economic policies right and ensure full employment, then it must at least show some understanding and compassion for those who are suffering as a consequence of its failed policies. Unfortunately in the short term we will need more money to support those who are in need now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's cynical disregard of the tragic human consequences of the recession, `We had to have.'.

I ask: how many honourable senators present remember the J-curve? That was one of Paul Keating's earlier explanations for why we should not worry about the economic downturn that we then all realised we were in. The simple notion was to say that we might be on the downturn, but nonetheless this was part of the process of coming up again. An analogy was drawn to this J-curve that we were simply in an inevitable part of the picking up process. For those who have forgotten the J-curve, they might remember the economy bubbling over like champagne spilling out of an overfilled champagne glass. One imagines that the Treasurer (Mr Keating), with his French clocks, is quite familiar with overfilling his champagne glass to the extent that it bubbles over. I do not happen to have the league of friends who, when they have champagne, waste it by letting it bubble over the glass. That is the privilege of people with antique clock collections, I suppose.

This was another way of saying, `Look, don't worry that the current account is not as we expect. Don't worry about all these imports coming in, the economy is bubbling over and things are going well', when we all knew that that simply was not the case.

The trouble with this situation was that the media absolutely loved the performance put on by the Treasurer; they absolutely applauded and encouraged Australia to do the same. It is no surprise that the Treasurer has run out of positive analogies to make; there are no more that he can trot out for this performance. No-one is amused any more, and the performance looks just as tired as we have known for some time that it really is.

Right now we are in the middle of the recession we needed to have. For those who do not remember, that is the recession that we were told just a few weeks before we did not need to have and we were not going to have. Those of us on this side of the chamber who said, `This nation is going into a negative growth phase, we are heading towards a recession', were labelled as the doomsday people who had nothing positive to say, who were trying to talk the economy down, when in fact we were trying to alert the Government to the fact that it was not in control, Paul Keating was not pulling the right levers, and a recession was on the way with all the tragic human consequences that we can now see.

Women, of course, are the first people to sense the imminence of a recession. I do not say that because of any outdated notions that women have any sort of intuition that men do not; I do not actually believe that. I say that because they have a presence in a far broader spectrum of the daily marketplace of our lives than most men do simply because most men are the primary breadwinners and they spend much more time and confine themselves to a narrower spectrum of life than women are obliged to cope with and, by and large, enjoy.

Women have been telling me and other parliamentarians what they have been able to sense by their engagement in this broad spectrum of life-what the kids need for school, what the prices are at the supermarket, whether their kids are having difficulty getting jobs-and they interchange this, if they are lucky enough to have some time to play tennis with their mates, and build up a collective knowledge which, quite frankly, is not accessible by bureaucrats locked away in Canberra. It is something someone can feel about a society, not something that someone can necessarily tell from statistics.

Anyway, here we are in this recession. It has apparently already been pointed out, but let me recap briefly how bad the situation is. The January 1991 seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for all persons is 8.4 per cent. That is the highest since March 1987. It is a dreadful situation. For young Australians, that is, the 15- to 19-year-olds, it is a desperate situation. The seasonally adjusted rate for January this year for young Australians who are looking for work and who cannot get a job is 21.7 per cent. As I say, it is absolutely disastrous.

The situation of women perhaps deserves particular attention. I would like to turn to that now, not because women have a more important place in the discussion of the recession but because the Government likes to blow its own bags about what it has done about creating jobs. I do not notice too much attention being given to the jobs the Government has not created or the jobs that have been lost as a consequence of Government activity.

Again, for January 1991, if the unemployment figures are split into males and females, the figure for females is actually higher. It was 8.5 per cent and the highest level since November 1987. Looking at the unemployed in terms of numbers, for females the figure is 300,100. That is the highest level ever of unemployed females. I admit that is partly because more women want to work in the first place, but it is not only that. That is not why that level is now the highest ever. It is at the highest level because we are in a recession and people cannot get the jobs they want. The January 1991 figure for unemployed females looking for part time work is 106,800; again the highest level ever. There has been a dramatic increase since December last year, with a further 17,700 women looking for part time work.

I listened to what Senator McMullan said and I do not think I heard him refer to numbers of people. I heard him refer to technical policies and what the Government was going to do about this and that in a very impartial and third party sense. The only aspect he raised which gave some insight into the fact that he might perhaps understand what it is like to be unemployed came when he quoted someone as having said, `It does not matter if you have only one per cent unemployment; if you are the one unemployed, you are 100 per cent unemployed'. He did not go on to say how many people fit into that category. There are 300,100 women who, as far as they are concerned, are 100 per cent unemployed. He did not mention that there were 418,500 men who are 100 per cent unemployed, as far as they are concerned. There are 106,800 women looking for part time work and 193,300 looking for full time work. Each of those people, in his or her own way, feels 100 per cent hard done by because of the policies of this Government. Every one of them is quite entitled to feel like that.

I am pleased that Senator Lees commenced on a positive note by saying that the answer to this situation is jobs. That is what we need for people who are unemployed. The way to alleviate the tragic consequences of this recession is to create a situation where people have jobs. However, she went on to say that the coalition deserves some sort of criticism for assisting the Government in better targeting welfare programs. She somehow sought to create the impression that better targeting programs was a bad thing, and that if one wanted to target welfare better, one was somehow out to get all welfare recipients, which is simply not the case. If there were an unlimited-or an almost unlimited-pool of money, one is nonetheless doing the right thing by those who are to receive that money if one makes sure the money is most appropriately targeted.

We could have a debate about that. Had I left home at 15, 16 or 17 years of age, I do not think there would have been the slightest question that I could get the unemployment benefit because the social attitude then was that one did not leave home when one was 15. I am grateful that honourable senators have not made any unkind remarks about how long ago that was. However, things have changed in that time. I know that and young people expect to get away earlier or, if you like, cut the umbilical cord, the apron strings or whatever.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are leaving later now.

—As Senator Lees said, there is another cycle coming on. All I mean by raising that matter is that the cycles do change, and what was an appropriate welfare payment for one generation may not be appropriate for another. I do not think it does the debate on welfare, which hopefully will continue to improve and become more informed, any good to say simply that if one wants to question the validity of continuing with a particular aspect of a welfare policy, one is therefore anti-welfare. I do not think that is an appropriate remark to make at all.

SPEECH.PARA: If one has in one's own mind a vision that welfare can be better targeted to people who are more needy, I do not think it is appropriate to say, `Well, you are just raising the concept of the undeserving poor'. I think that is a huge quantum leap and not one that I felt was explained in the speech made by Senator Lees. Senator Lees said that it was a question not of whether one is undeserving or deserving but of whether one is in need or not. I take issue with that. That is not a philosophy I endorse. I do not think that, if one is in need because one is not looking for work, it is fair to expect other taxpayers to foot the bill for one's indulgence. I do not say this to indicate at all that I believe there is a huge number of people in that category or that there is some unbelievably large proportion of these people on the unemployment benefit.

I do not think the guy who is on the assembly line at Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd thinks it is fair either. He has to work to support his family and children and he does not think that other people should have the choice about that, and neither do I. I do not think that is having a go at welfare recipients at all. Quite the contrary. I think it is maintaining the integrity of welfare recipients. If a guy is laid off from his job because of circumstances-because the company was mismanaged, because of the economy, or because the company failed because of the ineptitude of the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-and he has genuinely lost his job through no fault of his own, it is an unmitigated disgrace to ask him to line up with people who cannot be bothered to look for a job, because he deserves every penny and the others do not. We could debate another day the circumstances under which and how we define and ascertain whether someone is genuinely looking for a job. That is a difficult area, and I understand that. However, I do not think we should be deterred from pursuing that task simply because it is a difficult area. It is a task we should definitely continue to pursue.

Senator Lees said there is cynicism on both sides but she did not point out that the cynicism on her side is such that the Australian Democrats produced a whole whack of policies at the last election but could not cost them. Here is the party that picks up the bits and pieces of policy left by the major parties, according to them-the nooks and crannies they shove their beaks into-and parcels off what policies they can to people, telling the major parties here they are cynical. I would have thought that was the pot calling the kettle black.

I conclude by saying that the whole focus of this debate should be on the fact that, unless there is structural change in this country, jobs will not be created. What the Government and the Democrats do not understand is that one does not create jobs by giving money away. One creates jobs by structural reform. This is what we are on about. Senator Lees says she does not know what we are offering. That is what we are offering-reform of the labour market, reform of the waterfront and reform of the taxation system. I could go on had I more time, but I clearly do not. That is the way to give people jobs-not just give them money and say, `We're sorry for the mess we created'. The way to give people jobs is to fix up the mess and that is what the coalition will do when it gets into government after the next election.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the following matter of public importance proposed by Senator Alston:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's cynical disregard of the tragic human consequences of the recession, `We had to have.'.

It is quite interesting that this matter of public importance is proposed on the day of the release of the Government's industry statement where the Government outlines in a positive way a blueprint for the economic future of Australia. All we hear from the Opposition, in the most carping and negative terms, is this so-called matter of public importance. It is so typical of the intellectual bankruptcy of the Opposition-nothing more than a tirade of criticisms and absolutely no solutions whatsoever offered for Australia's economic circumstances.

The Government has proposed, and is working in a comprehensive and integrated way, both to cure the problems of the Australian economy and to mitigate their consequences. It is a government, of course, of ideas and ideals, as opposed to nothing from the Opposition. This Opposition has no plans for the economy except for a few tired, outdated and discredited New Right proposals that are religiously expounded by the gurus of the New Right that now litter the Liberal Party both in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. At the same time as putting forward this discredited New Right agenda, the Liberal Party plans to do nothing more than kick sand in the faces of those people who most need help in these difficult economic times. So I ask you, Mr Deputy President: who is really showing cynicism at this time?

Senator Alston talks about tragic human consequences. I think it is worth examining how the Opposition would plan to treat the unemployed, the aged, those people who need assistance in our community, the disadvantaged. What is the Liberal Party proposing at this time? Laurie Oakes said it all in an article in the Bulletin magazine when Dr Hewson described his mind-boggling plans for the social security area. In an article headed `Efficiency out, ideology in', he said:
No-one should be under any illusions about the hard line the coalition is taking on the question of social welfare under John Hewson's leadership. The ideas being tossed up by Hewson and Alston,-
Dr Hewson and Senator Alston, I interpolate-

including the possibility that the federal Department of Social Security could be abolished altogether, give the first real indication of how a coalition government would set about trying to achieve that $3 billion cut in federal spending that the Opposition's economic `dries' have been talking about for several years now. The plan is to slash the welfare budget.
Of course, I must give Senator Alston credit because he has had a very significant role in coming forward with this Liberal Party policy. In this same Bulletin article he is quoted as saying:
I think things such as review teams and rehabilitation exercises could all be done by the private sector much more efficiently.
What did Laurie Oakes, who, of course, is no noted Labor supporter, say about all this? He said:

Picture this. A woman pensioner answers a knock on the door and is confronted by a man from Wormauld or Mayne Nickless demanding to know whether she is living with anyone and, if so, who. What is his authority? His company has a government contract to check on the bona fides of welfare recipients. Most Australians, I suggest, would regard that scenario as unacceptable, but it is what the Federal Opposition is seriously putting forward.

That, of course, is Senator Alston's view of an ideal Australian society. I think it was the Treasurer (Mr Keating) who correctly said that Senator Alston would have age pensioners lining up in the marbled foyers of the major accountancy firms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that? That is what Paul Keating said.

—That is right: the Treasurer. It is interesting that Dr Hewson and Senator Alston have now gone quiet about some of their plans, but I can assure you, Mr Deputy President, that they are very serious. I know that they do not want the electors in Australia to get a grip on what they are proposing, but I think it is worth while reminding the Senate tonight in this matter of public importance of precisely what Senator Alston is putting forward.

SPEECH.PARA: This is his program: the abolition of the Commonwealth Department of Social Security, with many of the responsibilities of the Department of Social Security passing to the States; decisions about eligibility for benefits to be made by welfare agencies such as the Smith Family or St Vincent de Paul Society, presumably by voluntary workers; more money to be given to charities to distribute as hand-outs in place, at least partially, of current welfare payments; the actual payment of benefits to be made by firms of accountants; and eligibility reviews to be conducted by private firms with a government contract to check bona fides. In other words, those firms would have the power to investigate social security recipients' private lives.

Some of the welfare functions having been handed over to State governments, people in some States would then possibly receive higher welfare payments than people in other States. The coup de grace is the abolition of not only the Commonwealth Department of Social Security but also the health and education departments. That is the Opposition's agenda, to the extent that it has one. As I have said, the Opposition has gone a bit quiet on it now. But there is no doubt that fundamentally the Opposition is committed to destroying a targeted and equitable social welfare system such as the one we have in Australia-which, I might say, is the envy of other countries-and would put in its place the sort of appalling system of social security that we see in the United States.
I was very interested in an article in the Age on 24 October, 1990, entitled `US study challenges Libs' welfare plan', which stated:
The study, by the highly respected Brookings Institution, is believed to argue strongly against handing responsibility for welfare payments to the states.
. . . the difference in state benefits-
that is, in the United States-
was remarkably wide.

The study found a greater difference in welfare levels than between interstate costs of living and wage levels and evidence suggested that poor people actually were attracted to states with higher welfare levels.

The ``safety net'' of welfare payments has many holes in it, through which a large number of Americans fall. It is common to see people sleeping on the footpath and in parks in big cities; it is impossible to walk through central Washington or New York without being asked to hand over your spare change to a homeless person.
The social divisions-between rich and poor, between black and white-are often sharply defined. Income levels and, even more noticeably, benefit levels vary widely between states.

That is the sort of system that Senator Alston is proposing for this country. He wants to tear up the welfare safety net which existed even under conservative governments in Australia, although it has been greatly improved by Labor governments. In the meantime, Senator Alston diverts himself by repeatedly attacking the Department of Social Security as to the way it is administered. He tries to claim that the Department has no need to train its staff. He resents the fact that the Department of Social Security is such an efficient deliverer of services that it spends only 3.5c in the dollar in delivering its services-a record that private enterprise would kill for.

In the debate on this matter of public importance it is valid to draw out some of these basic philosophical differences which so obviously exist between the Opposition and the Government. This Government does not want the sort of divided and angry country that Margaret Thatcher bequeathed to England. This Government and the Australian Labor Party want a reasonable and compassionate society which takes care of those people who, for whatever reason or for that matter for whatever length of time, are not in a position to provide for themselves financially.

On the one hand, our policies aim to provide such a society through the good times and through a recession such as we are enduring now. On the other hand, the Opposition seems to aspire towards a social welfare system such as that in the United States where social welfare recipients have to go cap in hand to receive benefits and then humiliate themselves in the community by paying for goods with food stamps, and where in some States, left to set their own levels of benefits, unsustainable levels of support are offered deliberately so that poor people will not settle there. Dr Hewson and Senator Alston do not look at a system such as this and shudder as any reasonable person would; they look at that system and say, `Yes, that system is for us'. Yet they are the people who, in a matter of public importance such as this, talk about a cynical disregard for the tragic human consequences of the recession.

The report I have just tabled deals with the redevelopment of Borneo Barracks at Cabarlah in Queensland. The limit-of-cost estimate for the work is $12.71 million (at August 1990 prices).

The works referred to the Committee combine into a single project the construction of additional facilities for the Joint Telecommunications School and support facilities to enable 7 Signal Regiment to provide the necessary support for the School.

The Joint Telecommunications School provides specialist signal training for the Australian Defence Force. It cannot train the required numbers in the facilities it currently shares with 7 Signal Regiment.

In 1985, the ADF examined specialist signal training common to two or more Services with a view to conducting joint training by one Service, and to recommend the most appropriate location for a training school. As a result of this study, Cabarlah was selected and the Joint Training School was raised there on 1 September 1986. Navy and Air Force relocated their schools to Cabarlah, leading to a significant increase in the staff and student population. The 1985 study was reassessed in 1990 and Cabarlah was confirmed as the most suitable location for the School.

Most of the existing facilities at Cabarlah were constructed in the 1960s, when there were 212 personnel posted there; some facilities remain from the 1940s. The current establishment is 420 Service personnel (including 160 trainees) and 15 civilian staff. By 1995, there are expected to be 718 Service personnel, including 230 trainees at any one time, and 25 civilian staff.
The objective of the proposal is to provide sufficient working and living accommodation so the School can train sufficient specialist personnel for the Defence Force by building:
* permanent, purpose-designed training facilities
* upgrading working facilities for the supporting administration, medical/dental and technical maintenance functions
* additional living accommodation for all ranks
* rank and file dining and recreational facilities.

The Committee was concerned about the quality of the water supplied to Cabarlah and took evidence from the Crow's Nest Shire Council that it was examining the possibility of providing an adequate filtration system. We have recommended that Defence and Australian Construction Services continue their discussions with the Shire council to provide better quality water to Borneo Barracks.

This Bill is an omnibus Bill amending existing legislation administered within the primary industries and energy portfolio. The Bill contains minor administrative amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985 and consequential amendments; the Dairy Produce Act 1986; the Dairy Produce Levy (No.1) Act 1986; and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987.

Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985. The amendments to this Act provide for the name of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation to be changed to the Meat Research Corporation.

The decision to change the name of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation to Meat Research Corporation was made at the request of the Corporation. The change was sought because its name was being confused with the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation. In addition the length of the name itself was causing confusion, particularly in the media.

The amendments to this Act also bring the Corporation into line with Government policy and the legislation for other rural research and development bodies by confining the Government's commitment to match industry funding for the Corporation to 0.5 per cent of gross value of production.

Consequential amendments following from the change of the name of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation to the Meat Research Corporation and the name of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act 1985 being changed to the Meat Research Corporation Act 1985 are being made to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977; Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council Act 1984; Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act 1984; Beef Production Levy Act 1990; Cattle and Beef Levy Collection Act 1990; Cattle Export Charge Act 1990; Cattle Transaction Levy Act 1990; Exotic Animal Disease Control Act 1989; Live-stock Export Charge Act 1977; Live-stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964; Rural Industries Research Act 1985; and Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) 1930.

Dairy Produce Act 1986 and Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act 1986. This amendment is required to reflect the inclusion of equal employment opportunity provisions in the Dairy Produce Act 1986, which is the enabling act of the Australian Dairy Corporation. The amendment will bring the Australian Dairy Corporation into line with existing government policy on equal employment opportunity. The amendments to this Act also provide for the name of the Australian Dairy Industry Conference to be changed to the Australian Dairy Industry Council and for its executive council to be known as its executive. These name changes require consequential amendments to the Dairy Produce Act 1986 and the Dairy Produce Levy (No.1) Act 1986.

Horticultural Research and Development Act 1987. The amendment provides for changes to the commercial role, administrative controls and accountability of the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. The changes are consistent with provisions contained in the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 which provides the framework for portfolio research and development.

Amendments to the Corporation's functions and powers concern the commercialisation of research and development and powers to join in the formation of a company and to acquire, hold and dispose of real and personal property. Arrangements for the conduct of corporation meetings and the decision making processes are streamlined to permit meetings by electronic means and for decisions to be taken without face to face meetings. Minor modifications are made to the Corporation's research and development plan and program to assist the Corporation to use these documents as more effective budgetary and planning tools.

The accountability of the Corporation is strengthened by a requirement that commercial activity in which the Corporation has an interest and activities relating to the formation of a company are included in the Corporation's annual report.
