TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memorandum and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill may be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The chief purpose of this Bill is to provide a mechanism for the establishment within the Australian Horticultural Corporation of an Australian Dried Fruits Board.

The Bill forms one component of the Government's response to the Industries Assistance Commission's report into the dried vine fruits industry of September 1989. The Government agrees with the Commission that there needs to be reform of the existing level of government assistance arrangements for the dried vine fruits industry. The other measures are contained in the Dried Vine Fruits Legislation Amendment Bill which covers changes to dried vine fruits statutory equalization and sultana underwriting.

The Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Bill is also consistent with the Government's decisions in response to the Professor Jeremy Davis ``Review of Commonwealth Primary Industry Statutory Marketing Authorities'' of March 1990.

The Government announced on 18 October 1990 in response to the Davis Review that it would not proceed at this stage with the recommendation to reform the Australian Horticultural Corporation, the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation and the Australian Honey Board into an Australian Agricultural Marketing Corporation. Rather than disrupt the relationship being developed between industry and the Australian Horticultural Corporation established in 1988, the Government announced the incorporation of the dried vine fruits industry into the Horticultural Corporation.

Nevertheless, the dried vine fruits industry will retain a high degree of independence over its export marketing operations within the Australian Horticultural Corporation. This arrangement reflects the industry's long history of competing successfully in export markets, a record of achievement which, unfortunately, has not always been matched by some of Australia's other horticultural industries.

The future participation of the dried vine fruits industry in the Australian Horticultural Corporation through an Australian dried fruits board is also in line with the Government's view that when monopoly export control powers are exercised, government needs to be assured sufficient checks and balances are in place to ensure that national interest is taken into account. The range of dried fruits export controls which are currently exercised by the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation will be continued by the Australian Dried Fruits Board but under the broad oversight of the Australian Horticultural Corporation. The Government's concerns in this area will then largely be met.

The mechanism for the dried vine fruits industry joining the Australian Horticultural Corporation will be, as I have indicated above, the establishment of a product board which is provided by the Bill before us.

At this stage, it is my expectation that only the dried vine fruits industry will operate within the Horticultural Corporation under these special provisions and that existing participants and newcomers will continue to participate directly in the Horticultural Corporation under the existing provisions.

I turn now to the specific provisions of the Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Bill 1990. A product board established within the Australian Horticultural Corporation will be required as its major task, in the same way as is the Corporation, to assist, or in the case of dried vine fruit, to continue to assist, specific horticultural industries in export marketing.

Product boards will replace the existing option of industry forming product group committees. These were intended to provide a formal mechanism for the provision of product-specific advice to the Corporation. This role is now being efficiently and cost effectively exercised through market liaison committees established by the participating industry organisations in consultation with the Corporation. Should industries wish to formalise these without going to the cost of a product board, the Corporation retains the power to set up committees under the general committees provision and to delegate powers to such bodies.

Changes to the structure of the Australian Horticultural Corporation to provide for product boards are contained primarily in the early sections of part 2 of the Bill. The balance of part 2 sets out the form and areas of operation of product boards.

The Australian Horticultural Corporation's strategic planning process will need to take account of, and include reference to, products covered by product boards. The Corporation's annual report will include accounts of product board operations and separately audited product board financial statements.

In many respects the structure and operations of product boards mirror those of the Horticultural Corporation. This can be seen, for example, in the relationship between the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Minister which is largely replicated in the relationship between the Corporation and a product board.

For the dried vine fruits industry, the Australian Dried Fruits Board is set up under part 3 of this Bill. If there is a case in the future, any other product board will be established by regulations. These will set out the name of the board and the products to be covered by it.

The Bill makes special provision in the amendment to section 8 of the Horticultural Corporation Act to prevent both the Corporation and a board doing same things at the same time to the same products. This is achieved by providing that the Corporation will not undertake functions in relation to a board's products unless that board is in agreement. Obviously, corporation-wide activities may nonetheless be appropriate in such areas as advertising or market research programs and a product board will still have the opportunity to participate in these.

A product board will be a body corporate. There are sound commercial reasons for providing a product board with corporate identity particularly in terms of financial and contractual activities that it might undertake but, as well, it clarifies for those who have contact with a board the authority under which it is operating. This will be particularly important for the Australian Dried Fruits Board which will take on long standing arrangements with a number of overseas agencies and groups.

A product board will have functions and powers that mirror the Corporation's. However, mindful of the great diversity in horticultural industries and the need to ensure the product board structure is not unnecessarily rigid, the Bill provides for the functions of a particular board to be tailored to the products it covers. For example, the dried vine fruits industry runs a very active private industry marketing program in Australia and there is no need for statutory involvement in this. The Australian Dried Fruits Board will exercise only export activities and the functions relating to domestic activities are set to be removed.
A product board is to be empowered to control exports through the inclusion of new clauses in part V of the Horticultural Corporation Act.

The Government has agreed to the continuation of the current range of export controls for dried vine fruits. I would expect that these controls will be exercised by the Australian Dried Fruits Board as conditions of export licensing under export licences issued by the Corporation.
The Minister is empowered to give directions to boards under the same circumstances as apply to the Corporation, that is only in exceptional circumstances.

A product board is to comprise an independent chairperson selected by the Corporation in consultation with the relevant producer organisation and five other members. All board members are to be appointed by the Corporation.

Each of the members other than the chairperson is to be selected by the relevant industry body so that each of the areas of expertise identified for these other board members is represented. In line with the Government's recently announced policy, no age limit is to apply to members.

Because a product board is likely to have coverage of quite a narrow product or group of products, it is important that it can draw on product specific advice and expertise from within its membership. The selection criteria therefore provide for 3 of the 5 board members to have such expertise. The other two members may be drawn from more general areas and in any case the board will have recourse to the expertise of Corporation members for more broad ranging advice if necessary. The selection process is not formalised in the same way as it is for statutory marketing authorities because of the product-specific nature that its membership will have.

The representative industry body for products covered by a board is in the best position to identify such members. I would nonetheless expect that the selection process adopted by industry bodies will be a disciplined one that will withstand scrutiny.

Provision is made for the chairperson to be a member of the Corporation board or be drawn from outside the Corporation's membership. In either case, attendance at corporation meetings will provide an important opportunity for the corporation to monitor regularly board activities and provision is therefore made for the chairperson, if not a member of the Corporation, to attend meetings if requested.

A product board's membership does not include a government member as each board will have regular access to the advice of the government member of the Corporation. A board would still be free to request an officer of my Department to attend a product board meeting if this was considered necessary.
A board will have a general manager and its own staff. For the Australian Dried Fruits Board, the existing staff of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation will become the employees of the new board.

As for the Corporation, a board will be required to prepare corporate and annual operating plans which will be subject to the approval of the Corporation. To assist in the process of assessing a board's effectiveness, and in keeping with recently announced government policy, a board will be required to develop, in consultation with its industry bodies, performance indicators. These indicators are to then be included in both the planning and reporting process. Once prepared, board plans will contribute to the preparation of the Corporation's plans.

A board will contribute to the overheads of the Corporation and this arrangement will be set out in regulations. I would expect the Corporation and the relevant industry body covered by a board to contribute substantially to identifying this share on an equitable basis. The cost will nonetheless reflect the activities that the board will undertake in its own right which, for other participant industries, will be provided by the Corporation.

The bill sets out the mechanism for payment of funds to a board and for the payment of costs to the Corporation such that both payments are to be made at the same time to each body. Amendment to the Horticultural Levy and Export Charge Acts and the associated collection Acts is necessary for this to occur and these are provided for in parts 5 to 8 of the Bill.

The Government's recently announced policy on accountability to levy payers now requires that annual general meetings be held. In conformity with this policy, the Australian Dried Fruits Board will be required to account annually to its levy payers through an annual general meeting. In due course, the Australian Horticultural Corporation will also be required to hold annual general meetings.

The provisions the board's annual general meetings, contained in division 4 of the new part IV, have been designed to take account of the broader corporate structure within which the Dried Fruits Board is to operate. Provision is therefore made for the chairpersons of both the board and the Corporation to present reports and for the board chairperson to present the board's last audited financial statements. As well, levy payers will be able to debate and vote upon changes to the rates of levy and export charge and, in the extreme case, on motions of no confidence in the board chairperson and members.

Only levy payers of dried vine fruit will be eligible to vote at the annual general meeting of the Australian Dried Fruits Board and provision is made for the board to establish a register of such persons for each meeting. Voting entitlements will be relative to levy paid. The detailed procedures for convening a meeting and establishing the register of voters will be set out in regulations.

The Commonwealth will continue to collect and disburse industry levies to fund the operations of the Australian Dried Fruits Board as is the case for the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation. Costs of these activities are fully recovered by the Commonwealth and there are no costs to Consolidated Revenue which will result from the Bill.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.

I have moved the amendments because of the Opposition's concern about the slowness of the Minister in bringing reports from the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) and its councils to this Parliament. In our view, it would be better if the Act were tightened so that there is a requirement on the Minister to bring reports before us in a speedier fashion than is the case at the moment.

The amendments do nothing to reform the whole defective structure of advice and decision making that applies to education at present; they cannot make NBEET and its councils genuinely separate from the Minister; and they cannot stop politically motivated decision making by the Minister. What the amendments can do is speed up the time in which these reports are provided to Parliament.

The report of the Higher Education Council (HEC) which was presented to the Board last August did not reach us in this Parliament until November. It took six weeks for the report to get from the Board to the Minister. The report was not presented to Parliament until November. The present requirement allowing up to 15 sitting days is permitting this unjustifiably long time for reports to reach us and the public. For there to be healthy debate in any policy area, there needs to be adequate information; and in higher education, there needs to be access by the interested public to these documents as quickly as possible. Thus the Opposition seeks to speed up the process by changing the requirement from 15 to five sitting days. There is no doubt that the 15 days allowed have been abused, frankly, by the Government, which has stretched them to as long a time as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot stretch them for any longer than 15 days.

—That is a nonsensical interjection from the Minister, and one that I would expect. One can stretch them into longer days by determining the non-sitting periods and bringing reports in in such a way that the presentation of that information can be delayed for 8 1/2 weeks and has been. One wonders, in view of that response, whether it is not deliberate by this Government-a deliberate stretching, a deliberate set of delays, pushing the delay factor as long as it possibly can. What its motives are, I do not know. I do not attribute generous ones to it, because it is not in this Government's interests obviously to provide information speedily and properly to this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I dare say that the Government will try to tell us that this is not practical and it all takes longer and so on. Quite frankly, there is no cause to believe the Government on that score. The Government is not being anything more than a postbox, a sort of monumentally inefficient Australia Post-I look at the Minister and that concept comes to me-if it takes 7 1/2 weeks. I will give examples in a minute to cheer the Minister up about how this 15 days has been stretched into 7 1/2 to 8 1/2 weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —The average is 42 days.

—The Minister has made that point already in the second reading debate. One could say that the average weight of the Government is something; that does not mean there are not some very large members of the Government. We are objecting and complaining about particular instances. We are not asking the Minister to add something to the report as it comes through his dilatory letterbox. We are asking simply for the Minister to pass the report on to the people for whom it is intended-the Parliament and the people. If the Minister were wanting to make some commentary on these things, maybe he might have some justification for spending so much time doing it. But there is no policy statement, as I said.

SPEECH.PARA: All we want is to require the Minister-because obviously it is not going to be done unless there is a requirement-to respond promptly and to convey promptly to us what has been conveyed to him. I believe that it is entirely practical for the printing and other arrangements to be accomplished so that tabling can occur within five sitting days.

Perhaps to cheer up the Minister, I should give him the instances which he seeks to hide under a cloak of averages. I do not know whether the Minister's average relates only to section 25 reports or to any other reports. But I want to deal specifically with section 25 reports. When the Minister ceases getting briefed he may be able to--

TALK.START.PARA: —This isn't my Bill.
—But the Minister is capable of top level interjections as though he knows something about it. Presumably, if these are section 25 reports which he claims are the average--
—This isn't your Bill either, is it?

—Fortunately, I have taken the trouble firstly to listen-mistakenly-to the Minister's interjections during the second reading debate and I now have to put up with them again. They are the same interjections and they are just as ridiculous.
—They are thin arguments.

—Let us see how thin this argument is: why did it take-perhaps the Minister in charge of the matter will be able to explain this to us-8 1/2 weeks? The first report of 1989 went from HEC to NBEET, I think, on 23 February; it was endorsed by NBEET on 24 February; on 2 March it went from NBEET to the Minister; and it was tabled in the Senate on 4 May. SPEECH.PARA: On 21 August 1989-the Parliament was sitting-HEC sent the second report to NBEET; it was endorsed by NBEET on 25 August; NBEET sent it to the Minister on 31 August and it was tabled in the Senate on 25 October. Perhaps Senator Collins thinks that is remarkable expedition. It may be when it is relative to what Senator Collins thinks is speed. MARINE NAVIGATION (REGULATORY FUNCTIONS) LEVY BILL 1991
The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision in the last budget to recover the costs of marine safety and regulation from the industry that benefits from this regulation.

Maritime and safety regulatory functions include ship control and ship safety-related activities, bulk cargo and dangerous goods inspections and the administration of the Marine Council. These functions were transferred to the new Australian Maritime Safety Authority on 1 January 1991.

The levy will be imposed on all sea-going ships except those exempted by regulation. The ships that will be exempt are those that are exempt from payment of the existing navigation levy and include commercial ships under 24 metres, fishing vessels, pleasure craft and ships in ballast.

The levy will be phased in over three years with full cost recovery by the 1993/94 financial year. The present cost of providing these services is currently estimated at $7.1 million dollars per year.

The formula for calculating the levy is similar to the existing Marine Navigation Levy and is based on a sliding scale which ranges from 2 to 4 cents per net registered ton, with the rate per net ton being reduced as the ship's tonnage increases. The maritime industry was invited to propose alternatives to this method but no practical alternative was put forward.

The Bill also allows the rate of levy to be varied by regulation. However, after the phasing in period has been completed, the annual rate of increase in the levy which may be effected by regulation will be limited to an absolute maximum of 15 per cent. Any actual increase in the levy effected in this way will be related to reasonable cost increases.

To summarise, Mr President, this Bill and its associated collection Bill will provide funding to ensure that ship safety standards and the protection of the marine environment will continue to be maintained.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
MARINE NAVIGATION (REGULATORY FUNCTIONS) LEVY COLLECTION
BILL 1991
This Bill sets out the necessary procedures for the collection of the proposed regulatory functions levy and provides minor amendments to other legislation.

It provides for the levy to be paid to a Collector of Customs or an authorised person. The levy will not be payable merely because a ship calls at an Australian port for shelter, repairs or refitting, to take on provisions, to change crew or to land a crew member for medical treatment.
The levy will not be required to be paid for a ship more than 4 times a year.
Ships exempted by regulation under the Marine Navigation Levy Collection Act 1989 will also be exempted from paying this levy and I gave some examples of those when introducing the Levy Bill.
The Bill also allows payment of the levy to be made in person or by post or by a prescribed method.
The Bill amends the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act 1990 to provide for payments of the levy to be appropriated to the Authority, which provides these services to the shipping industry.
The Bill also amends the Marine Navigation Levy Collection Act 1989 to ensure that the procedures involved in paying that levy and the proposed levy are consistent.
In summary, Mr President, this Bill provides the administrative detail to give effect to the levy.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

In other words, it must get rid of cabotage between Australia and New Zealand.
—Why didn't you?

—I would like to touch on coastal shipping, but I would reply to Senator Collins by saying that there is a good reason. The people who work on the waterfront are a major influence within the Australian Council of Trade Unions, as Senator Collins will know. The waterside workers have always had a powerful influence in that body. In fact, since the Minister has interjected on this point--
—I am asking why you didn't.
—Because those opposite are the political arm of the trade union movement. That movement would torpedo this country in an effort to get rid of a government it did not like.
—I was asking why your Government didn't.

—I think that I have given the Minister the answer. Let me touch briefly on coastal shipping going back many years. It has never ceased to amaze me that it is cheaper, more efficient and safer to move half a dozen motor vehicles by way of a semi-trailer from Melbourne to my own city of Brisbane than to put a hundred on a roll-on roll-off vessel and move those same motor vehicles from Melbourne to Brisbane. Why? That cannot be the case. In a cost comparison it cannot be cheaper to move those vehicles on rubber than by way of vessels, that is, if we were permitted to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Until that time comes, I frankly cannot see how we will be able to tackle the awful economic problems confronting this country. In addition, there is the incredible cost of building and maintaining the road system which must take those loads when it is patently obvious to anyone that, if the freedom existed to ply those ships, we would be able to do so at a much lower cost. TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have no difficulty supporting the purpose of these Bills. SPEECH.PARA: I want to address my comments to the difficulty the Democrats have with some of the procedures set in train by these Bills-specifically, the way in which the Government could be seen to be using regulation to erode parliamentary power.

The first Bill, the Marine Navigation (Regulatory Functions) Levy Bill 1991, sets out in subclause 7(2) the various rates of levy which would apply to ships when the Bill is enacted. In each case an amount of levy per tonne is specified, but there is also the proviso:
or such other amount as is from time to time prescribed.

This prescription will be by regulation. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has drawn attention to this subclause in terms of the inappropriate delegation of legislative power. The Committee draws attention specifically to the fact that, although the levy cannot be increased by more than 15 per cent in any 12 consecutive months, this prohibition does not come into force until June 1993. So up until this date there is no limit on the amount that such a levy can be increased.

Senator Parer foreshadowed an Opposition amendment to clarify this position. He said that the levy was really a form of taxation. Much depends on how much is charged. If the levy were to be increased from, say, 4c a tonne to $4 a tonne, we could say that the levy appears to be a tax and, as such, it should be a matter for Parliament. I agree with Senator Parer that there is a disturbing trend to take matters off Budget. Who knows, as I often say, what is going to happen to Telecom's community service obligations should they find their way off Budget?

However, with respect to this, we should also consider that the Government is on record as having made a deliberate decision to phase in the levy over three years-starting at 35 per cent cost recovery in year one, increasing to 70 per cent in year two and 100 per cent in year three. It was a deliberate decision. The Government has a reason for it, and I am sure that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) will elaborate on that.

The costs that are to be recovered have never been recovered previously. I guess it is possible that, if the implementation date were brought forward by Senator Parer's amendment to the date of proclamation, industry would be prepared to comply. Our view on this amendment depends, too, on what view we may have of this Government's intention with respect to revenue raising between now and 1993.

The second Bill, the Marine Navigation (Regulatory Functions) Levy Collection Bill 1991, provides for the administration of the levy imposed by the first Bill that we are debating. Clause 7 of the Bill provides for the ways in which the levy is to be collected. Subclause 4 provides for payment to be made personally, by post addressed to the Collector, or-by paragraph (c)-as otherwise prescribed.

It is this paragraph (c) which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has drawn attention to. It is a Henry VIII clause, as it allows the amendment, by regulation, of the methods of payment as set out in the legislation. While this is a more mild version of a Henry VIII clause than some others we have seen in this place, nevertheless I want to emphasise the fact that this is not a good way for any government to attempt to operate.
Having said that, I want to draw attention to a subclause which is cause for greater concern, that is, subclause 11(2), which says:
the regulations may provide for the refund or remission (in whole or in part) of an amount of levy paid or payable in respect of a ship in such circumstances as are specified in the regulations.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee, whose deliberations we should treat with great consideration, points out that there is no guidance as to the grounds on which a levy could be refunded or remitted. This would be left up to the regulations. While such regulations would be disallowable, there would be no scope within the process of disallowance for the Parliament to have input into such regulations. Accordingly, I will be moving an amendment to clarify the process of refunding or remitting the levy.

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.

The speech read as follows-

This Bill is a machinery financing measure to enable certain defence expenditures to be met from the Loan Fund rather than from the Consolidated Revenue Fund and to supplement the moneys available to the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

The Bill is consistent with the practice, adopted over many years, of introducing an annual Loan Bill to authorise the issue of moneys from the loan fund to meet expenditures that have been appropriated by the Parliament but for which insufficient funds are available in the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

A Loan Bill is required this year because it now appears that the Consolidated Revenue Fund will be in deficit although the Budget as a whole is still expected to remain in surplus. The situation of the Consolidated Revenue Fund being in deficit while the Budget is in surplus arises because appropriations from the Fund include various items that are classified as financing transactions rather than budget outlays, so that they do not affect the budget outcome. These items include payments to the National Debt Sinking Fund and superannuation payments made by the Commonwealth on behalf of public trading enterprises.

The Bill provides authority for the Loan Fund to meet defence expenditures incurred after the passage of the Bill that would otherwise have been met from the Consolidated Revenue Fund, and to supplement the Consolidated Revenue Fund so that it can meet its other commitments. The Bill also provides the borrowing authority to cover these payments from the Loan Fund.

The Bill does not authorise expenditures additional to those already appropriated by Parliament, apart from loan raising expenses, which will be small. It is important that the Bill be passed as soon as possible so that necessary borrowings authorised under the Bill to finance the deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund can be accommodated within the Government's normal seasonal pattern of raisings.

In concluding, I emphasise that the Bill does not in any way impinge upon the prerogative of the Parliament to appropriate public moneys, but simply provides a mechanism for financing expenditures previously approved and appropriated by the Parliament. I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today a notice of motion in the name of Senator Brownhill to establish a joint select committee to inquire into the Family Law Act was declared formal and agreed to. I now take the opportunity on the adjournment of saying a few words about the Family Law Act. Since the Act came into operation, as at 31 December 1989 there have been 599,496 divorces, and a total of 705,279 children have been directly affected. As I understand it, those figures are to the end of December 1989. The Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act will have a very important task. There is probably no other piece of Commonwealth legislation which has produced such continuing animosity from the ordinary people who have come under its operation. It is often said that the difficulty lies in the administration of what is essentially a law which perpetuates injustice. I note that the terms of reference for the Committee are somewhat limited, but I believe that it will be necessary for the Chairman of the Committee and the Committee itself to accept submissions made to it from people who are concerned that they have suffered injustice as a result of the operations of the Act and other factors.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Brownhill has indicated that there will be a focus on the questions of reconciliation counselling and property and custody matters. It is important for the Senate to recall at this juncture that a terrible tragedy has been wreaked upon the community as a result of the number of divorces. This is a matter of concern and hurt particularly amongst those directly involved, and that surely is the most important matter for us to consider. But it also has an effect on the Commonwealth Budget. Some years ago I took out a figure which even then ran to something like $1.2 billion directly paid out by the Commonwealth as a result of the dissolution of marriage.

There have been a number of identifiable problems. The report on homeless children stated that a very substantial percentage of homeless youth have parents whose marriages have broken up. That also is surely a matter for consideration by the Committee, and no doubt there will be submissions which go to that aspect. I remind the Senate that some years ago-I think on 6 October 1983-I moved amendments to the Family Law Amendment Bill which received quite substantial support. Those amendments would have required a party to a marriage, 12 months prior to applying for a dissolution thereof, to undergo, together with the other party, counselling for the purpose of considering the legal, social and financial consequences of the dissolution of the marriage-in particular, the effect of that dissolution on any children of the marriage. Unfortunately, though that proposal received very substantial support, it was defeated.

I think it is necessary to point out that the counselling services of the Family Court of Australia provide largely, if not exclusively, divorce counselling, not reconciliation counselling. No doubt the Committee will be aware of section 43 of the Family Law Act, which asks questions of the Family Court counselling services as to whether the counselling has been effective and in accordance with the legislation. I remind the Senate of the provisions of section 43 of the Family Law Act, which states:

The Family Court shall, in the exercise of its jurisdiction under this Act or any other Act, and any other court exercising jurisdiction under this Act shall, in the exercise of that jurisdiction, have regard to-
(a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life;

(b) the need to give the widest possible protection and assistance to the family as the natural and fundamental group unit of society, particularly while it is responsible for the care and education of dependent children;
(c) the need to protect the rights of children and to promote their welfare; and
(d) the means available for assisting parties to a marriage to consider reconciliation or the improvement of their relationship to each other and to the children of the marriage.

Perhaps this Committee, at the end of the day, will be able to come forward with recommendations to improve the relationships between spouses and encourage the parties to the marriage to consider the effect of any possible dissolution on their own happiness, their own livelihood and the happiness and future of their children. I think an expectation has built up over a period as to what might come out of this inquiry. One finds from the letters one receives that there is a great deal of hurt out there in society. A great many people are carrying on their shoulders the burden of what they see as an injustice. Whatever happens, I believe that the Committee should receive the submissions that are made and consider them.

I hope that the terms of reference will not be interpreted narrowly. I know that my colleagues around the place, both here and in the House of Representatives, are concerned about this. I hope-indeed, I am confident from the feedback that I am getting-that it will not be the intention of persons I have spoken to to have the terms of reference narrowly interpreted. If people who feel as though they have suffered an injustice are not able to express themselves freely to the Committee, their frustration will be compounded, and I do not think that would be a good thing.

Part of our function here is a representative function. One of the ways that we exercise that function is to get information and submissions from constituents. I do not suppose there is one single member of parliament, either in this House or in the other, who has not received numerous representations concerning the operation of the Family Law Act.

So I see this as a first step. I hope that the Committee's considerations and recommendations will start to improve the situation, which needs to be improved not only for the individual welfare of married persons themselves and their children but for society as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I thank Senator Harradine for again reminding the Senate of the number of people involved with divorce, the number of children involved in divorce and the cost associated with divorce. He also talked of the heartbreak of people associated with divorce whose marriages have ended up in failure. One area he did not mention-and I am sure that this was only an oversight on his part and that he would have mentioned it had he thought of it-was the heartbreak for the grandparents when they see their children's marriages break up. In some cases, they do not even have access to their grandchildren. That is an area that we must all think about.

SPEECH.PARA: There are the problems caused with property settlements, particularly in the case of country properties. I know of cases where a father and son have built up a property over a lifetime and then, because of a property settlement following the divorce of the son, the property has had to be sold. As a result, the father and mother have had to move off the property. So there are problems in this respect.

Senator Harradine mentioned that a number of submissions would be sent to the Joint Select Committee into Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act. Because of the feeling amongst all people in this Parliament that something needs to be done to remedy some parts of the Act that are not working quite as well as people would hope, I am quite sure that the Committee will take into account the submissions that are put to it.

I do not believe the terms of reference are too narrow. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Spindler from the Australian Democrats, some of my colleagues and I helped to set the terms of reference in such a way that they are not too confined. This has been done so that at the end of the day we will be able to make some good recommendations so that things will be little bit better in the future.

I am very pleased that my motion was passed by the Senate tonight. I have been talking about it for some two years. In fact, it was introduced last May. I want to thank senators from all parties and persuasions in this chamber who, privately and publicly, supported this inquiry and who understand the reason it is so important that the inquiry proceed with haste. I also thank Senator Tate for his contribution and the help and support that he gave me earlier on. I will not go through all the names of members in the House of Representatives from all sides of politics who feel that there should be an inquiry. I hope that the motion to establish the Committee has a speedy passage through the other place.

There are a couple of points that I want to briefly canvass tonight. I believe the terms of reference as outlined are fairly comprehensive. I was concerned that the terms ought to reflect genuine community concerns while at the same time not be so broad as to render the inquiry unworkable. I believe that these terms cover most, if not exactly all, the points of view that have been put to me. As can be seen from the terms, there is an emphasis on the role of counselling and mediation-which Senator Harradine has already mentioned-and I believe that is very appropriate. It is important that the mediation and counselling be pursued if they can prevent the irretrievable breakdown of marriage.

Marriages ought not to fail for want of proper and timely counselling. It is only right that any inquiry into family law also examine the role and effectiveness of the counselling service. It was equally important in my view that custody and access be given high priority. Probably no other aspect of family law is more contentious than this, nor more heartbreaking. Similarly, reference is made to effective enforcement of rights and duties under the Act. Again, there is a perception, a view, that the Family Court of Australia lacks teeth and there is a need for court orders to be enforced. So we need to see whether the Act is at fault or whether its interpretation and administration could be strengthened or better worded.

In the revised terms, reference is made in part (c) to the question of property disputes arising out of de facto relationships. Before anyone is able to accuse me of anything or to read any motive into this, I would like to put a couple of points on record. I am a great believer in the institution of marriage. I do not support, nor do I particularly approve of, the concept of de facto relationships. But I also live in the real world. What was acceptable for young people in my day has changed today. It would have been unthinkable 30 years ago for teenagers to leave home to look for a job, or to move in with a friend of the opposite sex. Children borne out of wedlock used to be shunned by society and orphanages were filled with children from such backgrounds. Society today is more tolerant of such behaviour.

Whatever the reason, there are now many children living in family situations where the relationship has not been formalised nor legalised. It is just as common for those relationships to break down as it is for legal relationships. In both cases where families have been established and family homes have been set up, children are involved. I think that is something we have to remember when we are dealing with any part of this Act-that children are involved. The present legislative approach to de facto relationships and the legal consequences of breakdown are messy and it would seem appropriate that any inquiry into family law ought to extend to the question of extension of the Family Court powers to de facto relationships, particularly when there are many anomalies being presented to various courts arising out of property disputes of de facto partners. In fact, sometimes children of two marriages from the same parent are dealt with in different courts.

I believe that this inquiry-I back up Senator Harradine in what he said-may be able to enlighten all of us as to how we can better protect the institution of marriage and ensure the continuity of the family as the basic unit of our society. Marriage has always been the basic unit of our society. Let us hope that the inquiry is able to find out more reasons why certain things to do with the Act or even society are causing so many breakdowns of marriage.

The question of costs associated with divorce is an area that has been repeatedly brought to my attention. It has been included in this inquiry because it is the proper place for such an investigation to occur. I can understand and appreciate the reluctance of my colleague Senator Cooney to take on this additional and specific task in his cost of justice inquiry. I believe that it sits much better in this inquiry as part of the legal costs relating to family law.

Senator Harradine has already made some remarks about this inquiry and I know that Senator Spindler will make some as well. Senator Harradine is concerned-he has already mentioned this matter-at the raised expectations in the community as to the ability of this inquiry. That also worries me. Some seem to think that this inquiry will solve all marital problems. Of course it will not; of course it cannot. Because of that many will be disappointed that the part of the Act that affects them most has not had a recommendation to be changed. That should not stop us from trying to make some specific changes to the Act to avert some of the hurt and heartbreak that is occurring now.

I am grateful for the support I have been given in this quest. The development of the inquiry is not the result of any one person or any one action, it is the result of many people showing a concern. I believe that as parliamentarians we are here to voice their concerns through the parliamentary system to try to make things just a little better. It is the culmination of many hours work by a great many people by and large working together for a common purpose.

I thank those who have provided advice, information and assistance in this matter. Particular thanks must go to the staff of Senator Hill and the Hon. Andrew Peacock in the other place more recently who have taken much of the burden, as indeed have staff from probably all our offices. I am quite sure that the staff in Senator Spindler's office will be the same.

The work ahead is daunting, but the rewards for many in the community are great if all members of the committee, when they are elected, work on the inquiry with an open mind and a clear conscience. I thank the other members who have spoken tonight on this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the coming family law inquiry. In doing so, I thank Senator Vallentine for her courtesy in allowing me to speak in this bracket of senators who are addressing this particular issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I am moved to speak tonight in particular to reassure Senator Harradine, who has voiced a number of concerns, in particular, the necessity to address the counselling and mediation which could, and indeed should, be carried out before we proceed to the stage where a couple are facing divorce and an inevitable dissolution of their marriage. I wish to reassure him on that by pointing to the fact that before this inquiry got under way I was able to negotiate with the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) some increase in funding for such mediation services, which included family education and marriage education as well as mediation counselling, which is designed to keep a marriage together rather than to let it go to the point of irretrievable breakdown. I was rather sad that I was not able to get more concessions in a number of areas which I sought from the Attorney-General and that, as a result, we felt it necessary to support this particular inquiry.

I am not sorry that it has got to this point. I think it is necessary to acknowledge Senator Brownhill's perseverance over two years to get this inquiry going. He was gracious enough to acknowledge my contribution at the stage when we were looking at the terms of reference. I think proper credit must be given to his untiring efforts. If anyone deserves credit for getting this inquiry off the ground, it is Senator Brownhill.

I would like to point out one or two other aspects of the terms of reference which I was able to negotiate with both major parties, which I think go to some of the other concerns that Senator Harradine has mentioned. The recommendations that the Joint Select committee into Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act will make are not limited purely to amendments to the the Family Law Act, but I point out that there is also the phrase `and other action' which could, and should, be taken. I insisted that that was there to ensure that we could look at these mediation and counselling services which are outside the Act, and that we could look at funding questions. It is one thing to have a particular service in place as part either of a court or as part of some other counselling services, but it is quite another to ensure that it can function adequately and has the means to do so.

The other area that I was concerned about was actually specifically directed towards the role `of approved organisations providing marriage counselling and family mediation services'. So that area will be well and truly canvassed.

There is one other area which is of some direct personal concern to me; that is, the adversarial nature of our legal system, which in at least two areas-the industrial relations area and the family law area-is misplaced. If there are any areas which require a different approach, they are those two areas. The Committee will, as part of its investigations, have a look at the possibility of reducing the adversarial nature of proceedings in the family law area.

Judging by many of the approaches, letters and telephone calls that I have had, and I am that sure Senator Brownhill and others have had, many people feel quite strongly that their particular problems were in many cases exacerbated by the involvement of lawyers. Lawyers who, very often, actually created a dispute or certainly intensified it, were left to their own devices. With different counselling procedures the people concerned might have been able to resolve the difficulties and even heal the relationship much more easily. I think it is an important step forward for this inquiry to be looking at this particular aspect of the Family Court area.

The other point, already mentioned by Senator Brownhill, was the inclusion of legal costs which, at one stage, some people thought should be included in the cost of the justice inquiry, in which I am also participating but, clearly, costs cannot be separated from the procedures and from the problems that arise in a dispute in the family law area. I think it is appropriate and I am personally very glad that we were able to retain that as part of our terms of reference.

I shall not detain the Senate any longer except to make a personal commitment, which I think is shared by the other members of the Committee who will take part in this inquiry, that we will take it extremely seriously and that we will indeed, as Senator Harradine has requested, examine carefully the submissions that people make. I trust that it will not be necessary to exclude any of them from due consideration during the work of this Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to begin tonight by mentioning another horrible aspect uncovered in the aftermath of the Gulf war, that is, the publication of the discovery of a 60-mile long convoy of Iraqi vehicles bombed on the road to Umm Qasr as they fled out of Kuwait. These people were murdered in retreat. This comes just 10 days after the cease-fire and closely follows the mass destruction of another Iraqi convoy on the road to Basra, causing hundreds, maybe thousands, of deaths.

SPEECH.PARA: The Pentagon has not released any details about these Iraqi casualties, but I believe it should have enough intelligence on the ground at present to have access to that information. I have no doubt that information about atrocities on both sides is being suppressed, but it strikes me as very hypocritical indeed that the United States (US) now continually talks about the Iraqi war crimes when I believe that all war is a crime against humanity, especially when we have this awful spectacle of hundreds, maybe thousands, of Iraqi soldiers in all kinds of vehicles being shot as they tried to retreat from Kuwait. All war is a crime.

Many civilian deaths in Iraq and Kuwait were the direct result of exaggerated claims about Iraq's military capabilities. The military might of the high-tech forces aligned against Iraq was completely disproportionate to the threat. For example, of Iraq's 5,500 tanks, some 3,800 were old Soviet or Chinese types based on 1960s designs, with 1,500 or so of a relatively modern Soviet tank style, the T62s and the T72s. Yet we were consistently fed the line that Iraq had this massive capacity of 5,000 state of the art tanks. According to the US reports, the majority of the Iraqi army were poorly clothed and poorly fed conscripts rather than the crack military forces described before the war began.

In addition the Iraqi forces lacked night vision, which meant that they had no military capabilities after dark. However, the Pentagon constantly exaggerated the potential of the Iraqi military machine before the war to justify its planned onslaught. After the ground war phase had ended and the coalition's disproportionate firepower had been unleashed, the United States began to acknowledge the limited capabilities of the Iraqi military machine. It is instructive to quote General Norman Schwarzkopf, who denigrated the Iraqi military machine by denigrating Saddam Hussein's leadership abilities:
He is neither a strategist nor is he schooled in the operational art nor is he a tactician nor is he a general nor is he a soldier . . . other than that he's a great military man.

Yet this is the same person whom we were told had this massive military capability and therefore we needed to have this massive amount of military machinery against him to dislodge him from Kuwait. It is very interesting that many books are appearing now about the situation in Iraq. I have spoken here on several occasions about the fact that many countries-about 30 in total-have to take responsibility for the arming of Iraq and for creating this monster that then had to be destroyed. One of the books recently reviewed in the Guardian Weekly is entitled Unholy Babylon by Adel Darwish and Gregory Alexander. To quote just a few lines:
Twenty things you wouldn't have read in the [mainstream media] as the allies were walloping the Butcher of Baghdad.
1. Britain and the US blocked a Security Council resolution in September 1980 to condemn Iraq's aggression against Iran.
2. The State Department took Iraq off the list of countries involved with terrorism in March 1982, so that Baghdad could qualify for US trade credits.
3. The CIA gave Iraq satellite pictures of Iranian troops and their positions in 1986, in return for technical information about Soviet weapons.
4. Egyptian commandos led the Iraqi recapture of the Fao peninsula from Iran in April 1988. The US Navy jammed Iranian radar.
5. Reagan ``bitterly opposed'' attempts by Congress to impose sanctions on Iraq for gassing 3,000 Kurds in July 1988.

We have heard that particular incident referred to and of course it is absolutely deplorable, but it is very interesting that now we learn that the former President of the United States was opposed to any criticism of Iraq when that atrocity actually occurred.

Another source book on Iraqi civil liberty violations is entitled Human Rights In Iraq from the Middle East Watch. It was first published before Saddam became, in terms that were so convenient to the United States, `a monster'. Factual and well-documented, it allows itself two pages of damning judgment. It states:

Oil earnings have . . . made Iraq a coveted market for the industrialised nations. This substantial economic factor, reinforced by increasingly influential pro-Iraq lobbies, has provided an important incentive to the West to disregard brutal and widespread Iraqi abuses.

Iraq was allowed to get away with this kind of behaviour uncriticised. I think the world will have to learn this lesson and will pay bitterly for it in collective terms. Similar judgments about Iraq's violations of human rights over the last decade were provided last month by the International Commission of Jurists (ICJ) in a statement to the United Nations Human Rights Commission, which was overlooked in the rush to war in the latter part of 1990. That ICJ statement says:
After having perpetrated the most flagrant abuses on its own population without a word of reproach from the UN . . . Iraq must have concluded it could do whatever it pleased.

Many questions are raised by these various books, which are coming out now, about the background to the enormous change of heart that was so sudden and, obviously, was so convenient for the military planners who organised this war.

Was Saddam Hussein really planning to invade Saudi Arabia or was America's military response just an excuse to cover up a major blunder in US foreign policy? I quote again from the Guardian Weekly of 23 September 1990. This relates to the well-known-but it was not as well-known as it should have been earlier on-25 July conversation between United States Ambassador April Glaspie and Saddam Hussein in Baghdad. Only one week before he ordered his troops into Kuwait, the Iraqi leader warned the US Ambassador in Baghdad that America should not oppose his aims in the Middle East because:
``yours is a society that cannot accept 10,000 dead in one battle'' and is vulnerable to terrorist attack.

These statements were according to the Iraqi minutes of that conversation which have not been disputed by the State Department in Washington. Evidently, United States Ambassador Glaspie did not respond directly to Saddam Hussein's menacing comment, concentrating instead on praising Saddam's `extraordinary efforts' to rebuild his country. She also gently probed the Iraqi leader's intentions in massing troops on Kuwait's border but did not criticise the Iraqi troop movements. Iraq's version of the meeting shows Saddam giving Glaspie explicit warnings that he would take whatever action he deemed necessary to stop Kuwait from continuing an economic war against Iraq. Her response, as recorded by the Iraqis but not challenged by the State Department, was to reassure Saddam that the United States took no official position on Iraq's border dispute with Kuwait. She said:

I know you need funds. We understand that and our opinion is that you should have the opportunity to rebuild your country. But we have no opinion on the Arab-Arab conflicts, like your border disagreements with Kuwait . . . James Baker has directed our official spokesman to emphasise this instruction.

The disclosure of the transcript, which originated with Iraqi officials, appears intended to emphasise that Saddam had reason to believe that the Bush Administration would not offer any serious opposition to his move against Kuwait. They did seem to be surprised when it actually occurred on 2 August. Of course, there is no excuse for the brutality of that invasion or what has happened since then to the Kuwaiti people, for whom I feel a great sympathy, but I think we have not been told the whole story about the lead-up to this devastation. This war, more than anything else, has demonstrated that our world is in crisis, something which eminent scientists, academics and environmentalists have warned about for more than a generation-in fact, ever since World War II.
It was the `testing' of the atom bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki which was the stimulus for Einstein's famous statement:
The unleashed power of the atom has changed everything save our modes of thinking, and thus we drift towards unparalleled catastrophe.

But what or how do we need to think? What changes in our values and attitudes are necessary to achieve the changes in behaviour required for our survival? We in the affluent world, who constitute 20 per cent of the world's population and consume 75 per cent of its resources, would obviously need to change our patterns of consumption, for a start.

Consumerism would need to become unfashionable, simplicity valued. We would also need to take into account the effects of our present actions on the future. Further, we would need to understand that our survival cannot be at the expense of the quarter of humanity whose most basic needs are not currently met. We would need to re-examine our relationship to nature, to internalise the ecological doctrine and to see ourselves as custodians of nature, not its masters and despoilers. Can we, described by Danish poet Piet Hein as `global citizens with tribunal souls', achieve such radical changes in our thinking?
How we have been shaped into what we are and whether we can change our thinking are questions explored in Riane Eisler's challenging book, The Chalice and the Blade. Eisler asks:
Is a shift from a system leading to chronic wars, social injustice, and ecological imbalance to one of peace, social justice and ecological balance a realistic possibility?

Through a re-examination of our past, weaving together evidence from art, archaeology, religion, social science and history, Eisler argues that a fundamental shift in our direction is possible and is in fact firmly rooted in what actually happened in our past.

I am indebted to a great friend and clear thinker, Dr Edna Ross, not only for giving me a copy of this important book but also for her comments about it. Eisler's analysis of our past and present is from the perspective of the relations between the two halves of humanity-male and female. The result is a fascinating and convincing theory of our cultural evolution. This theory of cultural transformation proposes that underlying the surface diversity of human culture are two basic models of society. The dominator model, popularly termed either patriarchy or matriarchy, involves the ranking of one-half of humanity over the other. In the second model, the partnership model, social relations are primarily based on the principle of linking rather than ranking. The fundamental difference in our species, between male and female, is not equated with either inferiority or superiority.

Cultural transformation theory further proposes that the original direction of our cultural evolution was towards partnership. By examining new archaeological evidence, together with legends, biblical references and historical writings, Eisler creates an intricate tapestry depicting a long period of prosperity and peace during which technologies were developed in societies that were not male dominant, violent or hierarchic. Eisler's documentation suggests that during our prehistory, until the fall of Minoan Crete 3,200 years ago, societies displayed many of the perspectives we now see as necessary for our survival.

For example, in Neolithic art there is no imagery idealising armed might. Rather, there is a rich array of symbols from nature and a recurring theme of the unity of all things in nature, personified by the goddesses. In Cretan society there was a generally equitable distribution of wealth. This early period, during which our cultural evolution was moving towards partnership, was followed by a period of chaos and almost total cultural disruption when the direction of our cultural revolution was turned around.

There is evidence of invasions and of natural catastrophes. The invaders were Indo-Europeans and early Semitic tribes. They shared a dominator model of social organisation in which male dominance, male violence and a hierarchic social structure were the norm.

Another commonality that they characteristically acquired was wealth, not by developing technologies of production but through ever more effective technologies of destruction-which of course we have just witnessed yet again in the Gulf war. The title of the book derives from this cataclysmic turning point in the prehistory of Western civilisation. Societies that worship the life generating and nurturing powers of the universe, symbolised by the chalice, were taken over by invaders who worshipped the lethal power of the blade. Unfortunately, it seems as though that is where we still are.

Eisler explores this transformation in our history from the perspective of the relations between males and females. She shows how the way we structure this most fundamental of all human relations affects every one of our institutions, our values and the direction of our cultural evolution. By analysing human societies from the perspective that takes account of both men and women, she identifies patterns that characterise dominator or, alternatively, partnership models of social organisation.

From a conventional perspective, Hitler's Germany, Khomeini's Iran, Saddam Hussein's Iraq, the Japan of the Samurai and the Aztecs of Meso America are vastly different societies. Viewed from the perspective of cultural transformation theory, they share the social configuration characteristic of rigidly male dominated societies. They also have in common a generally hierarchic and authoritarian social structure and a high degree of social violence, particularly warfare.

The evidence presented in The Chalice and The Blade shows that behind the oscillating swings of history lie specific conflicts between dominator and partnership values. Periods characterised by increases in the masculine domination over women were periods of increased militarism and imperialism. Periods during which there was an increase in the status of women were characteristically ones of cultural resurgence. Eisler's argument that we have in our prehistory been through a fundamental change in the organisation of our society from a partnership to a dominator model has significance beyond its intrinsic interest. It shows that a fundamental change in how we structure society has occurred and therefore can occur again-which is the encouraging part of the story.

It is interesting that there happen to be only male senators in the chamber at the moment. I want to state very clearly that this is not a go at male society as it is at the moment; it is a part of a cultural conditioning which has got us into the situation in which we are. This is no bid for a complete transfer of power into another dominator kind of society, the matriarchy, which has been practised in some civilisations in the past. What I am talking about is a partnership model rather than a dominator model of either sex over the other.

The transformation from a partnership to a dominator type of organisation required fundamental changes in thinking, since what is considered normal and right under the two types of social organisation are poles apart. The way in which the required transformation of values and norms-that is, of minds-was brought about constitutes the second theme of Eisler's book. An intriguing tale of a monumental cover-up unfolds. If we accept that the replication of ideas is essential in forming and then maintaining social systems, then replacing a partnership social organisation with one based on force-backed domination required that changes in replicative information be made.

The process whereby the human mind was remoulded, which went on for millennia, entailed all the instruments of socialisation. One of the most important of these instruments was the spiritual education carried out by the ancient priesthoods. Eisler's documentation of the rewriting of our myths and sacred stories illustrates the way in which the constant refashioning of normative oral and written literature was an integral part of the process of norm changing through which a hierarchical society gradually began to be seen not only as normal but also as right.

The cumulative effect of this chronicle is disturbing at many levels. The suppression of information, which was seen as threatening to the new system, and the efforts of intellectuals to make reality conform to a dominator world view illustrates both the lengths to which those in power went to protect and entrench their position and the power of the replication of ideas in determining reality. Why do we not question how a righteous God could order his soldiers to commit acts of gross inhumanity towards their fellow human beings as we have seen so recently?

TALK.START.PARA: —We do question it.
—Some of us question it, but it was generally accepted that this was a very popular way of resolving a conflict and it really needs to be challenged.

SPEECH.PARA: Equally shocking is the demonstration of how our sacred texts function to maintain the boundaries that keep us imprisoned in a dominator system and, at a personal level, the realisation of the enormous toll of 5,000 years of conditioning on one's ability to think freely. Who has considered the implications of the biblical account of procreation in which endless lists of men begat other men and never a woman was mentioned, not to state the implications of women having been derived from man's rib as an afterthought, and the fall of grace initiated by Eve eating from the tree of knowledge?

It is impossible to do justice to Eisler's account in a short time such as this since it is the cumulative effect of the examples she uses that gives her argument its power. But what are the implications for the present and the future of the information presented in the Chalice and the Blade? Eisler's analysis of our history and pre-history shows that in the early days of civilisation our cultural evolution was truncated and then completely turned around. The evidence for the existence of a society organised on a partnership basis, and the associated cultural and technological evolution of such a society, suggests that it is not human nature but the organisation of a society which determines the direction of its evolution. It also shows how the old roots of civilisation were never eradicated.

Throughout our history there have been periods where values consistent with a partnership system have gained prominence. All modern, post-enlightenment movements for social justice as well as the more recent feminist peace and ecology movements are part of an underlying thrust for the transformation of a dominator system to a partnership system. However, it is only feminism which explicitly addresses the fact that underlying the problems on which these movements focus is a male dominator, female dominated model of the human species. It is only feminism which explicitly recognises that the way a society structures the most fundamental of human relations profoundly affects all aspects of living and thinking.

The world view which various scholars have identified as being necessary for our survival is consistent with the partnership model of society and the values of feminism. It is not consistent with the values embodied in a dominator society. For this reason, feminism could become the nucleus for a consistent ideology required to replace the dominator with a partnership society. Under a dominator model of social organisation, the crises that our planet faces today are insoluble.

Eisler shows that the most urgent problems require solutions which change the status and role of women. For example, present policies have failed to slow down significantly the population explosion. For population planning to succeed it is necessary to give top priority to reproductive freedom and equality for women and to create satisfying, socially rewarding roles for women other than those of wives and mothers, although that is not to denigrate the position of wives and mothers-far from it.

These are women's issues. They are not given top priority. Human evolution is now at a crossroads. There have been significant changes in the relationships between men and women over the past 20 years. Feminine values are increasingly seen as desirable, even amongst men. This is indeed encouraging. Even Rod Cameron has talked about the feminisation of Australian politics-a welcome change, if indeed he is right. The gains of the women's movement have posed the strongest challenge to male supremacy in thousands of years, and the increase in Christian and Islamic fundamentalism is seen by Eisler as a response to this perceived threat of the ascendancy of feminisation.

Probably the most significant changes in the relationship between males and females have been within the family. The argument and evidence presented in the Chalice and the Blade that a partnership society offers a viable alternative future are convincing. But how do we get from here to there? It is in answering this question that the book is probably at its weakest. Eisler argues that humans have the ability to choose their own evolutionary path and that, since our actions are determined by ideas and the way we conceive possibilities, it is how we will view reality, what is possible and desirable, which will determine our future.

The Chalice and the Blade presents a comprehensive and challenging perspective of our social evolution. It is a big book, not in its bulk but in its provision of a new way of looking at ourselves. It presents a strong argument for the proposition that the achievement of the goals of feminism may provide a social organisation which will address the crises we now face; for the view that feminism is not just good for women but essential for us all.

Maybe this ghastly war, in which Australia participated so enthusiastically at the behest of the United States but not without vigorous, if unpopular, dissent in this country, will be the last hurrah of the militarists. I sincerely hope so. It seems that the dominators needed to reassert their authority when faced with the evidence that the feminisation of culture was on the ascendancy. So they have used their destructive technology with devastating effect. The whole truth of the horrors may never be known. What we do know should provide a signal lesson that humanity cannot continue with the dominator, destructive, exploitative behaviour which results in human and environmental losses on a massive scale. A new path, perhaps the partnership model put forward by Riane Eisler, must be found.
