ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Illegal Fishing in Great Barrier Reef

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 6 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action, if any, is the Government taking to address the problem of illegal fishing by Australian and overseas vessels in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park?
(2) Has there been any reported damage to the reef from the actions of poachers?
(3) What is the estimated amount of marine life removed or destroyed by illegal fishing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Poaching in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park has been a problem in the past. The high level of surveillance effort undertaken in recent years has drastically reduced the number of infringements detected in the Marine Park. The surveillance program uses information sourced from several elements including:
* Coastwatch aircraft;
* Queensland National Parks and Wildlife surveillance aircraft;
* RAAF Orion patrols of the Australian Fishing Zone;
* RAN Patrol Boat surveillance vessels; and

* Regular patrols by the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service, Queensland Water Police and Queensland Boating and Fisheries Patrol (who are responsible for the day-to-day management of the Marine Park).

Australia also cooperates with foreign governments in trying to discourage incursions into the Australian Fishing Zone. These programs aim to make foreign fishermen aware of the penalties for illegal fishing in Australian waters and the likelihood of apprehension.

(2) It is very difficult to directly attribute specific instances where damage has been caused to the reef by the illegal activities of poachers. There are however exceptions where vessels become grounded on the reef and are subsequently found to have been engaged in illegal activities. Detected instances of this are rare.

(3) It is not possible to provide accurate estimates of the marine life removed by illegal fishing. The poaching of clam meat was a significant problem up to the late 1970s but all evidence indicates that the level of poaching activity is now very low. Untended drift nets which continue to indiscriminately trap marine life do represent a problem.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 6 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Gulf war having a significant impact on the Australian overseas tourism industry.
(2) Have any measures, including Government financial assistance, been initiated to stimulate this industry since the start of the Gulf crisis.
(3) What would be the estimated number of job losses to this country in the event of major set-backs to Australian tourism.
(4) What is the anticipated effect of the Gulf War on tourism oriented businesses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Reports from the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) and industry indicate that, while international travel was severely disrupted during the conflict, and there was a significant impact on some sectors of Australia's tourism industry, Australia was relatively less affected than other major travel destinations. This in part reflected the perception by many that Australia was relatively safe, and well removed from the war. As a result some travellers decided to revise their plans and visit Australia in preference to their original destinations.

The end of the Gulf War will greatly reduce the level of uncertainty being faced by the tourism industry. It should lead to a return to more normal international travel patterns and a more favourable climate for the ATC's marketing program.

(2) During the period of the Gulf War the Government closely monitored market developments with the assistance of the ATC. Market assessments have been regularly updated by the ATC in conjunction with the Inbound Tourism Organisation of Australia (ITOA) and the Australian Tourism Industry Association (ATIA), to ensure that the timing and scope of promotional activities were appropriate to developments in major source countries.

Special meetings were also held with State and Territory tourism ministers and the Tourism Advisory Council to exchange views on the effects of, and discuss strategies in response to, the Gulf situation to minimise the adverse effects on tourism to Australia.

No Government financial assistance was specifically allocated as a result of the Gulf crisis. The decision in December by the Government to boost promotional funding for the ATC by $23 million has helped to ensure that Australia continues to actively promote itself in our target markets. International promotion and marketing by the ATC, including a new campaign in North America, Japan and Asia featuring Greg Norman, is to be launched by the middle of the year.

(3) &(4) There is little doubt that some tourism operators experienced disruptions during the Gulf War although the net effect on business and tourism employment, particularly over the longer term, will be hard to quantify.

For the reasons outlined in (1) above, Australia's tourism industry has been relatively less affected, particularly when compared to other international travel destinations. It is likely that some potential visitors lost initially due to the war may now be regained.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the International Police Organisation (Interpol) applied to the Commonwealth Government to set up a base in this country.

(2) Does Interpol require complete immunity from intervention or enquiry for its staff and equipment by a host government; if so, what measures of control does a host country have over Interpol at law.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The International Criminal Police Organisation (ICPO), commonly known as Interpol, has never asked the Australian Government to set up any kind of base in Australia.
In 1948 Australia applied to Interpol to establish a National Central Bureau (NCB) in Australia, and was accepted.

At the 59th General Assembly of Interpol in Ottawa last year, Interpol delegates accepted Australia's offer for its NCB to be the Regional Communications Centre for Interpol in the South Pacific. Communications traffic to and from member countries in the South Pacific will now be channelled through Canberra. Strict confidentiality will be maintained by the NCB in its handling of the messages received and transmitted, in that hard copies of the messages will not be retained unless the message involves Australia. The Communications Centre will not require the allocation of any additional equipment or resources to the NCB.

(2) No. Firstly Interpol does not have ``host'' governments: it is made up of 154 member countries throughout the world. Its headquarters is at Lyon in France and each member country has an established link with Interpol Headquarters known as an NCB.

Responsibility for the control, operation and administration of an NCB rests with the member country. The staff and equipment in a country's NCB are subject to the laws of that country. Interpol does not require immunity from intervention or enquiry for its staff and equipment because it does not have staff or equipment in member countries.

Within Australia the NCB is administered by the Commissioner of the AFP and the personnel who work in the NCB are AFP personnel. The Australian NCB operates strictly within Australian law, including for example the Privacy Act, and its staff are subject to Australian criminal, civil and administrative laws. Additionally its staff are subject to the AFP disciplinary provisions including the overseeing of complaints by the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

While there is an agreement that individual staff assigned to NCBs in France, Argentina &Thailand cannot be sued, an NCB in any country can be sued through the member country's government according to the laws of that country, for example in Australia through the Commissioner of the AFP.
